questions.text: A 48-year-old male presents with constipation and anal bleeding. A mass is detected on digital rectal examination, prompting a CT with rectal contrast and a biopsy for suspected malignancy. Histopathological examination of the biopsy will confirm normal tissues of the anal canal as the transitional zone (area of Pecten) is lined by which type of epithelium?
questions.solution:
Option A: columnar → cuboidal → squamous

  • Option A is the correct statement as it accurately mentions the epithelial lining of the Anal transition zoneis lined by (superior to inferior) which is Columnar → Cuboidal → Squamous
  • The dentate line (Pectinate line) is Squamocolumnar junction; below is Squamous Epithelium, and above is the transitional zone, Columnar → Cuboidal Epithelium.
  • The pectinate line divides the anal canal into two parts (Upper and lower) which signifies the difference in structure and neurovascular supply of both parts.
  • The part of the anal canal above the pectinate line is derived from the embryonic hindgut and has the same epithelium as the intestines and rectum.
  • The lower part of the anal canal below the pectinate line is lined by non-keratinized squamous epithelium that continues with the keratinized epithelium of the anal skin.

Option B: columnar → squamous → cuboidal

  • This option is false as it says cuboidal → squamous → columnar. In contrast, Squamous epithelium is not present between the columnar and cuboidal epithelium.
  • It is at the lower part of the anal canal below the pectinate line.

Option C: squamous → cuboidal → columnar

  • This option is false as it says squamous → cuboidal → columnar, which is a total reversal of the correct answer.

Option D: cuboidal → squamous → columnar

  • The columnar epithelium is at the proximal end, and the squamous epithelium is at the distal end of the transitional zone.

questions.text: As a first-year resident in the Orthopaedics department, you observe a 15-year-old male presenting with frequent fractures every 3 months. Suspecting osteogenesis imperfecta type I, which type of collagen is involved in this disorder?
questions.solution:
Option A: Type I

  • Type I collagen is the most common type and is found in;
    • Bones
    • Fibro-cartilage [atypical cartilage]
    • Dermis [skin]
    • Old scar
  • Type I: Decreased production in osteogenesis imperfecta type I.
  • Osteogenesis imperfecta type I is a genetic disorder that results in skeletal deformities and deformity of bones.
  • The genetic mutation of the COL1A1 gene.
  • ↓ Formation of the hydrogen and disulfide bonds between type I pre-procollagen molecules → ↓ triple helix formation → ↓ synthesis of normal type I collagen → impaired bone matrix formation (osteogenesis).
  • Clinical features are:
    • Delay of growth.
    • Brittle bones, skeletal deformities.
    • Saber shins and bowing of bones.
    • Childbirth fracture.
    • Recurrent fracture from minimal trauma.
    • Deformation atrophy of the ossicles leads to progressive loss of hearing.
    • Lack of dentin leads to dentinogenesis imperfecta, brittle, opalescent teeth.
    • Blue sclerae.

Option B: Type II

  • Type II collagen is found in hyaline & elastic cartilage.

Option C: Type III

  • Type III collagen is found in
    • Lymphoid organs with reticular tissue [liver, spleen, lymph nodes]
    • Healing/Granulation tissue
  • Type III: Deficient in the uncommon, vascular type of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.

Option D: Type IV

  • Type IV collagen is found in
    • Basal lamina/membrane
    • Type IV: Under the floor (basement membrane). Defective in Alport syndrome; targeted by autoantibodies in Goodpasture syndrome.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to OPD with complaints of headache after hitting her head accidentally with the wall while doing household chores. An MRI was ordered, which confirmed the presence of a blood clot in her great cerebral vein of Galen. An obstructed vein is a direct tributary of which of the following venous structures?
questions.solution:
Option D: Dural venous sinuses

  • Dural venous sinuses lie between the two layers of the dura mater:
    • Meningeal layer
    • Endosteal layer

  • The great cerebral vein of Galen is a direct tributary of the dural venous sinus, eventually draining into the internal jugular vein.
  • Dural venous sinuses are venous channels located intracranially between the two layers of the dura mater (endosteal layer and meningeal layer) and can be conceptualized as trapped epidural veins.
  • Unlike other veins in the body, they run alone and not parallel to arteries. Furthermore, they are valveless, allowing for bidirectional blood flow from and into intracranial veins.
  • Together, the dural venous sinuses form the major drainage pathways from the brain, predominantly to the internal jugular veins.
  • It is important to note that the draining territories of intracranial veins are different from those of arterial territories of the major cerebral arteries.

Option A: Emissary's veins

  • Emissary's veins have an important role in the selective cooling of the head.
  • They also serve as routes where infections are carried into the cranial cavity from the extracranial veins to the intracranial veins.
  • There are several emissary veins, including posterior condyloid, mastoid, occipital and parietal emissary veins.
  • Emissary's veins are the venous structure that links the extracranial vessels of the scalp to the intracranial veins, such as the dural venous sinus.
  • They are valveless veins.
  • They drain from the scalp into the skull through the foramen.

Option B: Pterygoid venous plexus

  • The pterygoid venous plexus is located in the infra-temporal fossa.
  • Eventually drains into the maxillary vein.
  • Important from a dentistry point of view.
  • It also links with the cavernous sinus.

Option C: Diploic veins

  • Diploic veins are present in the diploe between inner and outer layers of the cranial bones of skull.
  • Diploic veins drain into the emissary's veins, eventually draining into the dural venous sinus.
  • The great cerebral vein of Galen is a direct tributary of the dural venous sinus.

questions.text: A 43-year-old male underwent a parotidectomy for a malignant lesion in the right parotid region. He now experiences loss of sensation while shaving. Which nerve could have been iatrogenically injured, causing this symptom?
questions.solution:
Option D: Greater Auricular Nerve

  • The patient's current symptoms of numbness in the parotid area followed by surgery of the parotid gland suggest damage to the Great auricular nerve.
  • The great auricular nerve arises from the spinal nerves C2 and C3 and joins the cervical plexus of nerves in the neck.
  • It courses along the surface of the sternocleidomastoid, perforates the cervical fascia, and ascends superiorly towards the parotid gland. Here, it divides into its terminal branches.
  • The anterior terminal branch of the Great auricular nerve supplies the skin of the face over the parotid gland. In contrast, the posterior branch innervates the skin over the mastoid process and the posterior surface of the auricle.
  • As the Great auricular nerve innervates the skin over the parotid, damage to this during parotidectomy would cause the loss of innervation in the skin of the face over the parotid gland. This is consistent with the patient’s symptoms of numbness while shaving the affected area.
  • The following diagram illustrates the proximity of the Great auricular nerve to the parotid gland:

Option A: Facial Nerve

  • Chorda tympani is a branch of the facial nerve, traversing through the middle ear into the oral cavity and carrying taste sensations from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. It also carries parasympathetic fibres to the sublingual and submandibular glands.
  • Chorda tympani has no cutaneous innervation or branches to the parotid gland.
  • Damage can occur during dental or inner ear surgical procedures, and it is very unlikely for the chorda tympani to get damaged in parotid surgeries.
  • Damage to chorda tympani can lead to the loss of taste or taste disturbances.

Option B: Mandibular Nerve

  • The mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve supplies cutaneous innervation to the ipsilateral chin/mandibular area below the level of the angle of the mouth.
  • Damage to the main trunk of the mandibular nerve can lead to a sensory deficit in the chin/mandibular area.

Option C: Auriculotemporal Nerve

  • The auriculo-temporal nerve carries parasympathetic secretomotor fibers to the parotid gland.
  • After parotidectomy, sometimes there may be a regeneration of secretomotor fibers in the Auriculotemporal Nerve.
  • This regeneration is misdirected into the sweat gland.
  • Thus, whenever the patient thinks of food/smells /chews food, there would be stimulation of sweat glands and hyperemia, resulting in redness and sweating in front of the ear on the cheek, called Frey's Syndrome.

questions.text: A 37-year-old male presents with a sudden severe sore throat, left ear pain, voice change, and difficulty opening his mouth fully for the past 3 days. On examination, there is significant fluctuant erythematous swelling involving the left tonsil and drooling of saliva. Which nerve is responsible for the referred pain in the patient's ear?
questions.solution:
Option B: Glossopharyngeal Nerve

  • The above case scenario is typical of Quinsy, also known as a peritonsillar abscess, characterized by a fluctuant, erythematous unilateral swelling involving the tonsil.
  • The pain in the ear in the case described above is typical of referred pain. Referred pain is the type of pain that is felt in a location different than the site of the painful stimulus.
  • Referred pain occurs when the different sensory pathways converge on the same level of the brainstem or spinal cord, resulting in the lack of distinction of the areas originally affected.
  • The glossopharyngeal nerve supplies the posterior one-third of the tongue, palatine tonsils, oropharynx, middle ear mucosa, pharyngotympanic tube, and mastoid air cells. As the ear and the palatine tonsils share the same sensory nerve, the pain in cases of peritonsillar abscess can be referred to the ear. This is shown in the diagram below:

  • Moreover, the glossopharyngeal nerve passes close to the peritonsillar space, which might get irritated by an inflammatory process in this region (Peritonsillar abscess or Quinsy), and this pain is referred to the middle ear via the glossopharyngeal nerve through its branch to the tympanic plexus on the medial wall of the middle ear cleft.

Option A: Facial Nerve

  • The sensory distribution of the facial nerve in the ear is far less than the other nerves. It supplies just a part of the external auditory meatus and tympanic membrane.
  • The facial nerve also innervates the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, submandibular, and sublingual glands.
  • Hence, any inflammatory process in these structures can irritate the facial nerve and referred otalgia.
  • Typical examples of referred otalgia via the facial nerve include:
    • Dental infections
    • Herpes zoster infection of the geniculate ganglion
    • Elongation of the styloid process and calcification of the stylohyoid ligament.

Option C: Trigeminal Nerve

  • Trigeminal nerve supplies sensory innervation to the face, temporomandibular joint (TMJ), nasal cavity, and maxillary sinuses, and not within the oral cavity.
  • Referred otalgia may be caused by the trigeminal nerve in the following conditions:
    • TMJ Syndrome
    • Disorders of the mandible or lower dentition
    • Trigeminal neuralgia
    • Disorders of the maxillary sinus and the nasal cavity

Option D: Auriculotemporal Nerve ​​​​​​​

  • The auriculotemporal nerve is a branch of CN V3 and supplies parasympathetic fibers to the parotid gland.
  • It causes referred otalgia only in the cases of parotid gland pathologies and post-parotidectomy.
  • It has no connection with the oral cavity or the otalgia referred from tonsillitis.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man underwent thyroidectomy. The nerve that accompanies the superior thyroid artery is damaged during the surgery. An injured nerve could result in a severe impairment of which of  the following functions?
questions.solution:
Tensing the vocal cords

  • The External laryngeal nerve innervates the cricothyroid muscle (major tensor) which tenses the vocal cord.
  • Hence damage to this nerve will lead to the inability to tense the vocal cords.
  • To prevent injury, superior. thyroid artery should be ligated

Learning objective

  • Laryngeal Mucosa Supply
    • Till the vocal cord/ upper surface of VC: Internal LN.
    • Below vocal cord/form lower surface of VC: Recurrent LN
    • Laryngeal Mucosa on Vocal Cord Supplied by: Internal LN
    • In Thoracic inlet syndrome: Lt recurrent laryngeal nerve is Involved

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is taken to the emergency room because of dyspnea, palpitations, and shortness of breath. A Doppler examination of the heart reveals an atrial septal defect (ASD). This malformation is generally the result of incomplete closure of which of the following embryonic structures?
questions.solution:
Option D: Foramen ovale

  • The atrial septum separates the right atrium from the left atrium and has the fossa ovalis and annulus ovalis.
  • The fossa ovalis is a shallow depression that marks the site of the fetal foramen ovale.
  • The floor of the fossa represents the persistent septum primum of the embryonic heart, and the annulus forms from the lower edge of the septum secundum.
  • Atrial septal defect (ASD) is a malformation that generally results from incomplete closure of the foramen ovale.

Option A: Ductus arteriosus

  • The ductus arteriosus and the pulmonary arteries develop from the left sixth aortic arch.
  • The ductus arteriosus closes functionally in an infant soon after birth, with anatomic closure requiring several weeks, but persistent 6th arch artery leads to PDA.

Option B: Ductus venosus

  • After birth, Ductus venosus is closed and becomes ligamentum venosum
  • Patent ductus venosus is a rare condition

Option C: Sinus venarum

  • The posterior wall of the right atrium and sinus venarum (smooth portion)
  • Veins opening here are
    • Coronary sinus
    • Posterior cardinal vein: IVC
    • Anterior cardinal vein: SVC

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents to the emergency department due to persistent hiccups post-cholecystectomy. Suspected abdominal abscess irritation of the diaphragm is causing this. Which nerves carry pain fibers from the central part of the diaphragm's lower surface?
questions.solution:
Option C: Phrenic nerve

 

  • The diaphragm, a muscle of respiration, separates the chest from the abdomen.
  • The phrenic nerve, which runs from the neck to the diaphragm, supplies the diaphragm.
  • The phrenic nerve supplies somatic motor fibres to the diaphragm.
  • It also carries pain fibres from the peritoneum covering the central part of the lower surface of the diaphragm.
  • The periphery of the diaphragm gets the sensory innervation from the 6th-11th intercostal nerves and the subcostal nerve.

Options A: Vagus nerve

  • The vagus, a nerve, does not supply any fibres to the diaphragm.

Option B: Lower intercostal nerve

  • The peritoneum of the central part of the diaphragm receives sensory fibres from the phrenic nerve.
  • The peripheral part of the diaphragm receives these fibres from the lower intercostal nerves (T6-T12).

Option D: Greater splanchnic nerve

  • The greater splanchnic nerve supplies the foregut and adrenal medulla.
  • It has no fibres supplying the diaphragm.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy is admitted to the emergency room after losing control in a motorcycle race in which several other drivers ran him over. The physical exam shows multiple cuts and bruises on the left forearm. The left wrist, fingers, and thumb cannot be straightened, although the elbow can be straightened. There is sensory deficit at the side half of the back of the left hand. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
Option C: Radial nerve

  • This patient, after being involved in a road traffic accident, is presenting with loss of the left wrist, fingers, and thumb extension. This patient most likely has a damaged radial nerve at the elbow or forearm level. The radial nerve innervates the extensor compartments of the arm and forearm.
  •  It supplies the proximal triceps brachii in the spiral groove so that the elbow extension is intact. So this location is less likely involved.
  • It provides sensory innervation to a large part of the back of the arm and forearm as well as the thumb, index finger, and middle dorsal finger up to the level of the nails.

Option A: Axillary nerve

  • The axillary nerve supplies the deltoid muscle. Axillary Nerve Palsy causes loss of initial abduction of the shoulder (loss of first 15 degrees of abduction).

Option B: Median nerve

  •  The median nerve innervates the forearm flexors and thenar muscles and supplies sensory nerve innervation to the lateral palmar hand.

Option D: Ulnar nerve

  • The ulnar nerve supplies only the flexor carpi ulnaris and the medial half of the flexor digitorum deep in the forearm.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions would be a result of radial artery stenosis?

choices.text: A marked decrease in the blood flow in the superficial palmar arterial arch
Decreased pulsation in the artery passing superficial to the flexor retinaculum
Ischemia of the entire extensor muscles of the forearm
A marked decrease in the blood flow in the princeps pollicis artery

questions.solution:
Option D: A marked decrease in the blood flow in the princeps pollicis artery

  • This patient presenting with claudication pain of the thumb and a positive Allen test is most likely diagnosed with radial artery occlusion.
  • Allen's test is performed to determine if Collateral circulation is intact from the ulnar artery if the radial artery is occluded.
  • The appropriate method to perform this test includes the radial and ulnar arteries.
  • At the same time then, the patient is asked to clench his fist. After clenching, the pallor is produced.
  • Then the radial artery remains clouded, but the ulnar artery pressure is released.
  • After unclenching the hand, the color disappears, and the hand's color returns to the baseline due to an intact ulnar artery and connecting arches.
  • The Radial artery divides into the Princeps pollicis and deep palmar arterial arch.
  • Thus, stenosis of the radial artery results in decreased blood flow in the princeps pollicis artery.

Option A: A marked decrease in the blood flow in the superficial palmar arterial arch

  • The ulnar artery is one of the big blood vessels in the upper extremity.
  • The Superficial palmar arterial arch is formed primarily by the ulnar artery.
  • The radial artery mainly forms the deep palmar arch.

Option B: Decreased pulsation in the artery passing superficial to the flexor retinaculum

  • The ulnar artery passes superficially to the flexor retinaculum.

Option C: Ischemia of the entire extensor muscles of the forearm

  • The extensor compartment of the forearm receives blood from the posterior interosseous artery, which arises from the common interosseous branch of the ulnar artery.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male, an alcoholic, was diagnosed with cholelithiasis. The surgeon explained to the patient about the risk of developing acute pancreatitis due to gallstones. Embryologically, the pancreas develops from two pancreatic buds, namely the ventral and dorsal buds. Which of the following part of the pancreas arise from the dorsal pancreatic bud?

choices.text: Lower part of the head of the pancreas

questions.solution:
Option C: Body of the pancreas

  • Dorsal pancreatic bud gives rise to:

    • The upper part of the head of the pancreas

    • Neck

    • Body

    • Tail

    • Accessory pancreatic duct

Option A: Lower part of the head of the pancreas

  • The ventral pancreatic bud gives rise to the lower part of the head of the pancreas.

Option B: Uncinate process

  • The ventral pancreatic bud gives rise to uncinate process of the pancreas.

Option D: Main pancreatic duct

  • The ventral pancreatic bud gives rise to the main pancreatic bud of the pancreas.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the emergency department by her mother with complaints of accidental ingestion of a coin. The patient is also complaining of pain and pressure on his neck. The patient was posted for endoscopy, and endoscopic removal of the coin was done. The foreign body may get lodged in which of the following part of the structure involved in the patient's pathology?

choices.text: Where it crosses the aortic arch
Where it is crossed by left bronchus

questions.solution:
Option A: At the level of cricopharyngeal

  • The foreign body was lodged in the esophagus.
  • There are physiological constrictions in the esophagus at 4 levels, the foreign body most commonly lodges at the first constriction.
  • Constrictions of the esophagus have the following measurement:
  • At 15 cm (6 inches) from the incisor at the cricopharyngeal junction behind the cricoid cartilage at the 6th cervical vertebra.
  • At 25 cm, Broncho-aortic constriction (23+28≅50/2≅25cm)
  • At 40 cm(15 inches) from the incisor- Esophageal hiatus where it passes through the diaphragm in the posterior mediastinum at the 10th thoracic vertebrae.
  • At 23 cm(9 inches) from the incisor- Due to crossing of the arch of the aorta in front of the superior mediastinum at 4th thoracic vertebrae.
  • At 28 cm (11 inches) from the incisor- The esophagus is compressed by the left main bronchus in the posterior mediastinum at the 6th thoracic vertebrae.

Option B: Where it crosses the aortic arch

  • The foreign body usually lodges in the cricopharyngeal junction.

Option C: Where it is crossed by left bronchus

  •  The foreign body usually lodges in the cricopharyngeal junction.

Option D: Where it pierces the diaphragm

  • The foreign body usually lodges in the cricopharyngeal junction.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the membrane potential of a neuronal cell membrane. He discovers that the cell membrane is freely permeable to three ions, X, Y, and Z. At resting membrane potential, the respective equilibrium potentials of X and Y are – 30 mV and – 40 mV. He infuses a drug that blocks the permeability of Z. What will happen to the membrane potential if a drug is infused that can block the permeability of Z?
questions.solution:
Option A: Depolarisation

  • Resting membrane potential in neurons is -70mV.
  • If X, Y, and Z are freely permeable, this -70mV potential will be achieved at the resting phase of the action potential.
  • When the Z ion channel is blocked, the resting potential will be constituted by the equilibrium potential of the remaining X and Y ions.
  • Assuming both the ions X and Y have equal permeability, the cell's resting membrane potential will move from –70 mV to equilibrium potential between –30 mV & –40 mV at equilibrium.
  • It means that the potential becomes more positive, indicating depolarisation.
  • Depolarisation is a process that causes a rapid change in membrane potential from a negative to a more positive state.

Option B: Hyperpolarisation

  • Hyperpolarisation is a shift in the membrane potential of a cell that causes it to become more negative. It is the inverse of depolarisation. It suppresses action potentials by increasing the stimulus needed to bring the membrane potential to the action potential threshold.
  • In this scenario, the resting membrane potential of the cell shifts from -70 mV to an equilibrium value between -30 mV and -40 mV. It signifies that the potential gets more positive; hence Hyperpolarization cannot occur.

Option C: No change

  • Assuming both the ions X & Y have equal permeability, the cell's resting membrane potential moves from –70 mV to equilibrium potential between –30 mV & –40 mV at equilibrium.
  • It means that the potential becomes more positive, indicating depolarisation.

Option D: Hyperpolarisation following repolarisation

  • In this case, the cell's resting membrane potential moves from –70 mV to equilibrium potential between –30 mV & –40 mV. It means that the potential becomes more positive, so it cannot be repolarisation or hyperpolarisation.

questions.text: Which of the following can cause an increase in cardiac output?
questions.solution:
Option A: Decrease intrathoracic pressure

  • Intrathoracic pressure influences venous return and consequently cardiac output and arterial pressure.
  • A drop in intrathoracic pressure dilates the thoracic vena cava, resulting in increased venous return and atrial filling. This increases cardiac output.

 

  • The opposite mechanism decreases heart rate in case of increased intrathoracic pressure as during Valsalva.
  • Factors maintaining the CO:
    • Heart rate (chronotropic effect)
    • Stroke volume
    • Venous return or EDV or preload
  • Force of contraction (inotropic effect) determines ESV.
  • Afterload is determined by total peripheral resistance (TPR).
  • Changes in intra-thoracic pressure during respiration :

  • Factors affecting cardiac output are explained below:

 

 

Option B: Decreased blood volume

  • A decreased mean systemic filling pressure →decreased venous return.

Option C: Decreased ventricular compliance

  • This will decrease the ability of the ventricle to accumulate blood during diastole → decrease EDV.

Option D: Decreased mean systemic filling

  • Decreased filling results in decreased EDV and hence reduced cardiac output.

questions.text: Airway resistance is not constant. Airway resistance is markedly affected by changes in the diameter of the airways. Therefore, diseases affecting the respiratory tract can increase airway resistance. Which of the following factors increases the resistance of the airways?

choices.text: Increased sympathetic stimulation of airway smooth muscle

questions.solution:
Option D: Inhaling cigarette smoke

Airway resistance:

  • The ratio of the pressure change (P) from the alveoli to the mouth to the flow rate change is known as airway resistance.
  • Applying mathematical calculations to the movement of the bronchial tree is challenging due to the anatomy of the bronchial tree and the air channel that contributes to its resistance.
  • Lung volume reduction causes a considerable increase in airway resistance.
  • The resistance of the airways is also strongly influenced by the bronchi and bronchioles.
  • The smooth muscle lining the bronchial airways will contract, increasing airway resistance and making breathing more difficult.
  • Inhaling cigarette smoke causes reflex constriction of the smooth muscles of the airways due to the stimulation of stimulus receptors in the airway wall.

Option A: Increasing lung volume above FRC

  • Increased lung volume above the FRC will decrease airway resistance.

Option B: Increased sympathetic stimulation of airway smooth muscle

  • By dilating the bronchioles, sympathetic stimulation leads to a reduction in airway resistance.

Option C: Going to high altitude

  • Going to great heights, the density of the air is reduced.
  • The density also decreases when nitrogen in the inhaled gas is replaced by helium.

questions.text: An experiment is being conducted on drug 'X' based on the phenomenon that when a drug is not actively secreted, and the reabsorption is negligible, the renal CL of a drug is often related to the renal glomerular filtration rate. Drugs are usually filtered through the glomerulus in a nonselective process if they are in a free, nonprotein-bound form. Which of the following is true for a substance "X," which has more renal clearance than the GFR?

choices.text: “X” is only being reabsorbed by the tubules
“X” is being secreted by the tubules
“X” is being secreted as well as reabsorbed by the tubules

questions.solution:
Option B: “X” is being secreted by the tubules

  • For the given substance “X”:
    • [(Ux × V)/Px] > GFR
    • (That is, clearance of “X” is greater than GFR).
  • It means urinary excretion of the substance (Ux × V) is greater than the total filtration of the substance (Px × GFR).
  • Hence, the substance must have been secreted by the tubules. Hence, Option B is correct.
  • If [Px × GFR] is greater than [Ux × V], it means the amount of total filtered substance is greater than its urinary excretion. In that case, the substance is reabsorbed from the tubules.

Option A: “X” is only being reabsorbed by the tubules

  • If a substance is only being reabsorbed, its clearance would be less than GFR.

Option C: “X” is being secreted as well as reabsorbed by the tubules

  • If a substance is being reabsorbed and secreted (for instance, K+), and if the amount of its secretion is greater than its reabsorption, there would be net secretion of the substance. And its renal clearance would be greater than GFR. Hence, this option could have qualified as a correct statement. However, the amounts of its reabsorption and secretion are not mentioned in the option. 

Option D: “X” is neither secreted nor reabsorbed

  • If a substance has more renal clearance than GFR, it is being secreted.
  • If it is neither secreted nor reabsorbed, its clearance would be equal to GFR.

questions.text: What is the underlying pathophysiological process responsible for short stature, obesity, craniofacial abnormalities, low blood sugar, and low serum IGF-1 levels despite elevated basal serum growth hormone levels?
questions.solution:
Option B: Growth hormone receptor (GHR) insensitivity

Laron Syndrome:

  • Plasma GH is normal or elevated.
  • GH receptors are unresponsive due to loss-of-function mutations of the gene for the receptors.
  • Results in growth hormone insensitivity.
  • Plasma IGF-I is markedly reduced, along with IGFBP-3 (IGF-binding protein-3).

 

Treatment: With the availability of recombinant IGF-1, effective treatment of these children may restore linear growth.

Option A: Growth hormone deficiency

  • Growth hormone deficiency (GHD), also known as dwarfism or pituitary dwarfism, is a condition caused by insufficient amounts of growth hormone in the body.
  • Laron syndrome is differentiated from pituitary dwarfism by elevated basal serum GH due to GHR insensitivity. Serum IGF-1 is low in both conditions.
  • GHD is treated by regular injections of synthetic human growth hormone before growth plates of bones are joined together. Laron syndrome is treated by recombinant human IGF-1 administration.

Option C: Elevated levels of plasma IGF-BP3

  • Plasma IGF-BP3 is markedly reduced along with plasma IGF-1 in Laron syndrome

Option D: Normal levels of plasma IGF-BP3b

  • Plasma IGF-BP3 is markedly reduced along with plasma IGF-1 in Laron syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following regions is devoid of myelin sheath in a normal peripheral nerve?
questions.solution:
Option A: Pre-axon

  • In the clinical scenario above, the boy presented with Guillain-Barre syndrome symptoms. It is a serious post-infectious immune-mediated neuropathy that has many variant forms resulting from the autoimmune destruction of Schwann cells in the myelin sheath of nerves in the peripheral nervous system.
  • Risk factors include recent infection with Campylobacter jejuni (most common), Mycoplasma pneumoniae, HIV, Ebstein-Barr virus, and Zika virus.
  • A previous infection can trigger an immune response that cross-reacts with parts of the peripheral nerve via molecule mimicry and damages the Schwann cells.
  • The classic presentation is symmetric ascending muscle weakness and absent tendon reflexes. Other findings include autonomic dysfunction, peripheral nerve palsies (cranial nerve 3-12), and Miller Fisher variant (ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and areflexia).
  • The nerve is composed of four parts: dendrites (receive information), cell body (receive and integrate information), axon (conducts information from cell body to axon terminal), and axon terminals (a presynaptic component of a synapse).
  • The axon of a neuron is myelinated and mainly responsible for the conduction of electrical signals in the form of an action potential.
  • Myelination is the formation of myelin sheath produced by oligodendrocytes that myelinate axons in CNS and Schwann cells that myelinate axons in PNS.
  • Myelin is made of proteins and lipids that form many concentric layers of plasma membrane around an axon to form a myelin sheath. Its main function is to increase the velocity of signals.
  • In PNS, each Schwann cell will myelinate only one axon by wrapping around it multiple times.
  • Nodes of Ranvier are gaps between Schwann cells and the myelin sheath allowing electrical impulses to jump from one node to another. This form of conduction is saltatory conduction. These nodes are unmyelinated regions of an axon.
  • Other regions where myelin is absent are pre-axons (proximal part of the axon), axon terminal, and the clefts of Schmidt-Lantermann (small pockets of cytoplasm left behind during the Schwann cell myelination process).
  • The main function of myelin is to separate the axon from the extracellular components, apart from increasing the velocity of a nerve impulse.

Option B: Axons of CNS

  • The axons of CNS are covered by a myelin sheath formed by the oligodendrocytes. A single oligodendrocyte can myelinate multiple axons.
  • It is the conductive segment of a neuron and, therefore, myelinated to ensure rapid and efficient propagation of an action potential.

Option C: Optic Nerve

  • It consists of the myelinated axons of retinal ganglion cells. Hence it is an incorrect option.

Option D: Motor roots

  • The motor root is the ventral part of a spinal cord and is composed of axons from alpha, gamma, and preganglionic autonomic motor neurons. All three of them are myelinated. Hence, it is an incorrect option.

questions.text: Which structure is least likely to be painfully stimulated by touching or pulling?

choices.text: The dura overlying the postcentral gyrus
Branches of the middle meningeal artery that lie superficial to the dura over the postcentral gyrus
Branches of the middle cerebral artery that supply the postcentral gyrus

questions.solution:
Option A: The postcentral gyrus

  • Since brain tissue lacks pain receptors, touching or pulling on the postcentral gyrus is least likely to induce a painful reaction.
  • The skin's and other tissue's pain receptors are all free nerve endings.
  • They often occur in the epidermis and some interior tissues, including the periosteum, artery walls, joint surfaces, the falx, and tentorium in the cranial vault.

Option B: The dura overlying the postcentral gyrus

  • There are free nerve endings in the dura mater overlying the postcentral gyrus.
  • Stimulation of this area would cause pain, for example, in meningitis.

Option C: Branches of the middle meningeal artery that lie superficial to the dura over the postcentral gyrus

  • Free nerve endings are also present in the middle meningeal artery branches that lie superficial to the dura over the postcentral gyrus.
  • Therefore, stimulation of this area would cause pain seen in migraine.

Option D: Branches of the middle cerebral artery that supply the postcentral gyrus

  • Free nerve endings are also present in the middle cerebral artery branches that supply the postcentral gyrus.
  • Stimulation of these nerve endings would cause pain in orofacial neuralgia.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct pairing of its nuclei and respective function?

choices.text: Satiety center: lateral nucleus of the hypothalamus
Reward center: Ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus
Circadian rhythm: preoptic nuclei of the hypothalamus
Oxytocin secretion: paraventricular nuclei of the hypothalamus

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option D: Oxytocin secretion: paraventricular nuclei of the hypothalamus

  • Hypothalamus is the control center for the body, which maintains homeostasis in the body through its hormone secretions.
  • It is composed of three zones. One of its zones is the periventricular zone, and the other is lateral and medial.
  • These zones control and regulate specific functions.
  • Medial and lateral zones of the hypothalamus are concerned with autonomic and somatic functions.
  • The periventricular zone is concerned with the regulation of the endocrine system.
  • Hypothalamus is composed of multiple nuclei, which are responsible for multiple functions in the body.
  • The paraventricular and supraoptic nuclei serve the function of oxytocin secretion and ADH secretion.
  • The preoptic, anterior, and posterior nuclei serve the temperature regulation function.
  • The suprachiasmatic nucleus regulates the release of hormones, circadian rhythm, and behavior.
  • The ventromedial nucleus serves as the satiety center of the body.
  • Similarly, the dorsomedial nucleus regulates rage, and the medial forebrain bundle serves as the body's reward center.

Option A: Satiety center: lateral nucleus of the hypothalamus

The pair does not represent the correct pairing of the nucleus and respective function.

  • The ventromedial nucleus serves as the satiety center.
  • The lateral nucleus of the hypothalamus does not serve as the satiety center.

Option B: Reward center: Ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus

The pair does not represent the correct pairing of the nucleus and respective function.

  • The media forebrain bundle serves as the reward center.
  • The ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus does not serve as the reward center.

Option C: Circadian rhythm: preoptic nuclei of the hypothalamus

The pair does not represent the correct pairing of the nucleus and respective function.

  • The suprachiasmatic nucleus is involved in regulating circadian rhythm.
  • The preoptic nucleus of the hypothalamus is not involved in the regulation of circadian rhythm.

questions.text: Which specific nucleus, located slightly anterior and lateral to the cerebral aqueduct, is involved in the constriction of the pupil, the light reflex, and the accommodation reflex?
questions.solution:
Option B: Edinger – Westphal nucleus

  • The pupillary light reflex is an autonomic reflex.
  • When light is shown into the retina, it leads to constriction of the pupil. Constriction of the pupil limits the amount of light reaching the retina.
  • There are two types of light reflex one is a direct light reflex, and one is a consensual light reflex.
  • Pupillary light reflex: Visual pathway - the pretectal nucleus - Edinger Westphal nucleus - constriction of the pupil.
  • Light in the pupil leads to the transfer of signals from the eye to the brain via the optic nerve. Signals travel via the lateral geniculate body to the pretectal nucleus. From the pretectal nucleus, signals travel to Edinger – Westphal nucleus.
  • From Edinger – Westphal nucleus signals travel to ciliary ganglion via cranial nerve III. Pupillary constriction occurs via constriction of the iris.

 

  • The Pretectal nucleus is connected to the Edinger Westphal nucleus bilaterally, causing the contralateral pupil also to constrict (indirect light reflex).
  • Edinger – Westphal nucleus is also involved in the accommodation reflex. It is a nucleus differentiated from the midbrain and immediately lies dorsal to the oculomotor complex. It lies slightly anterior and lateral to the cerebral aqueduct at the level of the superior colliculus.
  • The accommodation reflex brings near objects into focus. It is mediated via lens thickening, pupillary constriction, and convergence.
  • Accommodation reflex: Visual pathway transmits signals to the visual cortex (blurred image of a near object)
  • From the visual cortex, signals are transmitted to the Edinger Westphal nucleus, and it results in changes in accommodation.

 

 

Option A: Pretectal nucleus.

  • The pretectal nucleus is located at the junction of the forebrain and midbrain. However, it is classified as a midbrain structure.
  • It is involved in modulating motor response to visual input.
  • It is involved in the pupillary light reflex.

 

Option C: Suprachiasmatic nucleus.

  • The suprachiasmatic nucleus is located in the hypothalamus.
  • It is involved in modulating circadian rhythm in the body.

 

Option D: Supraoptic nucleus.

  • The supraoptic nucleus is located in the hypothalamus.
  • It secretes ADH and oxytocin.

questions.text: Opioids are a commonly used analgesic that can exert their effects at various places in the CNS, including in the spinal cord and dorsal root ganglia. Interneurons that utilize the neurotransmitter enkephalin to inhibit afferent pain signals are most likely to be found in which region of the central nervous system?
questions.solution:
Dorsal horn of spinal cord

  • Interneurons in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord use enkephalin which inhibits pain transmission from tissues of the body.

Postcentral gyrus

  • The somatosensory cortex is located in the postcentral gyrus and does not use enkephalin to inhibit pain transmission.

Precentral gyrus

  • The primary motor cortex is located in the precentral gyrus and does not use enkephalin to inhibit pain transmission.

δ-type A

  • Myelinated δ- type A fibers and unmyelinated type C fibers are not interneurons.

Learning Objective

Enkephalins

  • Enkephalins are the natural opiate peptides recognized first in a pig’s brain. Derived from the precursor proenkephalin, these peptides are present in the nerve endings in many parts of the forebrain, substantia gelatinosa of the brainstem, spinal cord, and GI tract. Two types of enkephalins are known, leucine enkephalin (YGGFL) and methionine enkephalin (YGGFM).
  • Interneurons in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord use enkephalin which inhibits pain transmission from tissues of the body.
  • Interneurons are physically short neurons that form a connection between other neurons that are usually close together.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man suddenly collapsed while standing, waiting for a bus. The rescue team arrives and finds that his BP is 90/60 mm Hg. After initial resuscitation by maintaining an IV line and fluid resuscitation, he is brought to the hospital to get investigated and managed on the line of shock. Low-pressure baroreceptors are involved in the regulation of blood volume. Which of the following is related to these receptors?

choices.text: They do not provide efferent for thirst control
They are located in the carotid sinus
They do not affect vasopressin release

questions.solution:
• Carotid sinus receptors are pressure receptors, not volume receptors (option-3); they respond to stretch stimulus.
  • Volume receptors are present in the right atrium, right ventricle, and pulmonary artery.

questions.text: In which part of the digestive tract are Brunner's glands predominately located?
questions.solution:
Option B: Upper duodenum

  • The small intestine absorbs about 90% of the food. It has three segments:
  • The duodenum
  • Jejunum
  • lLeum
  • The duodenum receives chyme from the stomach as well as digestive materials from the pancreas.
  • Brunner's glands are located in the submucosa of the duodenum.
  • They secrete an alkaline fluid containing mucin, which protects the mucosa from the acidic stomach contents entering the duodenum. It also neutralizes the acid.
  • Its alkaline nature of secretion also stimulates intestinal enzymes to assist with food absorption and breakdown.
  • The upper duodenum also secretes the gastrin hormone, which is produced by G-cells. These cells are also found in the stomach.
  • Brunner glands are composed of tubules lined by cells resembling the mucus-secreting cells of the gastric antral mucosa.
  • Brunner's gland adenoma, called hamartoma, is a duodenal benign tumor found in less than 5% of benign duodenal tumors.

Option A: Jejunum

  • The duodenum can be distinguished from the Jejunum and ileum by the presence of Brunner's glands in the submucosa.

Option C: Lower duodenum

  • Brunner's glands(or duodenal glands) are compound tubular submucosal glands found in that portion of the duodenum, which is above the hepatopancreatic sphincter (i.e., sphincter of Oddi).

Option D: Appendix

  • Appendix does not have any function in human beings. But, it can create major problems when diseased.

questions.text: Which of the following TCA cycle enzymes is most likely to be affected by riboflavin deficiency?
questions.solution:
Option A: Succinate dehydrogenase

  • The patient has a deficiency in riboflavin (urinary excretion of fewer than 30 μg/mg creatinine is considered clinically deficient).
  • Riboflavin is a component of the flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD) cofactor, which is required to convert succinate to fumarate by succinate dehydrogenase.
  • Deficiency leads to less activity of succinate dehydrogenase.
  • Other enzymes that require FAD are:
    1. Xanthine oxidase
    2. Succinyl CoA dehydrogenase
    3. G-3-P dehydrogenase

Option B and C: MDH and IDH

  • Both are dehydrogenase and requires NAD as coenzyme.
  • NAD requires vitamin B3 (Niacin)for its synthesis. So, deficiency of Vitamin B3 will affect their activity

Option D: Citrate synthase

  • One of the RLE of TCA but does not require any coenzyme
  • Activity is affected by NADH, succinyl-CoA, citrate, ATP and ADP allosterically

questions.text: A 20-year-old boy suffering from congenital deficiency of muscle phosphorylase is getting examined by an ischemic forearm exercise test by squeezing a rubber ball. This patient would exhibit which one of the following as compared to a normal person performing the same test?

choices.text: Increased blood glucose in the blood drawn from the exercising forearm vein
Increased lactate in the blood drawn from the exercising forearm vein
Relatively decreased blood lactate in the blood drawn from the exercising forearm vein

questions.solution:
Option D: Relatively decreased blood lactate in the blood drawn from the exercising forearm vein

  • Normal or low blood lactate and increased blood ammonia after an ischemic exercise test suggest a defect in the conversion of glycogen (glucose) to lactate.
  • This is observed in the case of McArdle's disease, which occurs due to a deficiency of muscle glycogen phosphorylase enzyme such that glycogen cannot be converted to glucose and further to lactate in exercising muscle.
  • Hence, relatively low levels of lactate will be formed from muscle glycogen after exercise compared to a normal individual.
  • Another thing that happens is that due to a lack of energy and ATP, muscle cells get damaged. Hence myoglobin will be released in urine, causing myoglobinuria.
  • Definitive diagnosis of this disease can be done by:
    • Enzymatic assay in muscle tissue
    • Mutation analysis of the myophosphorylase gene
  • Abnormal exercise response also occurs with
    • Deficiencies of muscle phosphofructokinase
    • Deficiencies of the debranching enzyme (when the test is done after fasting).

Option A: Exercise endurance

  • Any type of glycogen storage disease in muscles causes exercise intolerance and muscle cramps due to a lack of stored muscle glycogen utilization.
  • So, in McArdle’s disease also, there is no chance of developing exercise endurance.

Option B: Increased  blood glucose in the blood drawn from the exercising forearm vein

  • Muscle cells can take glucose from the blood during exercise, but muscle glycogen cannot contribute to blood glucose due to a lack of a glucose-6-phosphatase enzyme.
  • So, there can’t be any increased blood glucose in the blood vein of exercising forearm; rather, it will show decreased blood glucose

Option C: Increased lactate in the blood drawn from the exercising forearm vein

  • In glycogen phosphorylase deficiency, free glucose is not generated
  • Hence no lactate is formed due to a lack of glucose
  • Therefore, the blood level of lactate falls.

questions.text: A 3-year old male child presents with hepatomegaly and bilateral lenticular opacities. Laboratory examination revels normal blood glucose levels by GOD-POD assay but positive Benedict’s test in urine. Physician suspected it to be a case of galactosemia. Deficiency of which one of the following enzymes will cause such features.
questions.solution:
Option B: Galactose 1-phosphate uridyltransferase

  • Galactose is produced in intestine from degradation of milk sugar lactose by enzyme lactase.
  • The patient symptoms suggest it to be a case of classic galactosemia which is due to deficiency of enzyme Galactose 1-phosphate uridyltransferase of galactose metabolism.
  • Excess Gal accumulation occurs in this disease in liver causing jaundice, vomiting, hepatomegaly and in brain causing mental retardation

  • Other clinical features include a high risk of E. coli sepsis (reason unknown) and Oil drop cataract due to inhibition of galactokinase by product inhibition, as shown in the figure in text.

Option A and D: Glucokinase and aldolase A

  • Glucokinase and aldolase A are enzymes of glycolysis and defects in these enzymes generally manifest as hemolysis and anemia.

Option C: Aldose reductase

  • Aldose reductase converts galactose to galactitol which accumulates in eye causing oil drop>As there is cataract formation seen in this patient, so this enzyme is not deficient.

questions.text: A newborn is tested for phenylketonuria (PKU) using a blood sample taken from the umbilical cord. Based on the blood report, the newborn is declared negative for PKU, and the pediatrician imposes no dietary restrictions. The child is again brought to the pediatrician after 12 months. This time, the child is reported to have aggressive behavior and delayed milestones. Blood and urine tests for PKU are redone, and they are positive this time. Finally, a diagnosis of PKU is made. What is the most probable reason for misdiagnosis at birth in this case?

choices.text: Cord blood is not a good source of fetal blood
The Guthrie test used in diagnosis has low sensitivity
Maternal blood should have been used
The test was performed too early to be positive

questions.solution:
Option D: The test was performed too early to be positive

  • Phenylketonuria (PKU) is caused by an inborn error in phenylalanine hydroxylase enzyme or the co-factor, tetrahydrobiopterin or dihydropyridine reductase.
  • It results in elevated phenylalanine levels and metabolites in the blood and urine.
  • In newborns, maternal enzymes clear phenylalanine and its metabolites for the first 24-48 hours.
  • Thus, any screening test performed during this period may give false negative results.
  • In these circumstances, the neonatal screening test is performed after 24-48 hours when the infant has started taking a protein diet.
  • Furthermore, mass spectrometry is a relatively more credible way to diagnose PKU than the Guthrie test.

Option A: Cord blood is not a good source of fetal blood

  • Cord blood may contain more or less the same constituents as maternal blood. Nevertheless, the main reason for a false negative result is the wrong timing for drawing blood and not the wrong site.
  • Safe practice is to draw blood from the infant's heel on the 3rd day after birth.

Option B: Guthrie test used in diagnosis has low sensitivity

  • For the Guthrie test, a sample from the infant’s heel is taken after three days of birth and then used for diagnosis. So, it can not be false negative due to low levels of phenylalanine.

Option C: Maternal blood should have been used

  • Maternal blood is usually not used to diagnose PKU as she has normally functioning enzymes and normal levels of phenylalanine.
  • However, maternal blood can diagnose 'maternal PKU Syndrome.'
  • If women with PKU who are not on a low-phenylalanine diet become pregnant, the offspring are affected with "maternal PKU syndrome."
  • As phenylalanine is a teratogen, higher levels of phenylalanine in the mother cause microcephaly, mental retardation, and congenital heart anomalies in the fetus.

questions.text: A newborn presents with severe respiratory distress and has not gained proper weight during the past several weeks. Examination revealed muscle hypotonia and neurological problems and an extremely low level of acetyl CoA carboxylase in liver. The most likely reason for an infant's respiratory problems is:
questions.solution:
• Acetyl CoA carboxylase forms malonyl CoA, in the first step of fatty acid synthesis. The deficiency of this enzyme severely affects the fatty acid synthesis in the patient. In utero, the fetus utilized fatty acids provided from mother. Growth retardation, muscle and neurological problems later occurred due to demand of fatty acid requiring processes
  • In particular, the lungs require surfactant to function properly. Surfactants are lipoproteinaceous substances synthesized in alveolar cells, and are required for gas exchange as they lower alveolar surface tension. It contains significant amounts of dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine, the most common surfactant which requires palmitate formed mainly by de novo fatty acid synthesis.
  • None of the other answers listed would result in all of the symptoms given.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl is brought to the emergency by her parents with complaints because lethargy, vomiting, and abdominal pain for 6 hours. History revealed severe polyuria, polydipsia, and polyphagia. One of the test tubes with a positive test for the urinary examination is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely source of compound showing a positive reaction in this patient:
questions.solution:
The test shown in figure is Rothera’s test in which a purple ring is formed at the top, if ketone bodies are positive.

  • Fatty acid breakdown provides Acetyl CoA that serves as a precursor for ketone bodies.

Severe polyuria and polydipsia in question is indicating that patient is diabetic

  • In Diabetes Mellitus,
    • Glucose utilization is impaired due to absolute or relative insulin deficiency.
    • Fatty acid breakdown occurs to provide energy
    • Resultant excessive Acetyl CoA enters the pathway of ketogenesis.

questions.text: Dideoxynucleotides are used for Sanger DNA sequencing technique. Whenever this nucleotide is added in to growing DNA chain, the chain elongation stops causing termination of DNA synthesis. This form the basis of this sequencing technique. Based on that knowledge we can deduce that a dideoxynucleotide does not contain:
questions.solution:
Dideoxy nucleotide

  • Lacks 3’ OH group also.
  • Stop the chain elongation when they are incorporated.
  • DNA polymerase requires 3’ OH group to begin polymerisation.
  • Use:
    • Sanger chain termination method of DNA sequencing.
    • Didanosine (dideoxyinosine) is a dideoxynucleotide used in the therapy of HIV.

questions.text: What is the wavelength at which nucleic acids show maximum absorption of UV light?
questions.solution:
Nucleic acids absorb UV light maximally at the wavelength of 260 nm

  • 260/280 ratio of pure DNA/RNA is in the range of 1.8 to 2.
  • Amino acids absorb U.V light (not visible light) → colorless.
  • Aromatic amino acids absorb U.V light at 250-290 nm (maximum absorption is at 280nm) because of conjugated double bonds.

questions.text: A family member in a TB-positive patient's house is exposed and found to give a positive tuberculin test (PPD) with a normal chest X-ray. He is placed on preventive 6-month isoniazid therapy and develops peripheral neuropathies. Which of the following vitamins can be prescribed for the treatment of neuropathies?
questions.solution:
Option B: Pyridoxine

  • Isoniazid inhibits pyridoxal phosphokinase.
  • The biologically active form of pyridoxine is pyridoxal phosphate. Thus, Isoniazid inhibits the formation of the active form of B6.
  • Vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) supplementation during isoniazid (INH) therapy is necessary for some patients to prevent the development of peripheral neuropathy.
  • As Vitamin B6 (PLP) is required for Niacin synthesis from tryptophan, Isoniazid therapy also causes Niacin deficiency.

 Option A: Riboflavin

  •  Neither Isoniazid causes vitamin B2 deficiency nor vitamin B2 deficiency cause peripheral neuropathy.

Clinical features of vitamin B2 deficiency:

  • Corneal vascularization
  • Cheilitis, glossitis, stomatitis, pharyngitis
  • Normocytic normochromic anemia
  • Seborrheic dermatitis

Option C: Vitamin A

  • Neither isoniazid cause vitamin A deficiency nor vitamin A deficiency cause peripheral neuropathy.

Clinical features of vitamin A deficiency:

  • Ocular manifestations
  • Night blindness (nyctalopia)
  • Retinopathy
  • Xerophthalmia
  • Keratomalacia
  • Bitot spots

Option D: Folate

  •  Neither Isoniazid cause folate deficiency nor does folate deficiency causes peripheral neuropathy.

Symptoms of deficiency are:

  • Signs of anemia (e.g., fatigue, pallor)
  • Maternal deficiency: fetal spina bifida/anencephaly
  • Glossitis

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with mild liver disease, arthritis, fatigue, and grayish skin pigmentation. A highly elevated level of iron is observed in his liver biopsy report. Which of the following conditions will be most likely found in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: High Serum Ferritin

  • This patient with mild liver disease, arthritis, fatigue, grayish skin pigmentation, and a highly elevated iron level on liver biopsy likely has hemochromatosis.
  • It is an autosomal recessive disorder due to mutation in the histocompatibility region of chromosome 6.
  • Iron absorption is increased from the small intestine resulting in increased serum iron and iron-ferritin complex.

Option A: Low serum Iron

  • A high serum iron will be expected in a patient with hemochromatosis.

Option B: High Serum Copper

  • It is a characteristic finding of Wilson's disease and has no association with hemochromatosis.
  • Wilson's disease presents with Keyser Fleischer ring, neurological symptoms, and liver-related disorders.

Option C: Low saturation of transferrin

  • Hemochromatosis is characterized by high serum iron; as transferrin carries iron in the blood, higher transferrin saturation will also be observed.

questions.text: A 69-year-old male known case of DM and HTN for five years presented with fever, fatigue, and weakness for one month. His past medical history was unremarkable. On physical examination, the patient had anaemia and massive splenomegaly. His lab investigations showed pancytopenia. His peripheral blood studies, including flow cytometry and peripheral smear examination, suggested the diagnosis of Hairy Cell Leukemia (HCL) confirmed by bone marrow biopsy and immunohistochemistry (IHC). Which of the following statements is supportive of the diagnosis?

choices.text: The tumour cells express CD11c and CD103
The HCL cell is clover shaped

questions.solution:
Option B: The tumour cells express CD11c and CD103

  • Old age, fever, fatigue, pancytopenia, and splenomegaly with peripheral blood studies suggest hairy cell leukaemia (HCL), an uncommon indolent B-cell neoplasm characterized by leukaemic cells with fine, hairlike cytoplasmic projections. HCL characteristically express CD11c and CD103.
  • The tumour cells in HCL express pan-B cell markers (CD19, CD20), surface immunoglobulin, and CD11c and CD103.
  • CD11c and CD103 are not present in most other B-cell tumours, making them diagnostically useful.
  • It occurs mainly in the older age group with significant male predominance.
  • It is usually diagnosed by peripheral blood studies, including flow cytometry, peripheral smear, and bone marrow biopsy.

Option A: Splenomegaly is rare

  • HCL results from infiltration of bone marrow and spleen.
  • Splenomegaly, often massive, is the most common manifestation.
  • Pancytopenia results from bone marrow infiltration and splenic sequestration.
  • Lymph node involvement in hairy cell leukaemia is rare.

Option C: HCL has a poor prognosis

  • HCL is extremely sensitive to chemotherapeutic agents, unlike most low-grade lymphoid neoplasms.
  • The overall prognosis is excellent in HCL.
  • Cladribine and pentostatin are the first-line treatment for hairy cell leukaemia.

Option D: The HCL cell is clover shaped

  • The HCL cell is a mononuclear cell with abundant, pale, and blue-grey ‘fluffy’ or ‘hairy’ cytoplasm.
  • The cytoplasm is abundant, pale, and blue-grey with a ‘fluffy’ or ‘hairy’ appearance.
  • The hairlike cytoplasmic projections can be seen under the electron microscope.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman is being evaluated for chronic fatigue. She has a history of heavy menstrual periods since menarche and recalls frequent nosebleeds as a child. Her past medical history is otherwise insignificant, and she takes no medications. Laboratory studies show normal prothrombin time (PT), activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT), platelet count and fibrinogen levels. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Von Willebrand disease type 1

Bleeding from mucosal sites (Nose bleed) indicates mostly platelet disorder as supported by normal PT and aPTT (No extrinsic and intrinsic pathway defect)

But platelet levels are normal, so quantitative disorder is ruled out. We will consider qualitative disorder, which is Von Willebrand disease type 1

Qualitative Platelet Disorders 

  • Berhard-Soulier: GP-Ib deficiency, adhesion problem 
  • Von Willebrand's: vWF deficiency, adhesion problem 
  • Glanzmann's thrombasthenia: GP-IIb/IIIa deficiency, aggregation problem - cannot bind vWF and Fib 
  • Storage pool disease: dense body defect, secretion problem 

 

  • The most common cause of the inherited bleeding disorder
  • One of the common causes of puberty menorrhagia
  • PT, platelet count and fibrinogen levels will be normal
  • APTT will be normal or mildly increased in type 1, types 2A, 2B, 2M
  • APTT will be significantly increased in type 2N, type 3
  • VWF antigen and activity will be reduced, leading to bleeding symptoms
  • The function of VWF - Adhesion of platelets and increased half-life of factor 8

Option A: Hypofibrinogemia

  • In hypofibrinogenemia, the patient will have a low level of fibrinogen
  • In this case, levels are normal

Option B: Factor IX deficiency

  • In Factor IX clotting factor deficiency
    • APTT value is abnormal
    • Rare in females

Option C: Immune thrombocytopenia

  • In ITP, Antibody cause the destruction of platelets
  • So platelet count will be low

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady presents with features of malabsorption and iron deficiency anaemia. She is vitally stable and afebrile. A duodenal histopathological biopsy was performed, which revealed complete villous atrophy. Which of the following antibodies is likely to be present?
questions.solution:
Option A: Anti-endomysial antibodies

  • From the given case scenario suggesting features of malabsorption, iron deficiency anaemia and complete villous atrophy, a diagnosis of celiac disease can be made.
  • Serologic studies of celiac disease include:
    • Anti-endomysial antibodies
    • Tissue transglutaminase [tTG] antibodies: most specific
    • Antigliadin antibodies
  • Complications of celiac disease include:
    • Increased risk for enteropathic-associated T- cell lymphoma
    • IDA
    • malabsorption and skin complications
  • Treatment:
    • Cereal substitution with maise and rice
    • Dapsone for dermatitis herpetiformis
    • Corticosteroids

Option B: Anti-goblet cell antibodies

  • Autoimmune enteropathy, which is most common in children, is caused by anti-enterocyte antibodies, also known as anti-goblet cell antibodies and culminates in persistent diarrhoea with small intestinal villous atrophy.

Option C: Anti-saccharomyces cerevisiae antibodies

  • Anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibodies (ASCA) are immune proteins often found in persons with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), a set of chronic illnesses caused by an autoimmune process and characterised by swollen and damaged intestinal lining tissues.

Option D: Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies

  • Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) are autoantibodies directed against antigens identified in neutrophil and monocyte cytoplasmic granules. ANCA testing is often used to diagnose or exclude Wegener's granulomatosis and microscopic polyangiitis.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presents to the OPD with complaints of joint pain, rash on face, palm and shin, and weight loss. There is radiographic evidence of bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and interstitial lung disease. A lung biopsy gives findings similar to those shown in the figure. Which of the following is a major characteristic of this disorder?

choices.text: Highest incidence in persons of Asian lineage

questions.solution:
Option C: Hypercalcemia

  • The presence of asteroid bodies in the large cell, which can be seen in the image, and the clinical presentation of the patient are both necessary components in making a diagnosis of sarcoidosis.
  • Around sixty per cent of the granulomas have laminar concretions within their giant cells. These concretions are called Schumann bodies and are made up of calcium and proteins. Stellate inclusions, also called Asteroid bodies, can also be seen within giant cells.
  • Both polyclonal hypergammaglobulinemia and hypercalcemia are common abnormal laboratory findings in this condition. Hypercalcemia is caused by increased calcium absorption as a secondary effect of the production of active vitamin D by the macrophages that form the granulomas.
  • Polyclonal hypergammaglobulinemia is caused by increased levels of polyclonal hypergammaglobulin.
  • Granulomas are often connected with high levels of calcium in the blood.
  • People of African descent have a substantially higher prevalence of the illness than people of any other origin.

Option A: A positive test for tuberculin

  • A positive test for tuberculin is indicative of tuberculosis infection.
  • It has a poor sensitivity for sarcoidosis.

Option B: Highest incidence in persons of Asian lineage

  • The highest incidence of sarcoidosis is in persons of African lineage.

Option D: Hypogammaglobulinemia

  • There are increased levels of polyclonal hyper gamma globulin in sarcoidosis.
  • Hypogammaglobulinemia is seen in patients with immunodeficiency, nephrotic syndrome, and hematologic malignancy.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman has an ovarian tumour removed. The surgical specimen is cystic and 10 cm in diameter. Black hair and sebaceous substances are discovered in the cystic cavity. A range of benign differentiated tissues, including skin, cartilage, brain, and mucinous glandular epithelium, are found on histologic inspection of the cyst wall. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Teratoma

  • Teratomas are benign tumours composed of tissues derived from all three primary germ layers: ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm.
  • Teratoma originates from totipotential germ cells that are normally present in the ovary and testis and sometimes also found in abnormal midline embryonic rests. 
  • Such cells can differentiate into any of the cell types found in the adult body and so, not surprisingly, may give rise to neoplasms that contain, in a helter-skelter fashion, bone, epithelium, muscle, fat, nerve, and other tissues. 
  • A particularly common pattern is seen in the ovarian cystic teratoma (dermoid cyst), which differentiates principally along ectodermal lines to create a cystic tumour lined by skin replete with hair, sebaceous glands, and tooth structures.

Option A: Adenoma

  • An adenoma is a benign tumour of epithelial origin.
  • An adenoma is applied to benign epithelial neoplasms derived from glands, although they may or may not form glandular structures.

Option B: Chondroma

  • Chondroma is a benign cartilaginous tumour.
  • Chondromas are benign tumours of hyaline cartilage that usually occur in bones of enchondral origin. 
  • They can arise within the medullary cavity, where they are known as enchondromas, or on the surface of the bone, where they are called juxtacortical chondromas. 
  • Enchondromas are the most common intraosseous cartilage tumours and are usually diagnosed in individuals 20 to 50 years of age. 
  • Typically, they appear as solitary metaphyseal lesions of tubular bones of the hands and feet. The radiographic features consist of circumscribed lucencies with central irregular calcifications, a sclerotic rim and an intact cortex.

Option C: Hamartoma

  • Hamartoma is disorganized normal tissue.
  • Hamartomas are disorganized but benign masses composed of cells indigenous to the involved site.
  • The term hamartoma refers to an excessive, focal over-growth of cells and tissues native to the organ in which it occurs. 
  • Although the cellular elements are mature and identical to those found in the remainder of the organ, they do not reproduce the normal architecture of the surrounding tissue. 
  • The line of demarcation between a hamartoma and a benign neoplasm is often unclear since both lesions can be clonal.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl comes to the hospital with chest pain and respiratory distress. A prominent pansystolic heart murmur and a prominent third heart sound are heard on cardiac auscultation. The patient expires despite intense supportive measures. At autopsy, microscopic findings are as shown in a given image. The mechanism of developing a given disease is which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option A: Cross-reactivity with self antigens

  • This patient is affected by acute rheumatic fever, and the image shows “Aschoff body”.
  • It results from the immune response to group A streptococci (Strep. Pyogenes) cross-react with the host tissue.
  • Antibodies directed against streptococcal M proteins cross-react with cardiac autoantigens.
    • In addition, CD4+T cells, which are specific for streptococcal peptides, also react with self-proteins in the heart and produce cytokines that activate macrophages.
    • Therefore, cardiac tissue damage combines antibody and T-cell-mediated responses.
  • In patients with acute rheumatic fever, lesions are found in various tissues.
  • These inflammatory lesions are most pronounced in the heart, called the "Aschoff body".
  • They consist of foci of eosinophilic material surrounded by T lymphocytes, occasionally plasma cells, and bulging macrophages called “Anitschkow cells".
  • These characteristic cells have abundant cytoplasm and round-to-void central nuclei in which the chromatin is arranged in a central, thin, wavy band (caterpillar cells).
  • These lesions are pathognomonic for rheumatic fever.

Option B: inflammation of the endocardium

  • Infective endocarditis is a disease which affects the inner layer of the heart, valvular endothelium, chordae tendineae and mural endocardium.
  • The following pathogens mostly cause it:
    • S. Aures (acute)
    • Viridans streptococci (sub-acute)
  • It causes the following signs/symptoms:
    • Fever
    • New murmur
    • Roth spots
    • Osler nodes
    • Splinter haemorrhages
    • Janeway lesions

Option C: Decrease organ perfusion

  • Decrease organ perfusion and delivery of nutrients cause shock in the patient.
  • These are necessary for normal tissue and cellular function.
  • It is a life-threatening condition if not treated timely.
  • It is caused by dehydration, haemorrhage (hypovolemic shock), sepsis, anaphylaxis, CNS injury (distributive shock), and cardiac embolism (obstructive shock).

Option D: Release of atrial natriuretic peptide

  • The atrial myocytes release it in response to increased blood volumes and atrial pressure.
  • It plays an important role in vasodilation and decreases Na reabsorption at the renal collecting tubule.
  • It dilates the afferent renal arteriole and constricts the efferent arterioles.
  • It promotes diuresis and contributes to the “aldosterone escape” mechanism.

questions.text: A 68-year-old Caucasian man with a history of smoking of twenty-five pack-year presented in the outpatient department with complaints of new-onset dyspnea on exertion and abdominal pain. He had a history of prolonged neonatal jaundice. On physical examination, the patient had a barrel chest, diminished lung breath sounds, and a swollen abdomen with hepatomegaly. Chest x-ray shows hyper-inflated lungs widened intercostal spaces and a low diaphragm. The abdomen ultrasound report showed a nodular liver surface. Based on the above history and clinical findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency

  • The patient presented with dyspnea on exertion and abdominal pain in this case.
  • The patient had a barrel chest and swollen abdomen.
  • Hyperinflated lungs and nodular liver.
  • These findings help in the diagnosis of Alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency.

Α1-Antitrypsin deficiency

  • Deficiency of an α1-Antitrypsin (α1-AT) enzyme is an autosomal recessive disorder marked by deficient levels of serum protease inhibitor (Pi); Its deficiency leads to emphysema and hepatic disease (cholestasis or cirrhosis).

Pathogenesis

  •  Α1-AT is synthesized primarily by hepatocytes. The gene is highly polymorphic, with more than 75 isoforms designated alphabetically based on gel migration mobilities; the most common genotype (more than 90% of people) is designated pimm.
  • Most mutations result in no or only moderate reductions in a1-AT levels and have no clinical manifestations.
  • However, pizz homozygotes (the most common disease genotype) have circulating a1-AT levels below 10% of normal.
  • Piz has a single glutamic acid to lysine substitution, resulting in protein misfolding and preventing egress from the endoplasmic reticulum.
  • This triggers the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress response, including autophagy, mitochondrial dysfunction, and pro-inflammatory nuclear factor-kb (NF-kb) activation, all causing hepatocyte damage. Additional genetic or environmental factors modify the pathogenesis since only 10% to 15% of pizz homozygotes develop overt liver disease.

Morphology

  • Α1-AT deficiency is characterized by periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)- positive (diastase-resistant) cytoplasmic globules in periportal hepatocytes.
  • Hepatic manifestations range from cholestasis to hepatitis to cirrhosis.

Clinical Features

  • Neonatal hepatitis with cholestatic jaundice occurs in 10% to 20% of newborns with an α1-AT deficiency; later presentation may be attributable to acute hepatitis or complications of cirrhosis. Hepatocellular carcinoma develops in 2% to 3% of pizz homozygous adults. Smoking accentuates emphysematous lung damage.
  • Treatment is liver transplantation
  • Autosomal recessive disorder of protein folding marked by deficient levels of circulating α1-Antitrypsin (α1at).
  • Neonatal hepatitis with cholestatic jaundice appears in 10% to 20% of newborns with the deficiency.
  • In adolescence, the presenting symptoms can be related to cirrhosis, hepatitis, or pulmonary disease that is emphysema.

Diagnosis of α1-Antitrypsin deficiency can be made by;

  • Decreased antitrypsin protein levels in serum
  • Electrophoresis: decreased alpha-1 peak
  • Chest x-ray shows widened intercostal spaces, hyperinflated lungs, low and flat diaphragm
  • Chest CT shows pan-acinar emphysema
  • Liver biopsy: PAS-positive, spherical inclusion bodies

Option B: Cystic Fibrosis

  • Autosomal recessive disorder
  • Mutation in CFTR gene
  • Meconium ileus in newborns
  • Salty sweat
  • May lead to liver cirrhosis
  • Respiratory symptoms common in adulthood
  • Chronic obstructive lung disease with bronchiectasis

Option C: Bronchiectasis

  • Irreversible abnormal dilation in the bronchial tree
  • Caused by cycles of bronchial inflammation leading to mucus plugging and progressive airway destruction
  • High-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) confirms the diagnosis

Option D: Autoimmune hepatitis

  • Chronic hepatitis with unknown aetiology
  • Diagnosis is by detecting autoantibodies, especially anti-smooth muscle antibodies
  • Without treatment, cirrhosis may develop.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presented to the emergency department with complaints of the right upper quadrant (RUQ) abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and high-grade fever. Physical examination reveals signs of jaundice. He has no history of pancreatitis or any alcohol or drug abuse. His vitals show mild tachycardia with normal blood pressure. Laboratory investigations revealed leukocytosis, normal haemoglobin, increased direct bilirubin, normal serum indirect bilirubin, and increased alkaline phosphatase. Which of the following is the appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Biliary duct obstruction

  • This is the case of common bile duct obstruction seen in patients with the signs and symptoms of RUQ abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and high-grade fever, along with jaundice.
  • The common bile duct obstruction usually presents clinically with biliary colic (severe right upper quadrant abdominal pain), jaundice, and high fever due to cholangitis. This is known as Charcot’s triad.
  • Jaundice, due to extrahepatic obstruction, will commonly result in leukocytosis and increased levels of direct bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase, but normal levels of haemoglobin and serum indirect bilirubin, as seen in the laboratory investigations.
  • Gallstones are the most common cause of bile duct obstruction, and the other is carcinoma in the head of the pancreas, which can be ruled out as the patient has no history of pancreatitis or drug or alcohol abuse.
  • Most patients with gallstones usually have cholecystitis, which is characterized by a thickened gallbladder wall preventing the gallbladder from dilating. Therefore, if the obstruction is due to a gallstone, dilation of the gallbladder will not occur, and it will not be palpable.

 

Option A: Acute cholecystitis

  • In the case of acute cholecystitis, the obstruction is usually seen at the level of the cystic duct, which results in only the clinical manifestations of gall bladder obstruction with no hepatic manifestations.
  • Signs of inflammation/infection of the gallbladder are seen in acute cholecystitis with a positive Murphy sign.
  • Acute cholecystitis is typically associated with right upper quadrant pain, fever, and leukocytosis, but it may not present with elevated alkaline phosphatase.
  • Alkaline phosphatase not specific for acute cholecystitis

 

Option B: Appendicitis

  • It is an inflammatory reaction to the appendix, which usually results in right lower quadrant pain starting from the stomach and moving to the right side, along with low-grade fever.
  • Pain at McBurney’s point, along with the signs and symptoms, establish the diagnosis.

 

Option D: Chronic cholecystitis

  • Chronic cholecystitis can occur as a result of gallstone formation, and resultant cystic duct obstruction can lead to inflammation and oedema in the gallbladder wall.
  • There is usually a general worsening of clinical symptoms and a history of similar episodes in the past, with fever and tachycardia occurring rarely.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female presents to a fertility clinic to discuss her inability to conceive despite an active effort to conceive for more than two years.
