She denies using any protective equipment or contraceptive medication. She mentions that her menstrual cycles are regular but have recently been more painful than usual. She states a history of unusual pain during intercourse for more than a year with no associated post-coital or heavy menstrual bleeding. Physical examination reveals focal tenderness on the vaginal examination, immobility of the cervix on manipulation and palpation of the left adnexal mass. A transvaginal ultrasound scan reveals a 6cm nodule on the surface of the left ovary. A diagnostic laparoscopy reveals a large nodule on her left ovary and multiple small red-blue nodules over the surface of her ovaries and uterine ligaments. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Endometriosis

  • Endometriosis is characterized by endometrial glands and stroma outside the uterine cavity. 
  • Ovaries and uterine ligaments are one of the commonest sites for endometriosis.
    • Endometrial tissue in the ovary bleeds cyclically and results in hematoma surrounded by ovarian parenchyma.
    • Endometriomas have fibrotic walls and surface adhesions filled with syrup-like chocolate-coloured material.
    • These findings are consistent with the diagnostic laparoscopy given in this scenario.
  • Usual signs and symptoms of endometriosis include
    • Pelvic pain
    • Severe dysmenorrhea (Painful menses)
    • Dyspareunia (Painful intercourse)
    • Infertility

  • Transvaginal ultrasonogram of a 6 cm (diameter) left ovarian endometrioma and its corresponding laparoscopic image.

Option A: Adenomyosis

  • Adenomyosis is the presence of the endometrial glands within the uterine cavity's myometrium, characterized by very painful menstrual periods and heavy menstrual bleeding.
    • It is not associated with painful intercourse or subfertility.

Option B: Endometrial hyperplasia

  • The proliferation of endometrial glands is termed endometrial hyperplasia and is characterized by abnormal uterine bleeding out of regular periods and less often by post-coital bleeding.

Option D: Leiomyoma

  • The presence of whorls of smooth muscles and fibroblasts in the uterine myometrium is termed leiomyoma or uterine fibroids.
    • Uterine fibroids are characterized by heavy menstrual bleeding and subfertility but are not associated with dysmenorrhea or dyspareunia.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female underwent hysterectomy for dysfunctional uterine bleeding. Following are the gross and histological findings. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Diagnosis- Leiomyoma of uterus
  • Well circumscribed growth arising in uterine wall from myometrium
  • Can be Multiple in number
  • hanges which can be seen- hyaline degeneration, calcification.
  • Common signs and symptoms include abnormal bleeding, urinary frequency due to compression of the bladder, sudden pain from infarction of a large or pedunculated tumor, and impaired fertility.
  • Mutations in the gene MED12 occur in roughly 70% of uterine leiomyomas.

♦ Microscopic Examination:

  • Well differentiated spindle shaped smooth muscle cells in a whorl pattern.
  • Individual muscle cells are uniform in size and shape and have a characteristic oval nucleus and long, slender bipolar cytoplasmic processes.
  • Mitotic figures are scarce.

questions.text: A 56-year-old female comes to the outdoor patient department with presenting complaints of fever, myalgia and arthralgia for 6 days. The patient has no history of concomitant respiratory or gastrointestinal symptoms. Her physical examination is normal, and she has been treated for viral fever. However, her complete blood count reveals that she has pancytopenia (total white cell count of 2.9 × 109/L, neutrophil count of 1.1 × 109/L, Hb of 10.6 g/ dL, and Plt of 110 × 109/L) despite her recovery from viral fever. Subsequently, investigations are done to identify pancytopenia. Bone marrow aspiration and trephine biopsy (BMAT) show normal marrow cellularity. Serum vitamin B12 and folate levels are normal. On further investigation, free T4 37.8 pmol/L, TSH < 0.01 mU/L, detection of anti-microsomal antibodies, anti-thyroglobulin antibodies and Thyroid Stimulating Immunoglobulins are seen. Which of the following is most likely to be seen in histology?

choices.text: Sheets of Polygonal cells in an amyloid stroma
Empty appearing nuclei with central clearing
A pale colloid in the follicular lumen with scalloped margins

questions.solution:
Option D: Pale colloid in the follicular lumen with scalloped margins

  • Low levels of TSH and the presence of anti-microsomal antibodies, anti-thyroglobulin antibodies, and Thyroid Stimulating Immunoglobulins suggests Grave’s Disease.
  • Grave’s Disease is Type II hypersensitivity caused primarily by Thyroid Stimulating Antibody (IgG, which can cause transient neonatal hyperthyroidism).
  • It often presents during stress (e.g. pregnancy or viral fever, as in the given patient). It is associated with HLA-DR3 and HLA-B8.
  • The most common antibody subtype, thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin (TSI), is observed in approximately 90% of patients with Graves disease resulting in hyperthyroidism. Thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin (TSI) is directed mainly against the TSH receptor. It stimulates the TSH receptor that causes the release of excessive Thyroid hormones, which leads to clinical manifestations of hyperthyroidism such as palpitations, sweating, heat intolerance and weight loss (yet to be seen in this patient).
  • Due to continuous stimulation by autoantibody, the thyroid gland is usually symmetrically enlarged due to diffuse hypertrophy and hyperplasia of follicular epithelial cells. Follicular epithelial cells in untreated cases are tall and more crowded than usual on histology. This crowding may result in the formation of small papillae, which project into the follicular lumen and encroach on the colloid, sometimes filling the follicles. The colloid within the follicular lumen is pale, with scalloped margins.

Option A: Sheets of Polygonal cells in an amyloid stroma

  • Sheets of Polygonal cells in an amyloid stroma are usually seen in medullary thyroid carcinoma, the tumour of Parafollicular 'C-cells' of the thyroid gland.
  • They produce calcitonin, which can lead to hypocalcemia.
  • It is associated with MEN2A and MEN2B (RET mutation).

Option B: Lymphocytic infiltration with germinal centres

  • Lymphocytic infiltration with germinal centres is usually seen in Hashimoto's Thyroiditis.
  • It is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient countries.
  • Other important features are present Anti-Thyroid peroxidase antibodies on serology and Hurthle’s cells on histology.

Option C: Empty appearing nuclei with central clearing

  • Empty appearing nuclei with central clearing (Orphan Annie eyes) are seen in papillary carcinoma of the thyroid
  • The other important features on histology are Psommoma bodies and nuclear grooves.

questions.text: A 47-year-old male with no previous medical history presents to his physician complaining of episodic headaches, sweating, palpitations, and tremors. The symptoms started a few years ago, have become more frequent, and can last between a few seconds and an hour. The episodes often occur when the patient is stressed or during exercises. He has no history of serious illnesses, hospitalizations, or trauma. He is not on any medications. Radiological imaging was done, which is shown below. Which of the following is the least likely feature of the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: 90% are malignant

  • 90% of pheochromocytomas are benign only 10% are malignant

Pheochromocytoma:

  • A pheochromocytoma is a catecholamine-secreting tumour that typically develops in the adrenal medulla.
  • Pheochromocytomas are usually benign (∼ 90% of cases) but may also be malignant.
  • Classic clinical features are due to excess sympathetic nervous system stimulation and involve episodic blood pressure crises with paroxysmal headaches, diaphoresis, heart palpitations, and pallor.
  • However, pheochromocytomas may also be asymptomatic or manifest with persistent hypertension.
  • Elevated catecholamine metabolites in the plasma or urine confirm the diagnosis, while imaging studies in patients with positive biochemistry are used to determine the tumour's location.
  • Surgical resection is the treatment of choice but is only carried out once alpha-adrenergic blockade with phenoxybenzamine has become effective.
  • Pheochromocytoma-rule of 10
    • 10% malignant
    • 10% Bilateral
    • 10% extraadrenal
    • 10% calcified
    • 10% children
    • 10% familial
    • Discussed 10 times more often than actually seen

Option B: 95% occur in the abdomen

  • Almost 95% of tumours are abdominal in location since 90% arise from the adrenal medulla
  • Therefore this statement is true regarding pheochromocytoma

Option C: They secrete catecholamines

  • These tumours secrete catecholamines like epinephrine, norepinephrine, dopamine
  • Therefore this statement is true regarding pheochromocytoma

Option D: They arise from sympathetic ganglia

  • Extra-adrenal pheochromocytomas occur in the sympathetic ganglia in the neck, mediastinum, bladder, and organ of Zukercandl [aortic bifurcation]
  • Therefore this statement is true regarding pheochromocytoma

questions.text: A 32-year-old female developed symptoms of amenorrhea about one and a half years after she stopped nursing her baby; she had no resumption of menses. Her gynaecologist told her she had Polycystic ovary syndrome (after five successful pregnancies without assistance). She then developed acne and facial hair about 6 months later. Subsequently, she developed back pain and was found to have a compression fracture of her lumbar spine. Imaging shows a decreased size of the adrenal gland. . What will be the most common cause of the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Exogenous corticosteroids

  • This patient with hyperglycemia, weight gain, amenorrhea, acne, hirsutism, and bilateral enlarged adrenal glands most likely suggests Cushing syndrome.

Cushing syndrome(Hypercortisolism)

  • Hypercortisolism:
  • Hypercortisolism is an endocrine condition typically produced by exogenous glucocorticoids (iatrogenic Cushing syndrome).
  • Endogenous overproduction of cortisol is another cause that might contribute to Cushing syndrome.
  • The adrenal gland's autonomous overproduction of cortisol is the primary cause of primary hypercortisolism (e.g., due to an adrenal adenoma or carcinoma). Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) is produced excessively by either a pituitary adenoma (Cushing disease) or ectopic, paraneoplastic foci, leading to secondary hypercortisolism (e.g., in patients with small cell lung cancer).
  • The typical clinical characteristics are central obesity, thin, easily bruised skin, abdominal striae, secondary hypertension, hyperglycemia, and proximal muscular weakness. Hypercortisolism is diagnosed using cortisol measurements (urine free and/or late-night salivary cortisol) and/or the dexamethasone suppression test.
  • To distinguish between primary and secondary hypercortisolism, serum ACTH levels are employed.
  • The standard test to diagnose Cushing syndrome is a 24-hours urine cortisol measurement.
  • Depending on the suspected Cushing syndrome, more tests could involve imaging, additional hormone testing, and a bilateral inferior petrosal sinus sample.
  • To treat endogenous hypercortisolism, the source of excessive cortisol or ACTH production is typically surgically removed (adrenalectomy or transsphenoidal hypophysectomy).
  • In addition to surgery, pharmacological therapy to normalize cortisol levels, such as metyrapone, may be utilized as a backup plan if surgery is unsuccessful.

Option B: Pituitary tumour

  • The pituitary tumour most likely causes elevated prolactin levels.
  • High prolactin can cause amenorrhea.
  • However, hirsutism, acne, and high cortisol level is unlikely
  • Moreover, ACTH-producing tumours can cause these symptoms but usually present with headaches and bilateral adrenal gland enlargement.

Option C: Adrenal adenoma

  • Adrenal adenoma can present with symptoms consistent with Cushing syndrome.
  • However, the adrenal gland will be enlarged in such patients, not shrunken.

Option D: Adrenal carcinoma

  • Adrenal gland carcinoma is a less common cause of Cushing syndrome than adrenal adenoma and exogenous steroid use.
  • Moreover, the gland is enlarged, not shrunken, on the imaging in case of carcinoma

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and coronary artery disease presented to emergency complaining of approximately 1–2 weeks of neck pain radiating to his chest. The pain is associated with movement, particularly when he moves his head and neck. Other than the presenting symptoms, his review of symptoms was negative. His blood pressure was 126/67 mm Hg, and his pulse was 88 beats/min. Chest CT revealed no significant cardiac or pulmonary disease. However, a large ill-defined 4 cm right thyroid nodule was noted, associated with tracheal deviation at the thoracic inlet. TSH was normal at 1.18 mIU/ml. Hemithyroidectomy was done, and the H&E stain was positive for the nest of tumour cells and calcitonin shown below. RET proto-oncogene is associated with the most probable diagnosis discussed above:
questions.solution:
Option A: Medullary thyroid cancer

  • The patient described in the clinical vignette has a thyroid mass, and histopathology shows tumour cells containing calcitonin which is the hallmark of medullary thyroid carcinoma associated with RET-proto-oncogene.

RET is a proto-oncogene that is:-

  • Associated with the development of MEN II syndrome (affects thyroid & adrenal medulla)
  • Therefore, patients have the risk of developing medullary thyroid cancer & pheochromocytoma.
  • So, by rule, every patient with medullary carcinoma of the thyroid should be screened for pheochromocytoma.

Option B: Follicular thyroid cancer

  • RAS proto-oncogene is associated with Follicular thyroid cancer
  • Therefore this option is also incorrect

Option C: Papillary thyroid cancer

  • Papillary thyroid cancer is also associated with the RET-PTC gene
  • However, the presence of calcitonin makes medullary carcinoma of the thyroid the most likely diagnosis

Option D: Anaplastic thyroid cancer

  • Anaplastic thyroid cancer is associated with the p53 gene.
  • Therefore this option is also incorrect

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presented with neurological deficits and seizures. Imaging showed a lesion in the temporal lobe. Biopsy was taken from the lesion, and neural tissue was sent for histological examination (microscopy shown below). Based on the characteristic histological features, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Oligodendroglioma

  • The tumours are composed of spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm, giving a 'fried egg' appearance.
  • The tumour typically contains a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries ('chicken-wire capillaries).
  • Perineuronal Satellitosis is a feature of oligodendroglioma.
  • Most commonly presented in the fourth and fifth decades.
  • The lesion is mostly found in the cerebral hemispheres (mainly in the temporal or frontal lobes).

  • Image on the left showing perinuclear halos giving rise to a 'fried egg' appearance.
  • Image on the right showing Perineuronal satellitosis.

Option A: Glioblastoma

  • Glioblastoma is a Grade IV astrocytoma.
  • It is a common, highly malignant primary brain tumour with one-year median survival.
  • It is found in the cerebral hemispheres.
  • It can cross the corpus callosum "butterfly glioma" associated with EGFR amplification.
  • It is of astrocyte origin, glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) positive.
  • "Pseudopalisading" pleomorphic tumour cells with central border areas of necrosis, haemorrhage, and/or microvascular proliferation.

Option B: Pilocytic astrocytoma

  • It is a low-grade astrocytoma. Most common primary brain tumour in childhood.
  • Usually well circumscribed.
  • In children, most often found in the posterior fossa (e.g., cerebellum), but supratentorial can also be found.
  • It has a benign course and a good prognosis.
  • Histology shows it is of astrocyte origin, GFAP positive, with bipolar neoplastic cells with hairlike projections.
  • Associated with microcysts and Rosenthal fibres (eosinophilic, corkscrew fibres)

Option D: Medulloblastoma

  • Most common malignant brain tumour in childhood.
  • It commonly involves the cerebellum and can compress the 4th ventricle causing non-communicating hydrocephalus causing, headaches and papilledema.
  • It can involve the cerebellar vermis causing truncal ataxia.
  • It can send "drop metastases" to the spinal cord.
  • Histology shows it is a form of primitive neuroectodermal tumour (PNET).
  • "Homer-Wright rosette" (small blue cells surrounding the central area of the neuropil)
  • It is positive for synaptophysin.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presented with slurring of speech and right-side weakness of both upper and lower limbs. CT head revealed the presence of an infarct in the brain. Disease or infarction of neurological tissue causes it to be replaced by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option B: Neuroglia

  • Reactive astrocytes can be seen as early as 1 week after the insult. 
  • As the process of liquefaction and phagocytosis proceeds, astrocytes at the edges of the lesion progressively enlarge, divide, and develop a prominent network of cytoplasmic extensions.
  • After several months, the astrocytic response recedes, leaving behind a dense meshwork of glial fibres admixed with new capillaries and some perivascular connective tissue. 
  • In the cerebral cortex, the cavity is separated from the meninges and subarachnoid space by a gliotic layer of tissue derived from the molecular layer of the cortex. 
  • The pia and arachnoid are unaffected and do not contribute to the healing process.
  • Infarcts undergo these reactive and reparative stages from the inward edges; thus, different areas of a lesion may look different, particularly during the early stages, revealing the natural progression of the response.

Option A: Fluid

  • A dense meshwork of glial fibres admixed with new capillaries and perivascular connective tissue is formed after several months of injury.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option C: Proliferation of adjacent nerve cells

  • A dense meshwork of glial fibres admixed with new capillaries and perivascular connective tissue is formed after several months of injury.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option D: Blood vessel

  • A dense meshwork of glial fibres admixed with new capillaries and perivascular connective tissue is formed after several months of injury.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: A 36-year old female patient is evaluated for gram negative septicemia. The patient’s medical records reveals that she has earlier experienced an episode of anaphylaxis leading to shock after the administration of penicillin V. Which of the following drugs can be used in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Aztreonam

  • In a patient with severe sensitivity to Penicillin, all beta-lactams are contraindicated as they can cause a life-threatening reaction
  • Monobactams can be used instead of beta-lactams in this case as they lack the thiazole ring of Beta lactams and are safe to use if there is a contraindication to beta-lactams.
  • Aztreonam and imipenem are effective for gram-negative infections. However, as the patient is allergic to beta-lactams, carbapenems show cross allergy and are contraindicated in people with beta-lactam allergy. So Aztreonam is preferred in such a patient.​​​​​​​

Option A: Ampicillin plus sulbactam

  • Ampicillin is a beta-lactam which can cause a life-threatening infection again in this patient, so it is contraindicated

Option C: Cefazolin

  • Cefazolin is a cephalosporin and is a beta-lactam, so it cannot be administered to this patient with evidence of beta-lactam allergic reaction

Option D: Imipenem plus cilastatin

  • Imipenem is a carbapenem, and carbapenems have shown cross-allergy in patients with a beta-lactam allergy, so it is also contraindicated in this case

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presents at the clinic with complaints of foul-smelling white discharge from the urethra. He also has burning micturition for 10 days. He also gave a history of intercourse with a commercial sex worker 7 days prior to the onset of all symptoms. Gram staining shows gram-negative diplococci. Which of the following is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
Option B: Ceftriaxone

  • The patient had intercourse with a Commercial sex worker a week prior to the onset of symptoms. 
  • He also presented with symptoms of mucopurulent discharge per urethra, and the Gram staining showed gram-negative diplococci. All of this is suggestive of Gonococcal urethritis.
  • For Gonococcal urethritis, the drug of choice is ceftriaxone.

Option A: Clindamycin

  • Clindamycin is indicated for the treatment of infections caused by susceptible Bacterioid species and other anaerobes. 
  • It is used in combination with an aminoglycoside or cephalosporin, is used to treat penetrating wounds of the abdomen and the gut; infections originating in the female genital tract, e.g., septic abortion, pelvic abscesses, or pelvic inflammatory disease; and lung and periodontal abscesses.

Option C: Metronidazole

  • Metronidazole is effective for Trichomonas vaginalis infection in males and females.
  • It is also indicated for infection with Gardnerella vaginalis.

Option D: Azithromycin

  • For non-gonococcal urethritis, the drug of choice is azithromycin

questions.text: A 48-year-old male undergoing Whipple’s procedure suddenly becomes rigid. His temperature rises to 104º F. The anaesthetist identifies it as a case of malignant hyperthermia. He starts the treatment with a skeletal muscle relaxant. Which of the following describes the correct mechanism of action for the skeletal muscle relaxant?

choices.text: Reduces acetylcholine release from motor nerve endings
Inhibits the generation of muscle action potential
Reduces calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum in the muscle fibre

questions.solution:
Option D: Reduces calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum in the muscle fibre

  • Dantrolene is a skeletal muscle relaxant which resembles centrally acting muscle relaxants.
  • It acts by uncoupling muscle contractions from membrane depolarization.
  • It acts on the ryanodine receptor (RyR1) receptor located on the sarcoplasmic reticulum to reduce calcium release through these channels in the skeletal muscles.
  • As calcium ions are not released into the cytoplasm, the excitation-contraction coupling does not occur.
  • Fast-contracting muscles are more affected than slow-contracting muscles.
  • It is the preferred drug for malignant hyperthermia, which occurs due to the persistent release of calcium ions from the sarcoplasmic reticulum initiated by fluorinated anaesthetics.
  • Adverse effects include muscle weakness, sedation, malaise, light-headedness, and dose-dependent liver toxicity.

Option A: Reduces acetylcholine release from motor nerve endings

  • Hemicholinium, botulinum toxin, aminoglycosides, magnesium, and calcium ions reduce acetylcholine release from motor nerve endings.

Option B: Suppresses spinal polysynaptic reflexes

  • NMDA antagonists and tizanidine inhibit spinal polysynaptic reflexes.

Option C: Inhibits the generation of muscle action potential

  • Neuromuscular blocking drugs (muscle relaxants) such as tubocurarine, pancuronium, doxacurium, succinylcholine, and suxamethonium block and inhibit the generation of the muscle action potential.

questions.text: A 4-year-old kid was referred to a small clinic since she had seizures continuously for over 8 minutes (including time to shift to the hospital). Which of the following is considered the drug of choice as first line medication for Status Epilepticus?
questions.solution:
Option C: Lorazepam

  • The question mentioned above is a case of Status Epilepticus.
  • Status epilepticus is defined as a seizure occurring for more than 5 minutes of duration.
  • Lorazepam is a benzodiazepine, the first-line drug in treating active status epilepticus. Diazepam is the 2nd line drug.
  • It also treats anxiety disorders, sleep problems, severe agitation, active seizures, alcohol withdrawal, and chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting.
  • Lorazepam is the preferred sedative and anxiolytic in the inpatient environment due to its rapid (1 to 3 minutes) start of action when delivered intravenously.
  • Lorazepam is also one of the few sedative-hypnotics with a low risk of adverse effects.

Option A: Valproate

  • Valproate is an anticonvulsant that increases Na+ channel inactivation and GABA concentration by inhibiting GABA transaminase.
  • It is generally used for tonic-clonic seizures but can be used for treating partial (focal).
  • Valproate is the first-line drug for absence seizures in India
  • It is also used for migraines, myoclonic seizures, and bipolar disorder prophylaxis.

Option B: Phenytoin

  • Phenytoin is an anti-epileptic drug which functions by blocking Na+ channels.
  • It is mainly used in the treatment of focal (partial) seizures.
  • It is also used as the 1st line drug for prophylaxis of recurrent status epilepticus.

Option D: Carbamazepine

  • Carbamazepine is an anticonvulsant drug primarily used to treat epilepsy and neuropathic pain.
  • Carbamazepine treats trigeminal neuralgia and can also benefit peripheral neuropathy of diabetic origin.
  • It is also used as adjunctive therapy in schizophrenia and a second-line drug in bipolar disorder.

questions.text: A 43-year-old male presented in the OPD with complaints of excessive thirst. He also reports has polyuria and polyphagia. He suspects it could be diabetes mellitus and orders fasting blood sugar, postprandial blood sugar & HbA1c. The HbA1c was about 12%, and the blood sugar values were over 240. He decides to start the patient on subcutaneous insulin therapy and educate the patient regarding the same. What is the mechanism of action of the therapy prescribed?
questions.solution:
Option B: Stimulation of Enzymatic receptor

  • Insulin acts by stimulation of Tyrosine kinase receptor → enzymatic receptor.
  • A full insulin receptor consists of two covalently linked heterodimers.
  • Tyrosine kinase receptor contains α subunit, which is entirely extracellular and constitutes the recognition site, and a β subunit that spans the membrane.
  • The β subunit contains tyrosine kinase.

Option A: Stimulation of Ionotropic receptor

  • Ionotropic receptors are coupled with some ion channels.
  •  When they bind a ligand, activation of the receptor results in a conformational change, rendering the ion channel open. In other words, they are the ligand-gated ion channels. The binding of the ligand results in the opening of ion channels
  • Ionotropic receptors allow ions to diffuse down their electrochemical gradient.

Option C: Stimulation of Metabotropic Receptors

  • A metabotropic receptor, also referred to by the broader term G-protein-coupled receptor, is a type of membrane receptor that initiates a number of metabolic steps to modulate cell activity. The nervous system utilizes two types of receptors: metabotropic and ionotropic receptors.
  • When a metabotropic receptor is activated, a series of intracellular events are triggered that can also result in ion channels opening or other intracellular events but involve a range of second messenger chemicals.

Option D: Stimulation of Nuclear receptor

  • Nuclear receptors are activated by lipid-soluble signals (e.g., steroid hormones) that cross the plasma membrane.
  • Once activated, most function as transcription factors to control gene expression for numerous biological processes.

questions.text: A 51-year-old patient visits the clinic again, expressing gastric irritation and diarrhea, despite recurrent duodenal ulcers and multiple treatments. After a secretin stimulation test shows elevated serum gastrin levels, which medication would the doctor prescribe to manage this condition?
questions.solution:
Option B: Omeprazole

  • This is a case of Zollinger-Ellison syndrome with an increase in gastrin level after administration of secretin and recurrent ulcers in the duodenum. 
  • Zollinger Ellison syndrome:
    • It is a Pancreatic or duodenal gastrinoma, which leads to the secretion of large amounts of gastric acid causing severe ulcers and hyperchlorhydria. PPI is better than H2 blockers in this condition.
    • Omeprazole and all related "-prazoles" are irreversible and direct inhibitors of a proton pump (K+ /H+ antiport) in gastric parietal cells.
    • Other drugs in proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) include Esomeprazole, Pantoprazole, and Rabeprazole.
    • Rabeprazole is safe during pregnancy.
    • PPIs are more effective than H2  Antagonists like Cimetidine
    • Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) are the drugs of choice for peptic ulcer disease (PUD) due to any aetiology (even NSAID induced).
    • These are also the agents of choice for gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome (ZES)

Option A: Cimetidine

  • Cimetidine is H2 Antagonist; other agents in this class include Ranitidine and Famotidine.
  • Mechanism of Action: Reversible blockage of histamine H2-receptors and ultimately decrease H+ secretion by parietal cells.
  • Uses: Peptic ulcers, GERD, and Zollinger-Ellison syndrome.
  • Overall less effective than PPIs in PUD.

Option C: Misoprostol

  • Mechanism of Action: Prostaglandin E1  (PGE1) synthetic analogue, which is cytoprotective and increases the secretion of bicarbonate and mucus and decreases the secretion of HCL.
  • Uses for NSAID-induced ulcers and termination of pregnancy with a mifepristone combination.

Option D: Aluminium hydroxide

  • Aluminium hydroxide is an antacid with constipation as the most common side effect in the antacid class; it also causes Hypophosphatemia, Proximal muscle weakness, and seizures.
  • All antacid, including Aluminium hydroxide, causes Hypokalemia and can delay gastric emptying.

questions.text: A couple is presenting to you for a consultancy. They are planning a trekking experience in the Himalayas. The wife had previously experienced nausea and dizziness when she went for a trek in Skardu. Which of the following medications would you let her take to avoid developing headache, nausea, dizziness, and difficulty breathing?
questions.solution:
Option D: Acetazolamide

  • The drug of choice for acute mountain sickness is carbonic anhydrase inhibitors like Acetazolamide.
  • Symptoms of mountain sickness include headache, tiredness/fatigue, difficulty of breathing, nausea/ sick feeling, dizziness etc.
  • Acetazolamide works by acidifying the blood and reducing the respiratory alkalosis associated with high elevations, thus increasing respiration and arterial oxygenation and speeding acclimatization.
  • The best treatment is to descend down because it occurs due to decreased pO2 at high altitudes.

Option A: Diltiazem

  • Diltiazem is a calcium channel blocker and acts on calcium channels of the heart as well as blood vessels.
  • It is used to control blood pressure and arrhythmias.

Option B: Digoxin

  • Digoxin is an inhibitor of the Na+-K+ ATPase pump, increasing calcium concentration inside the cell and resulting in increased inotropy of the cardiac muscles.
  • It also stimulates the vagus nerve and decreases heart rate.

Option C: Dexamethasone

  • Dexamethasone is used in the dexamethasone suppression test for Cushing's disease.
  • It has also been used in differential diagnoses of different depressive psychiatric states.

questions.text: Which of the following is the mechanism of action of a statin drug?
questions.solution:
Option D: HMG-CoA reductase inhibitor

  • Above mentioned clinical scenario indicates the patient has ST-segment elevation and elevated troponin I levels, confirming a myocardial infarction(MI).
  • Atherosclerosis is central in developing an MI; statins have a key role in the acute and chronic management of a patient with MI.
  • Statins work by inhibiting HMG-CoA reductase.
  • HMG-CoA reductase is a very important enzyme in lipogenesis.
  • HMG-CoA reductase catalyses the rate-limiting step in cholesterol biosynthesis (conversion of HMG-CoA to mevalonate).
  • Statins act by inhibiting this enzyme competitively and decrease cholesterol synthesis in the liver.

Option A: HMG-CoA synthase stimulator

  • HMG-CoA synthase is another important enzyme in lipogenesis.
  • It catalyses the condensation of acetoacetyl CoA into HMG-CoA.
  • Stimulating lipogenesis will be counterproductive for our target.
  • Statins do not interact with HMG-CoA synthase.

Option B. HMG-CoA reductase stimulator

  • HMG-CoA reductase is also an enzyme that catalyses lipogenesis's key step.
  • Stimulating lipogenesis will increase cholesterol synthesis, thereby increasing the cholesterol levels in the blood.

Option C: HMG-CoA synthase inhibitor

  • HMG-CoA synthase is another important enzyme in lipogenesis.
  • It catalyses the condensation of acetoacetyl CoA into HMG-CoA.
  • Statins do not interact with HMG CoA synthase.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can likely worsen myocardial ischemia in a patient with angina?
questions.solution:
Option B: Nifedipine

  • Headache right above the nape of the neck and examination revealing the high BP, previous history of the parents of hypertension; all these are suggestive of angina pectoris.
  • Vasodilators and peripherally acting CCBs (Dihydropyridines) can cause tachycardia and thus may precipitate an acute attack of Angina.
  • The risk of tachycardia is higher with short-acting drugs like nifedipine than with long-acting agents like amlodipine.
  • Still, theoretically, there is a possibility for developing tachycardia on the usage of amlodipine, nicardipine and clevidipine, too.
  • Diltiazem & verapamil results in decreased heart rate even while causing vasodilation.

 

Option A: Amlodipine

  • Amlodipine is a calcium channel blocker drug used to treat coronary artery disease and high blood pressure.
  • It is consumed orally. Typical adverse effects include oedema, fatigue, pain in the abdomen, and nausea.

Option C: Diltiazem

  • Diltiazem is a calcium channel blocker drug used to treat excessive blood pressure, angina, and types of heart arrhythmias.
  • If beta blockers are ineffective, they may also be used to treat hyperthyroidism. It can be consumed orally or administered intravenously.

Option D: Verapamil

  • Verapamil is a calcium channel blocker medicine used to treat high blood pressure, angina, and supraventricular tachycardia.
  • Additionally, it can be used to stop migraines and cluster headaches. It is administered orally or by venous injection.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female is brought to the physician by her mother with complaints of bradykinesia and resting tremors for five days. The mother of the patient further gives a history that the wedding of the patient was called off due to personal reasons, pushing her into a pile of stress. At times, the patient was noted to have violent episodes. After consultation with a psychiatrist, she was diagnosed with schizophrenia. The psychiatrist prescribed haloperidol for the control of the symptoms. A few weeks post-drug initiation, the patient developed these symptoms. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities. Which of the following would be the best to treat the patient’s current symptoms?
questions.solution:
Option C: M1 muscarinic antagonist

  • This is a case of drug-induced Parkinsonism in which the patient presents with complaints of bradykinesia and resting tremors for five days after using haloperidol.
  • M1 muscarinic antagonist is the best drug to be used for the treatment of drug-induced Parkinsonism.
  • Extrapyramidal disturbances are the major dose-limiting side effects of high-potency antipsychotics like fluphenazine, haloperidol, pimozide, etc.
  • The extrapyramidal effects may be categorised into:
    • Parkinsonism
    • Acute muscular dystonia
    • Akathisia
    • Malignant neuroleptic syndrome
    • Tardive dyskinesia
  • Parkinsonism usually appears between 1-4 weeks of therapy.
  • It occurs due to an imbalance between acetylcholine and dopamine. Since Parkinsonism is usually due fall in dopamine levels. Anticholinergic drugs are given to balance out acetylcholine levels.

Option A: Cholinesterase inhibitors

  • The cholinesterase inhibitors inhibit the AchE enzyme, which results in a decreased breakdown of acetylcholine.
  • Pyridostigmine, neostigmine and ambenonium are examples of cholinesterase inhibitors.

Option B: Beta receptor antagonist

  • Beta receptor antagonists are commonly used in the treatment of angina, myocardial infarction and arrhythmias.
  • It includes:
    • Atenolol
    • Metoprolol
    • Propranolol

Option D: Alpha 1 adrenergic antagonist

  • Alpha 1 adrenergic antagonist results in vasoconstriction.
  • It is commonly used for the treatment of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia.

questions.text: A few Doctors Without Borders physicians on a 6-month African village posting encounter a pale foreigner complaining of extreme fatigue since arrival. He's a diabetic on insulin with controlled bronchial asthma. Despite malaria prophylaxis, he struggles with food adjustment and erratic blood glucose. If suspecting a pharmacogenetic condition, what might explain his current state?
questions.solution:
Option D: Primaquine-induced hemolytic anaemia

Pharmacogenetics:

  • Pharmacogenetics deals with genetic variation in the expression of enzymes that metabolize drugs.
  • These genetic differences can cause a drug response to deviate from the expected response and increase the risk of side effects.
  • If the enzyme in question is responsible for the breakdown of a drug, the following effects are possible:
    • A hyperactive variant of the enzyme decreases the drug response.
    • A hypoactive variant of the enzyme can cause cumulative drug effects and thus increase the risk of side effects.
  • The reverse is true if the enzyme is responsible for the activation of a drug. E.g. CYP2D6 polymorphism 
    • There are hyperactive and hypoactive variants.
    • CYP2D6 is involved in the metabolism of many drugs (e.g., the breakdown of antiarrhythmics and tricyclic antidepressants; the activation of codeine).
    • Gender-specific differences in CYP2D6 have been observed (e.g., CYP2D6-mediated breakdown of beta-blockers (such as metoprolol) is greater among women).
  • Primaquine is an oxidant drug. It can cause hemolytic anaemia in subjects having a deficiency of the G6PD enzyme.
  • This condition is genetically determined.

Option A: Hypoglycemia by insulin

  • Hypoglycemia due to insulin can occur due to the following conditions:
  • Insulin excess
    • Accidental overdose of insulin or noninsulin drugs (e.g., sulfonylureas, meglitinides)
    • Wrongly timed medication
    • Drug interactions
    • Factitious disorder
  • Increased sensitivity to insulin
    • Weight loss
    • Increase in activity/exercise
  • Decreased insulin clearance
    • Renal failure

Option B: Tachycardia by albuterol

  • Tachycardia by albuterol is the dose-dependent adverse effect of Albuterol and can happen in any individual.

Option C: Metoclopramide-induced muscle dystonia

  • Metoclopramide is a D2 receptor antagonist and increases the resting tone, contractility, lower oesophageal sphincter tone, and motility and promotes gastric emptying.
  • It is used in diabetic and postoperative gastroparesis as an antiemetic and persistent GERD.
  • Metoclopramide disrupts central dopaminergic signalling. Thus it may produce rare movement disorders, such as acute dystonic reactions.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl arrived at the ER after ingesting 15 tablets of an unknown drug, causing altered mental status, rapid breathing, and vomiting. To treat drug toxicity, various methods can remove the drug from the body, such as dialysis. Which drug, when toxic, is eliminated through urine acidification?
questions.solution:
Option C: Amphetamine

  • In this case, the patient presented in a semi-conscious state with tachypnea and vomiting due to drug overdose toxicity.
  • Most drugs are metabolized in the liver and excreted by the kidneys.
  • During the poisoning of drugs, multiple mechanisms work to remove the drug from the body.
  • Changes in urinary pH affect tubular reabsorption of partially ionized drugs. Weak bases ionize more and are less reabsorbed in acidic urine. Weak acids ionize more and are less reabsorbed in alkaline urine.
  • Urine is acidified in case of amphetamine poisoning, as amphetamine is basic. It ionizes more and absorbs less in acidic urine.

Option A: Salicylates

  • Urinary pH has a great impact on the reabsorption of a drug.
  • Weak acids ionize more and reabsorb less in alkaline urine.
  • Urine is alkalinized in salicylate poisoning, as salicylate is a weak acid, so it ionizes more and reabsorbs less in alkaline urine.

Option B: Barbiturates

  • Urinary pH has a great impact on the reabsorption of a drug.
  • Weak acids ionize more and reabsorb less in alkaline urine
  • Urine is alkalinized in barbiturate poisoning, as it is a weak acid, so it ionizes more and reabsorbs less in alkaline urine.

Option D: Methotrexate

  • Urinary pH has a great impact on the reabsorption of a drug.
  • Weak acids ionize more and reabsorb less in alkaline urine
  • Urine is alkalinized in methotrexate poisoning, as it is a weak acid, so it ionizes more and reabsorbs less in alkaline urine.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents to the outpatient department with hypotension, shortness of breath, swollen feet, and fatigue for the last day. He is a known case of ischemic heart disease. The patient also reports a history of snake bite six hours back. A clinicopathological conference is planned, and the same patient is discussed in the case study by a team of doctors, including a physician and a microbiologist. The microbiologist is asked about sterilizing heat-sensitive liquids like serum, vaccines, antisera, enzymes, and antibiotic solutions used in this patient. Which of the following best fixes heat labile keys in this case?
questions.solution:
Option C: Membrane filtration

  • Heat-sensitive liquids like serum, vaccines, antisera, enzymes, antibiotics, and urea can be sterilized using membrane filtration. The filtration can be aided by using either positive or negative pressure.

  • 3 types of filters:

Depth filters

Membrane filters

Air filters

  • Porous filters [metal polymer with random mats]

  • Examples:

      • Candle filters

      • Unglazed porcelain filters

      • Seitz filter

      • Sintered glass filter

  • Most widely used filters for bacterial filtration

  • Made up of cellulose acetate, cellulose nitrate and polycarbonate

  • Pore size:

    • 0.22 µ → most common used

    • 0.45 µ → retains coliforms

    • 0.8 µ → retains airborne microorganisms

  • Use → to sterilize sugar, sera & antibiotic solution.

  • HEPA [high-efficiency particulate air] filter→ removes 99.97% of particles having a size of 0.3µ or more.

  • ULPA [ultra low particulate/penetration] → removes 99.999% of dust, pollen, and moulds.

    • Control → Brevundimonas diminuta & Serratia marcescens

 

Option A: Dry heat

  • Dry heat sterilization is one of the earliest types of sterilization practiced.

  • It uses hot air from water vapour, but this moisture plays a minimal or no role in sterilization.

Option B: Autoclave

  • This process is used to sterilize the medical grounds and stainless-steel instruments.

Option D: Pasteurization

  • Pasteurization is used for liquids like milk to sterilize at low temperatures for a short time.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male presents to the physician with complaints of repeated episodes of diarrhoea and fever for 1 week. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examinations reveal no abnormalities. The doctor sent the patient for stool examination and culture in the microbiology laboratory, which revealed a salmonella infection. In the laboratory, what screening procedure is used to differentiate the organism involved in the patient's pathology from other Enterobacteriaceae?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer

Option B: Inability to ferment lactose

  • This is a case of infectious diarrhoea, in which the patient presents with a complaint of fever and diarrhoea for 1 week.
  • It is caused by salmonella.
  • The inability to ferment lactose differentiates salmonella and shigella from other Enterobacteriaceae.
  • Enterobacteriaceae properties:
    • Ferments glucose
    • Reduces nitrate to nitrite
    • Oxidase test negative
    • Catalase positive (except Shigella dysenteriae type-1)
    • Motile, except Shigella and Klebsiella.

Other Options

Option A: Inability to ferment glucose

  • Glucose fermenters include:
    • Enterobacteriaceae
    • Salmonella
    • Shigella

Option C: Produce cytochrome oxidase

  • Enterobacteriaceae and salmonella can produce cytochrome oxidase; on this basis, it is not differentiated from salmonella.

Option D: Reduce nitrates

  • The bacteria which can reduce nitrates include:
    • Lactobacillus brevis 
    • Lactobacillus fermentum
    • Lactobacillus acidophilus
    • Lactobacillus plantarum

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presents with fever, weight loss, and cough for several days. He is found to be HIV positive, and hepatomegaly is seen on examination. Sputum culture on SDA and staining reveal the fungus shown in the figure below. Which of the following fungus is the causative agent for this condition?
questions.solution:
Option C: Penicillium

  • The image shows brush-like conidiophores.
  • Brush-like conidiophores formed at 25 0C are characteristic of the Penicillium fungus.
  • P. marneffei is the only dimorphic species of the Penicillium fungus.
  • The yeast form is seen as small, oval, 2-4 mm in diameter spherules. The mycelial form produces brick red-colored diffusible pigment.
  • It is an opportunistic fungus and causes infection in immunocompromised patients or individuals with a defective immune system and metabolic diseases like diabetes mellitus.
  • Penicillium causes tuberculosis-like disease involving the liver, spleen, and lungs.

Option A: Aspergillus

  • Aspergillus forms septate hyphae and conidiophores on wet preparations stained with lactophenol cotton blue.
  • Aspergillus fungus forms conidiophores with swollen round vesicles with chains of conidia on elongated cells. These elongated cells are called sterigmata.
  • Tissue sections of Aspergillus fungus show typical dichotomous branching of hyphae at acute angles.
  • Aspergillus is also an opportunistic fungus and causes several clinical syndromes:
    • Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis
    • Aspergilloma
    • Invasive aspergillosis
    • Superficial infections

Option B: Absidia

  • Absidia causes an invasive disease called mucormycosis.
  • Spores of Absidia are found in air and dust.
  • Wet preparation shows broad ribbon-like hyphae. Hyphae are readily stained with hematoxylin and eosin and show broad, non-septate hyphae.
  • Under the microscope, broad hyphae ending in sporangium can be seen.
  • Absidia causes invasive diseases and can be treated with intravenous amphotericin B.

Option D: Acremonium

  • Acremonium fungus causes ocular keratitis.
  • Ocular keratitis by Acremonium fungus can be caused by a preceding corneal injury and bacterial infection of the cornea.
  • Under the microscope, Acremonium can be seen as hyaline hyphae, which produce simple awl-shaped erect phialides with inconspicuous collarettes.
  • Conidia of Acremonium are one-celled, hyaline or rarely pigmented, globose to cylindrical, and mostly aggregated in slimy heads at the apex of each phialide.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the physician with complaints of fever, loose motion and nausea for 2 days. He further gives a history of foul-smelling fatty stools. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examinations reveal no abnormalities. Analysis of stool on wet mount shows motile protozoa without RBCs and pus cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Giardiasis

  • This is a case of giardiasis in which the patient presents with complaints of fever, loose motion, nausea and foul-smelling fatty stools.
  • It is caused by the parasite Giardia duodenalis.
  • It results in malabsorption syndrome and steatorrhea (fat in stools, bulky stools).
  • Predisposing conditions to giardiasis are agammaglobulinemia, common variable immunodeficiency and selective IgA deficiency.

        1. Giardia causes noninvasive diarrhea, so there will be no RBCs.

        2. In acute giardiasis, diarrhea is often foul-smelling with fat and mucus without blood. It causes G.I. disturbances

        3. Microscopy: Demonstration of either trophozoite (active infection) or cyst (carrier) sample by iodine and saline wet mount preparations.

  • Trophozoites(image above):
  • Axostyles are present
  • 4 pairs of Flagella → Falling leaf-like motility
  • Sucking disc → helps in adherence to various surfaces (virulence factor)
  • Enter test/ String test done to demonstrate trophozoites.

  • A cyst (image below):
  • 4 nuclei present
  • Have Axostyle

Option A: B. coli

  • Balantidium coli may cause dysentery: Ulcers mimic amebic ulcers but never invade the muscular layer.

Option C: Trichomonas hominis

  • T. hominis is non-pathogenic.
  • It may be associated with diarrhoeagenic stools.

Option D: E. histolytica

  • E. histolytica causes dysentery.
  • The dysentery results in RBCs in the stool.

questions.text: A 32-year-old lady brings her two-year-old unimmunized child to a child specialist. The baby has suffered from high-grade fever, cough, runny nose, and watery eyes for 5 days. The mother also gives a history of rash starting behind the ear pinna a day before coming to the hospital. On examination, the baby has normal weight and height according to age, his eyes are watery, and maculopapular rashes are seen on the abdomen and trunk region. What is the most probable diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Measles

  • Measles usually occurs in an unvaccinated child.
  • Usually, involve children.
  • Maculopapular rashes, which begin behind the ears, are the characteristic feature of measles.
  • The rash spreads from head to trunk towards the lower extremities.
  • Symptoms of measles include fever, running nose, and congested eyes.
  • Infectivity period is 4 days before and 5 days after the rash.
  • The virus is transmitted through direct contact by droplets or airborne spread when an infected person breathes, coughs, or sneezes.

Option B: Mumps

  • The mumps virus causes mumps.
  • The mumps Virus belongs to a family of viruses known as paramyxoviruses.
  • Mumps present with bilateral parotid swelling.
  • Pain while chewing or swallowing. Mumps is a viral infection primarily affecting salivary glands near your ears.

Option C: Rubella

  • The rubella virus causes rubella / German Measles
  • There is a rash on the face with lymphadenopathy.
  • Infectivity period: 1 Week before and1 week after the rash.
  • Forchheimer Spots are seen.

  • Blue Berry Muffin Rash Seen over uvula.

Option D: Chickenpox

  • Chickenpox is a contagious disease.
  • Chickenpox is due to the varicella-zoster virus (VZV).
  • Chicken pox presents with fever with vesicular rash. (Refer to the images below).
  • Infectivity period: 2 days before and 5 days after the rash [until the scab Falls].
  • Centripetal Rash, Dew Drop Appearance & Pleomorphism seen.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the emergency department physician because of progressive pain and swelling of her wrists and hands for the past two months. Her hands are stiff in the morning; the stiffness decreases as she starts her chores. She also reports early-morning neck pain at rest for the past three weeks. Tenderness of the wrists, second, third, and fourth metacarpophalangeal joints; a range of motion is limited by pain. The doctor sent her sample for immunoglobulin testing to the microbiology laboratory. Which of the following is true about the classes of immunoglobulins?

choices.text: IgM has a maximum half-life of 23 days
IgE has least serum concentration of 0.0003 mg/ml
IgG has a maximum sedimentation co-efficient of 19
IgD has a carbohydrate concentration of 8 %

questions.solution:
Option B: IgE has least serum concentration of 0.0003 mg/ml

  • The above given is a case of rheumatoid arthritis.

  • It is a systemic inflammatory condition that causes morning joint stiffness and polyarthritis.

  • Immunoglobulins come in a later phase as they get older.

  • The highest serum half-life and serum concentration are IgG.

  • The least serum half-life and serum concentration are IgE.

  • The highest sedimentation coefficient is IgM.

IgE

  • Binds to mast cells → cross-linking upon allergen exposure → release of histamine (involved in allergic diseases).

  • Binds to basophils.

Option A: IgM has a maximum half-life of 23 days

  • The half-life of IgM is 5 to 6 days.

  • The largest antibody is located on the surface of mature B cells as a monomer and circulates as a pentamer (with a J chain).

  • Formed early (evidence of recent infection) as the first response to antigen contact.

  • Binds and activates complement.

  • The pentameric structure allows strong antigen binding while a humoral immune response is initiated.

Option C: IgG has a maximum sedimentation co-efficient of 19       

  • IgG has a maximum sedimentation coefficient of 7.

  • Most abundant immunoglobulin in blood serum.

  • Delayed formation during infection (IgM-IgG switch); ensures long‑term immunity; the main antibody in subsequent exposure.

  • Titer determination for follow-up: high affinity and specificity.

  • It can be free-floating in serum or bound to the surface of lymphocytes.

  • The only immunoglobulin that can cross the placenta and thus conveys transient passive immunity to the child.

  • Activates complement.

  • Opsonization of bacteria.

  • Neutralization of viruses and bacterial toxins.

Option D: IgD has a carbohydrate concentration of 8 %

  • The carbohydrate concentration in IgD is 13%.

  • Found in blood serum and on the surface of mature B lymphocytes.

  • The function is not entirely understood.

questions.text: An 11-year-old patient is brought to the outpatient clinic by his mother with the complaint of eczema, lung infections and recurrent cold. On examination, he has deep-set eyes, a broad nasal bridge, a prominent forehead, and coarse skin. The doctor ordered some blood tests that showed a high concentration of Ig E and eosinophils. Serum IgG, IgA, and IgM are normal. Which of the following statements is true regarding the given condition?

choices.text: There is early onset of eczema

questions.solution:
Option D: Also called Job's syndrome

  • The given scenario suggests Job's syndrome, also known as hyper Ig E syndrome or Buckley syndrome.It is a rare disorder of phagocytosis.
  • It is caused by mutations in the STAT3 gene (STAT3 is one of 7 human signal transducers and activators of transcription proteins, which are critical second messengers for many cytokines, hormones, and growth factor receptors.)
  • There is an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance, defect in T 17 cells.
  • As a result, helper T cells fail to produce gamma interferon.
  • It is characterized by the triad of:
    • Eosinophilia
    • Eczema
    • Recurrent skin (esp. recurrent cold Staphylococcal abscesses) and pulmonary infections.
  • Other clinical features include abnormal dentition, scoliosis, pneumatoceles, mild facial dysmorphia, and osteopenia.
  • Immunoglobulin levels:
  • The serum Ig E level is found to be extremely high.
  • Serum IgG, IgA, and IgM are typically normal.
  • Humoral and cellular immunity is not affected.
  • Management is antimicrobial drugs.

Option A: There is the late onset of eczema

  • There is early onset of eczema.

  • This disease is characterized by the presence of eczema.

Option B: Cellular immunity is affected

  • Cellular immunity is not affected.

  • An example of a cellular immunity-affected disorder is Di-George syndrome or severe combined immunodeficiency syndrome.

Option C: Humoral immunity is affected

  • Humoral immunity is not affected by Job's syndrome.

  • Examples of humoral immunity-affected disorders include common variable immunodeficiency and selective immunoglobulin A deficiency.

questions.text: A 52-year-old African female presents to the emergency department with a complaint of fever and an urticarial rash for the last three days. He also reports a mild dry cough. His examination reveals a blood pressure of 130/80 mmHg with a regular pulse rate of 75 beats per minute. She also has an enlarged liver and enlarged spleen. On chest auscultation, bronchospasm is noted. His stool examination is done, which demonstrates eggs with the lateral spine. Which of the following organism is likely to present in the patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Schistosoma mansoni

  • Key features in the scenario are fever, urticarial rash, enlarged liver and spleen, and bronchospasm suggestive of Schistosoma mansoni. The stool sample having eggs with lateral spine confirms the organism Schistosoma mansoni.
  • Eggs with a lateral spine are characteristic of Schistosoma mansoni.
  • Katayama fever is caused by Schistosoma mansoni.
  • Common in Africa, including Caribbean Islands (West Indies) and South America.
  • Resides in inferior mesenteric plexus.

Clinical manifestations:

  • Katayama fever is a manifestation of acute schistosomiasis.
  • Typical features include fever, an urticarial rash, enlarged liver and spleen, and bronchospasm.
  • Acute schistosomiasis (Katayama fever) Serum sickness-like illness: Type III hypersensitivity.
  • Swimmer’s itch (cercarial dermatitis): Type 1 hypersensitivity reaction.

Diagnostic form: Egg has a lateral spine (faeces); eggs of S. mansoni are acid-fast.

Option A: Fasciola Hepatica

  • It is a sheep liver fluke.
  • Mode of transmission: Ingestion of aquatic plant contaminated with encysted metacercaria.
  • Clinical manifestation: Hepatomegaly, halzoun (laryngeal oedema): due to eating sheep liver and bile duct obstruction.

Option B: Clonorchis sinensis

  • Also known as Asian/Chinese liver fluke.
  • Mode of transmission: Ingestion of freshwater fish contaminated with encysted metacercaria.
  • Causes: Cholangitis, dilatation of the bile duct and ductal epithelial hyperplasia, fibrosis, and cholangiocarcinoma.

Option D: Ascaris lumbricoides

  • Also known as roundworm and causes GIT symptoms, malabsorption, intussusceptions, and Loeffler syndrome.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male presents to the physician with complaints of stomach pain, bloody diarrhoea, and fever for 1 week. He has no history of any chronic illnesses. He is vitally stable, and a general physical examination reveals no abnormalities. On stool examination, iodine-stained cysts were seen. The clinical diagnosis of intestinal amoebiasis was made by the physician. Which of the following is true regarding the organism involved in the patient's pathology?

choices.text: Glycogen mass is present in the cytoplasm
It has 8 chromatid bodies in the cytoplasm

questions.solution:
Option B: Glycogen mass is present in the cytoplasm

  • This is a case of intestinal amoebiasis in which the patient presents with complaints of stomach pain, bloody diarrhoea, and fever for 1 week.
  • It is caused by Entamoeba histolytica.
  • Entamoeba histolytica Morphology:-3 stages:
    • Trophozoites
    • Pre-cyst
    • Cyst.

Cystic stage of E. histolytica (Refer to the image below):

  • Size and shape - 12-15 µm, spherical.
  • Cyst wall – highly refractive membrane.
  • Nucleus - Eccentric nucleus, mature cyst contains 4 nuclei.
  • Cytoplasm – 1-4 chromatid bodies, glycogen mass (stain brown with iodine), both gradually disappear as the cyst matures from uninucleate to quadrinucleate.
  • Chromatid body - Present in immature cysts, Thick bars with rounded ends.

  • The image below: Mature Cyst of Entamoeba coli in a stained wet mount preparation.

  • The image above: Trophozoite: Erythrophagocytosis (engulfed RBC inside trophozoites).

Option A: It is oval in shape

  • It is not oval in shape.
  • Size and shape of Entamoeba histolytica - 12-15 µm, spherical.

Option C: It has 8 chromatid bodies in the cytoplasm

  • Cytoplasm – 1-4 chromatid bodies, glycogen mass (stain brown with iodine), both gradually disappear as the cyst matures from uninucleate to quadrinucleate.

Option D: Ingested RBC are seen

  • Ingested RBC are seen in trophozoite.
  • It is not seen in cysts.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents with cellulitis two days after he is bitten by his cat. What is the most likely dominant organism involved in the infection?
questions.solution:
Pasteurella multocida is a dominant organism in the infection.

Option 1

Bartonella, is the causative agent of cat scratch fever and is less common in bites.

Features of Bartonella:

Can be cultured on normal culture media

  • B. bacilliformis → causes OROYA FEVER
  • B. henselae → caused Cat Scratch Disease and Bacillary Angiomatosis (common in HIV positive patients).

Bacillary Angiomatosis: Refer to the image below.

  • B. quintana → Causes TRENCH FEVER and Bacillary Angiomatosis (fewer cases).
Option 2

Calymmatobacterium granulomatis: causes a sexually transmitted infection, granuloma inguinale (or donovanosis).

  • Small,painless nodules appear after about 10–40 days of the contact with the bacteria.
  • Later, the nodules burst, creating open, fleshy, oozing lesions.
  • Site: Shaft of the penis, the labia, or the perineum
  • Diagnosis :Painless,"beefy-red ulcer" with a characteristic rolled edge of granulation tissue.
  • Wright Giemsa stain:Donovan bodies- rod-shaped, oval organisms that can be seen in the cytoplasm of mononuclear phagocytes or histiocytes in tissue samples.
Option 3

Pasteurella multocida is a dominant organism in Cat's mouth.
Option 4 Toxoplasma: associated with cats but transmitted by their faeces, not bites.

questions.text: On examination of the body of the 28-year-old actress, who had allegedly committed suicide by hanging, the forensic doctor noticed hypostasis (reddish-purple discolouration) in the hands, the feet, and around the genitalia of the victim. He documented the same as "Suggilation" which can also be documented as?
questions.solution:
Optio D: Postmortem staining

  • Postmortem Staining Synonyms: Livor Mortis, Hypostasis, lucidity, cogitation, vibices, suggilation, postmortem or cadaveric lividity, darkening of death.

Option A: Postmortem calorcity

  • Postmortem caloricity is a phenomenon where the body temperature of a corpse rises or remains unusually high for up to 2 hours after death instead of falling.

Option B: Rigor mortis

  • Rigor mortis (stiffness of death) is the state of the muscles in a dead body when they become stiff or rigid with some degree of shortening. It is a sign of death and indicates molecular death of the muscle involved.

Option C: Algor mortis

  • Algor mortis is the cooling of the body that normally takes place after death, where the body temperature equilibrates with its environmental temperature.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man has been arrested by the police on charges of stalking a female friend. In the complaint, she alleges that he had followed her home after office hours and had also been threatening to hurt her if she did not accept his marriage proposal. What does the law refer to as stalking if this was the man's first offence?
questions.solution:
Option A: Cognizable & bailable

  • Stalking involves following a woman or contacting such a woman despite clear disinterest or monitoring her through the internet, e-mail, or any other form of electronic communication.
  • It is punishable under Sec. 354-D IPC with imprisonment for up to 3 years and fine (cognizable and bailable) and imprisonment up to 5 years and fine for subsequent offence (cognizable and non-bailable).

Option B: Non-Cognizable & non-bailable

  • A non-cognizable offence is an offence listed under the first schedule of the Indian Penal Code and is bailable in nature.
  • But here, in this case, stalking a female is a cognizable offence.

Option C: Non-Cognizable & bailable

  • In the event of a non-cognizable offence, the police are prohibited from detaining the suspect without a warrant and from opening an inquiry without the court's approval.
  • But here, in this case, stalking a female is a cognizable offence.

Option D: Cognizable & non-bailable

  • Stalking a woman is punishable under Sec. 354-D IPC with imprisonment for up to 3 years and fine (cognizable and bailable) and imprisonment up to 5 years and fine for subsequent offence (cognizable and non-bailable).

questions.text: The doctor who had treated the victim for the gun shot injury was summoned with a Subpoena to testify in court with the relevant medical documentation. What category of the document does a subpoena fall under?
questions.solution:
Option A: Legal document

  • Subpoenas fall under the category of Legal documents.
  • The legal document compelling the attendance of a witness in a court of law, under penalty, on a particular day, time, and place to give evidence.

Option B: Medicolegal document

  • Medicolegal Reports: They are reports prepared by a doctor at the request of the investigating officer, usually in criminal cases, e.g., assault, rape, murder, etc.
  • The examination of an injured person or a dead body is made, when there is a requisition from a police officer or Magistrate.
  • Subpoenas do not fall under this category

Option C: Medical document

  • Medical records are legal records.
  • They include information of a medical, preventive, and social nature, as well as the information required for providing patients with the proper care.
  • Subpoenas do not fall under this category

Option D: First Investigation Report(FIR)

  • When the police learn of the commission of a crime that is punishable by law, they must create a First Information Report (FIR).
  • The First Information Report is a report of information that is received by the police first in time, for this reason.
  • Subpoenas do not fall under this category

questions.text: The act of Burking includes which one of the following methods?
questions.solution:
Option D: Traumatic asphyxia

  • Burking is a combination of homicidal smothering and traumatic asphyxia.

Option A: Choking

  • Choking is a form of asphyxia caused by an obstruction within the air passages by a foreign object, like a coin, fruit seed, toffees, candies, fish, or any other material.

Option B: Ligature

  • Ligature strangulation: When ligature material is used to compress the neck.
  • A ligature mark is a well-defined groove, which is slightly depressed and of the same width as that of ligature material. The groove may be narrow at parts due to the folding of the ligature.

Option C: Overlaying

  • Overlaying or compression suffocation results from compression of the chest, nose, and mouth, so as to prevent breathing.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman has  a stillbirth. During the 24th week of pregnancy, she experienced bleeding from the vagina associated with crampy abdominal pain. She had also not experienced fetal movement since. On examination, the obstetrician was unable to detect any fetal heart sounds. After delivery, the baby's body was sent for autopsy to determine the cause of death. Which part of the body will the doctor open first during the autopsy?
questions.solution:
Option C: Abdomen

  • The abdomen is opened first during the autopsy of a new-born.

Option A: Head

  • The purpose of conducting an autopsy on a newborn is to know whether the baby is live born or not.
  • The head should not be opened first, as it may cause death to the live child.

Option B: Heart 

  •  The heart should not be opened first, as it may cause death to the live child.

Option D: Back

  • The back should not be opened first, as it may cause spinal cord damage to the live child.

questions.text: The forensic dentist was invited to observe the dentition of a body that was excavated from the garden of a businessman. He has remained uncooperative during questioning. The forensic team has thus, decided to proceed with the investigations to gather evidence to file charges. The dentist has observed that all permanent teeth have erupted. The dentist would agree that all of the following statements are true of permanent dentition, except?

choices.text: They are ivory white in color

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Eruption starts with central incisor:

  • The eruption of permanent teeth usually begins with the first molars, specifically the lower first molars. This is followed by the central incisors.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Anterior teeth are inclined forward: Anterior (front) teeth, including incisors, are typically inclined forward, allowing for effective biting and cutting of food.

Option B - Roots of molars are larger: The molars, especially the permanent molars, tend to have larger and more complex root structures compared to other teeth.

Option D - They are ivory white in color: Permanent teeth are usually ivory white in color, although there can be variations in shade.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy, with normal growth and development, came to the OPD with a 14-day history of continuous involuntary jerky movements of the left half of his body, including the head. The patient was completely unvaccinated as informed by his mother. EEG revealed generalized slowing. Brain magnetic resonance imaging showed focal T2 hyperintensity in the right parasagittal cortex. The given condition is a complication of which of the following disease?
questions.solution:
Option A: Measles

  • The symptoms mentioned above point toward the complication of measles.
  • The most common complication of measles is Serous otitis media.
  • Subacute sclerosing pan encephalitis is a rare, late complication of measles - Aka ‘Dawson's disease’, Dawson’s encephalitis.

Option B: Mumps

  • The causative agent for mumps is Myxovirus parotitis.
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks. Cases are the source of infection in mumps.
  • The Mode of transmission is Respiratory/air droplets.
  • The most common complication of mumps is Aseptic meningitis.
  • Complications in children: Aseptic meningitis
  • Complications in Adolescents males: Orchitis, Adolescents Females: Oophoritis
  • Complications in Adults: Meningoencephalitis.

Option C: Rubella

  • The causative organism for rubella is RNA Togavirus.
  • The incubation period is 14-21 days. Cases are the source of infection in Rubella.
  • No carriers and no iceberg phenomenon are seen in Rubella.
  • The Mode of transmission is Respiratory/air droplets, vertical transmission from mother to child.

Option D: Chickenpox

  • Chickenpox is caused by HHV-3 [Varicella Zoster]
  • The incubation period of chickenpox is 14-16 days. Cases are the source of infection.
  • The mode of transmission of chickenpox is respiratory/ air droplets.
  • The period of communicability of Chickenpox is 1-2 days before the appearance of the rash till 5 days afterward.
  • The rash in chickenpox is superficial, unilocular, centripetal, and pleomorphic, showing a due drop in rose petal appearance affecting flexor aspects and axilla.
  • Late complication: Shingles by recrudescence.

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby with a 10-day history of choking spells presented to the OPD. The child's spells began with repetitive coughing and progressed to his turning red and gasping for breath. In the prior 2 days, he also had three episodes of vomiting in association with his choking spells. His physical examination was significant for a pulse of 160 beats per min and a respiratory rate of 72 per min. A nasopharyngeal swab confirmed B. Pertussis as the causative agent. Which of the following is false about this disease?

choices.text: There is no subclinical or chronic carriers state
Incidence and fatality are more common in males than in females
Erythromycin is the drug of choice

questions.solution:
ANSWER

Option C: Incidence and fatality are more common in males than in females

  • The above-given clinical features point toward the diagnosis of pertussis also called whooping cough or 100-day cough.
  • Incidence and fatality are more common in males than in females- False statement
  • Incidence and fatality are more common in females than males.

Other options

Option A: Incubation period is 7-14 days

  • True statement: The incubation period of pertussis is 7-14 days.

Option B: There is no subclinical or chronic carriers state

  • True statement: The disease pertussis does not show iceberg phenomena or subclinical or chronic carrier states.

Option D: Erythromycin is the drug of choice

  • True statement: The drug of choice for pertussis is Erythromycin.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male from a rural village presented to the hospital with a high fever, chills, muscle pain, rash, nausea, and vomiting for 5 days. Which of the following can best diagnose the given condition during the first week of infection?
questions.solution:
Option A: NS1 antigen detection

  • The above-given clinical features point towards the diagnosis of dengue.
  • Dengue caused by Group-B Arbovirus- D1, D2, D3, D4 (MC subtype - D1)
  • Diagnosis:
    • Clinically Seen 10 spots in Tourniquet test- Dengue fever; seen more than or equal to 20 spots seen in Dengue hemorrhagic fever.
    • Serologically- NS-1 Antigen Test comes positive even in 1st week.

Option B: Viral nucleic acid detection

  • Real-time RT-PCR and reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) assays may both identify the RNA-based dengue virus genome. Several RT-PCR tests for diagnosing dengue virus have been described in recent years. They have a considerably quicker turnaround time than virus isolation and offer superior specificity and sensitivity.

Option C: Both 

  • Only, Serologically- NS-1 Antigen Test comes positive even in 1st week.

Option D: None of the above

  • This is not the appropriate answer to the above-given question.

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with discoloured patches on skin, blister formation, numbness and weakness in hands and feet, loss of eyebrows and eyelashes. The physician sent the sample to the microbiology laboratory to find the causative agent. Which of the following culture medium is used to culture the causative organism?
questions.solution:
None of the above

  • Mycobacterium leprae has no artificial culture media.
  • Leprae bacilli are cultured by: Foot pad of mice and 9-banded armadillo.

Bordet Gengou medium

  • Bordet gengou medium: Bordetella Pertussis.

LJ medium

  • LJ medium: Mycobacterium Tuberculosis.

Loeffler’s serum slope

  • Loeffler’s serum slope: Corynebacterium Diphtheria.

Leprosy:

  • Oldest disease known.
  • Caused by Mycobacterium leprae.
  • Leprosy Elimination was achieved in India by 31st December 2005.
  • Elimination level for Leprosy is ‘<1/10,000’
  • Mode of transmission: Air droplets, skin contact, transplacental, breast feeding, insect bite, tattoo, corneal/organ transplantation.
  • Mycobacterium leprae has no artificial culture media.
  • Leprae bacilli are cultured by:
    • Foot pad of mice.
    • 9-banded armadillo.
  • Central Leprosy Training & Research Institute (CLTRI): Chengalpattu
  • National JALMA Institute for Leprosy: Agra

questions.text: A 30-year-old male truck driver visited the clinic with a fever, skin rash, swollen glands, and fatigue. The physician referred him to the Suraksha clinic. Which among the following is included in the provision of services at Suraksha Clinic?
questions.solution:
Option C: RTI/STI services

  • Suraksha clinic: Chain of RTI/STI clinics to provide reproductive and sexual health services.
  • Facilities: Blood sample testing; Counseling, and Syndromic case management (RTI/ STI/ RPR kits).

Option A: Immunization services

  • Immunization services are not included in the provision of services at Suraksha Clinic.

Option B: Blood transfusion safety services

  • Blood transfusion safety services are not included in the provision of services at Suraksha Clinic.

Option D: Diarrhea control services

  • Diarrhea control services are not included in the provision of services at Suraksha Clinic.

questions.text: A patient with complaints of high fever, runny nose, white spots inside the mouth, and skin rash, presented to the OPD. The clinical diagnosis of Measles was made by the physician. Which of the following age group is most commonly affected by measles?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option D: 6 months to 3 years

  • The age group most commonly affected by measles is 6 months to 3 years.
  • The clinical features of measles include 
    • Runny nose,
    • White spots inside the mouth
    • Skin rash
    •  High fever

Other options

Option A: 9 months to 3 years

  • Measles most frequently affects children between the ages of 6 months and 3 years.

Option B: 6 months to 2 years

  • Measles most frequently affects children between the ages of 6 months and 3 years.

Option C: 5-9 years 

  • Mumps is more frequent in this age group (5 to 9 years).
  • Measles most frequently affects children between the ages of 6 months and 3 years.

questions.text: Epidemiologic Triad, is a tool that scientists use for addressing the three components that contribute to the spread of disease. In the Advanced epidemiological triangle, Agent is replaced by which of the following?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option C: Causative factors

  • In the advanced epidemiological triad, the agent is replaced by causative factors. 
  • The advanced epidemiological triad is given below

Option A: Determinant risk factors

  • In the advanced epidemiological triad, the agent is replaced by causative factors (not determinant risk factors).

Option B: Causative bacterium/virus

  • The term causative factor is preferred over Causative bacterium/virus

Option D: Determinant factors

  • This is not included in the advanced epidemiological triad.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female diagnosed with anemia was given iron tablets. The physician recommended her not to consume Iron tablets along with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option C: Milk

  • Milk contains calcium which Inhibits the absorption of Iron by binding to Intestinal DMT-2 (Divalent Metal transporter-2).
  • Hence, iron tablets should never be taken with milk.

Option A: Water

  • Water does not decrease iron absorption.
