Option B: Lemon water

  • Vitamin C (ascorbic acid) is a facilitator of iron absorption.

Option D: All of the above

  • Only milk interferes with iron absorption.

questions.text: A female visited the hospital's gynecology department to undergo a permanent sterilization operation. All of the following are the eligibility criteria for female sterilization, except?

choices.text: The client's age should not be less than 22 years or more than 49 years
The client or her spouse must not have undergone sterilization in the past
At least two living children should be present

questions.solution:
Correct answer

Option D: At least two living children should be present

  • At least one living child should be present for the patient to undergo a sterilization procedure.

Other options

Option A: The client's age should not be less than 22 years or more than 49 years

  • The female undergoing sterilization should be 22-49 years of age.

Option B: The client should be married

  • The patient planned for sterilization should be married

Option C: The client or her spouse must not have undergone sterilization in the past

  • The client or her spouse must not have undergone any type of sterilization in the past.

questions.text: A 20-year-old boy consulted a physician regarding protection method to be used during sexual intercourse. The physician recommended condoms. Condoms are more preferred method in young adults because?
questions.solution:
They have no side effects

  • Utilizing condoms has no negative effects
Advantages Disadvantages
Easily available Slip or tear due to incorrect use
Safe and inexpensive Interference with sensation
Easy to use
No side effects
Light, compact, disposable
Prevents STI/HIV transmission

They have reduced failure rates / High pearl index

  • The male condoms have a failure rate of 2-4/HWY and female condoms have a failure rate of 5-21/HWY.

Learning Objective

  • Condoms are manufactured in India by Hindusthan Latex in Trivandrum, London Rubber Industries in Chennai, and others. Besides commercial outlets, condoms are supplied under social marketing programs.
  • Protect those adolescents, with occasional different sexual partners, against STD and AIDS. However. condoms must be properly used.
  • It depends on the man's behavior. Young men seem to be increasingly aware of the importance of safeguarding their own health and that of their partners. Cervical caps and diaphragms. on the other hand, are inappropriate for adolescents since they require foreseeing of intercourse and complicated manipulations, which young people loath.

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant female in her 1st trimester presented to the OPD with fever, chills, night sweats, swollen glands and fatigue. On serological examination she was found to be HIV positive. Which of the following is the Next line of management in this condition?

choices.text: Start ART now, continue throughout pregnancy and till 6 weeks after delivery
Start ART now, continue throughout pregnancy and till lifelong
Start ART after First trimester, continue throughout pregnancy and till 6 weeks after delivery
Start ART after First trimester, continue throughout pregnancy and till lifelong

questions.solution:
Start ART now, continue throughout pregnancy and till lifelong

Current guidelines:

  • ART should be started at any CD4 count
    • Any age
    • Any clinical staging
    • Any & all population
  • Preferred first line drugs in adults is Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Dolutegravir.
  • Newborn of HIV +ve mother should be given Zidovudine + Lamivudine + Raltegravir.
  • In HIV +ve pregnant female, start ART As soon as possible, throughout pregnancy & lifelong.
  • To prevent mother to child transmission of HIV, Nevirapine is Drug of choice.

Learning Objective

  • ART should be started at any CD4 count Any age, Any clinical staging, Any & all population.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the rural PHC with fever, stiffness in the neck, pain in legs, headache, and sore throat. The condition was diagnosed as poliomyelitis. Which of the following is an example of disability limitation in poliomyelitis?

choices.text: Reducing the occurrence of polio by immunization
Resting the affected limbs in neutral position

questions.solution:
Option C: Resting affected limbs in a neutral position

  • Resting limbs in a neutral position helps to prevent over-stretching of paralyzed muscles, thereby limiting further disability.
  • Its objective is to prevent or halt the transition of the disease process from impairment to handicapping.

Option A: Reducing the occurrence of polio by immunization

  • Immunization against disease is a primary level of prevention.
  • It is a protection against a specific disease.
  • It is not an example of disability limitation.

Option B: Early diagnosis 

  • Early diagnosis of poliomyelitis is a secondary level of prevention.
  • It is an action that halts the progress of the disease.

Option D: Providing calipers for walking

  • Providing calipers for walking is not an example of a disability limitation.
  • It is an example of rehabilitation.
  • Rehabilitation has been defined as the coordinated and combined use of social, medical, educational, and vocational measures for training the individual to the highest possible level of functional ability.

questions.text: 26 years old Ramesh, who is a painter visits the infertility clinic with his wife as they couldn’t conceive even after trying for the last 2 years. His semen analysis showed oligospermia. Which of the following metal can be obtained from his blood sample?
questions.solution:
Option B: Lead

  • In the given case scenario, as the person is working in the fuel industry, he would have occupational exposure to lead, which damages testes, resulting in oligospermia.
  • Thus, Lead can be obtained from his blood & urine samples.

Option A: Cadmium

  • It causes 'Itai - Itai' disease.
  • Teeth: Golden yellow staining.
  • Proximal tubular necrosis, emphysema, and anemia.
  • Osteomalacia, bone pain, and pathological fractures.

Option C: Mercury

  • In mercury poisoning, we can see black blue lines of gums, intentional tremors (hatters shaking palsy); erethism; acrodynia or pinks disease, mercuria lentis, minimata disease; membranous glomerulopathy.
  • TEST: If a piece of copper wire is introduced into the solution and a few drops of hydrochloric acid are added, a silver coating of mercury will be formed on the wire.

Option D: Nickle

  • The symptoms of nickel poisoning: Headache, Nausea, Vomiting, Dizziness, Irritability, and Difficulty Sleeping.
  • The second group of symptoms will become more severe after a few days: Chest Pains, Sweating, Rapid Heart Beat, and Dry Cough. These symptoms are similar to pneumonia but may be fatal in the case of nickel poisoning

questions.text: A 23-year-old sexual worker female presented to the hospital with rapid weight loss, fever, night sweats, sore throat and swollen lymph nodes. Blood reports confirmed the patient to be HIV positive. Which of the following is the most common opportunistic infection in AIDS worldwide?
questions.solution:
Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia

  • MC opportunistic infection in AIDS Worldwide is Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia (PCP).

Tuberculosis

  • MC opportunistic infection in AIDS in India is Tuberculosis (up to 40% co-infection).

Candida

  • MC opportunistic infection in AIDS in India is Tuberculosis (> Candida > PCP).

Histoplasmosis

  • Histoplasmosis is a type of lung infection.
  • It is caused by inhaling Histoplasma capsulatum fungal spores. These spores are found in soil and in the droppings of bats and birds.

Learning Objective

AIDS:

  • Caused by HIV (HTLV-III, Lymphadenopathy associated virus)
  • Mode of transmission - Sexual, blood, needle/syringes, vertical
  • Prevalence - 0.22%.
  • MC age group affected - 30-44yrs.
  • MC opportunistic infection in AIDS:
    • World: Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia.
    • India: Tuberculosis. (Upto 40% co-infection)

questions.text: A 22-month-old female child was reported to the hospital with a chief complaint of swelling on the left cheek region. There was a history of traumatic injury while eating sugarcane twenty-four hours back. On examination, extraoral swelling was present in the left cheek region. A clinical diagnosis of herniation of the buccal fat pad was made. The necrotic mass was surgically excised under local anesthesia, and healthy tissue was repositioned, followed by primary closure using a 4-0 vicryl suture, as shown in the image. Which of the following is related to this suture material?

choices.text: Tensile strength is maintained for 8-10 days

questions.solution:
Option C: Delayed absorbable suture

  • Vicryl(polyglactin) is also known as the work-horse suture of a general surgeon. 
  • Vicryl is a synthetic absorbable sterile surgical suture composed of a co-polymer made from 90% glycolide and 10% L-lactide. 
  • It retains tensile strength of about 70% and is maintained for 28-30 days, it completely absorbs within 56-70 days (delayed absorbable suture) by a simple hydrolytic mechanism, and its absorption is predictable. 
  • It is violet in color and used in organs with an increased risk of stone formation, such as the common bile duct, ureter, and bladder.

Option A: Tensile strength is maintained for 8-10 days

  • The tensile strength of Vicryl is maintained for 56-70 days, not for 8-10 days.

Option B: Co-polymer of glycolide and caprolactone

  • Vicryl is a co-polymer of glycolide and L-lactide, not caprolactone.

Option D: Used in Whipple's procedures

  • Vicryl is not used in Whipple's procedures.

questions.text: A patient after 1 month of getting vaccinated presented to the hospital with muscle weakness, difficulty in swallowing, and a pricking needle sensation in the hands and feet. The diagnosis of Guillain Barre syndrome was made by the physician. Which of the following vaccine is most likely to cause this reaction?
questions.solution:
Option D: Killed Influenza Vaccine

  • The adverse effects of killed influenza vaccine include:
    •  Anaphylaxis
    • Guillain barre syndrome
    • Oculo-respiratory syndrome.

Option A: Pertussis

  • Hypotensive, hyporesponsive episode following immunization is seen mainly with DTP, rarely with other vaccines.
  • In the DPT vaccine, the pertussis component is mainly responsible for Hypotensive hypo responsive episodes (HHRE).
  • It can also result in persistent inconsolable crying.

Option B: Measles

  • The measles vaccine can cause reactions such as TSS, and febrile seizures.
  • The vaccination Schedule consists of 2 doses, 1st dose at 9 months and 2nd dose at 16-24 months.

Option C: Hepatitis B

  • Adverse effects of the Hep B vaccine include hypersensitivity, and shock.
  • Hepatitis B vaccine in newborns: 3 doses- (6, 10, 14 weeks) if the child is delivered at home or (0, 6, 14 weeks) if the child is delivered at an institute(Dose: 0.5 ml each).
  • Hepatitis B vaccine schedule for adults: 0,1,6 months. (dose: 1 ml each).

questions.text: A 19-year-old male comes for a routine physical examination before playing for a college basketball team. He takes no medications and has no allergies. In his family history, his father and uncle died at around 40 from sudden cardiac death. However, his mother is healthy. On examination, his height is 195 cm, and his weight is 92 kg. He has pectus excavatum and arachnodactyly. A high-arched palate is present. He wears glasses for severe myopia and has had ectopia lentis on the right. A diastolic murmur is heard in the left third intercostal space. What will you advise him?

choices.text: He is not safe for further competitive basketball or other strenuous physical activities.
He is safe to resume physical activity without further evaluation.
He may continue to practice with the team while further evaluation with an echocardiogram, slit lamp examination, and genetic testing is performed.
He should be placed on a β-blocker and then can resume physical activity.

questions.solution:
Option A: He is not safe for further competitive basketball or other strenuous physical activities

  • Given clinical presentation is suggestive of Marfan syndrome.
  • Due to the high risk for Marfan related cardiovascular problems in this person it is not safe for further competitive basketball or other strenuous physical activities.
Skeletal Cardiovascular Others
  • Long limbs and tall stature
  • Upper segment: Lower segment <2 SD
  • Arachnodactyly: Long, slender fingers and hands
  • Pectus excavatum/pectus carinatum
  • Scoliosis
  • MVP
  • Dilatation of aortic root
  • Aortic regurgitation
  • Aortic aneurysm
  • Ectopia lentis
  • Spontaneous pneumothorax
  • Inguinal hernia
  • Diagnosis is based on the revised Ghent criteria: Major and minor criteria.
  • 4 major criteria
    • Ectopia lentis
    • Dilatation of ascending aorta with/without dissection
    • A blood relative who meets the same criteria
    • With/without DNA diagnosis
  • Further workup with echocardiogram and slit-lamp examination will be required in this patient.
  • The sudden death of the patient’s father is likely to represent an aortic aneurysm rupture.
  • Because this patient has several clinical features and a murmur concerning for Aortic regurgitation, an echocardiogram would not be required before removing him from further strenuous physical activity.

Option B: He is safe to resume physical activity without further evaluation.

  • A thorough evaluation is necessary before resuming physical activity.

Option C: He may continue to practice with the team while further evaluation with an echocardiogram, slit lamp examination, and genetic testing

  • Once any cardiovascular events have been excluded, physical activity can be resumed.

Option D: He should be placed on a β-blocker and then can resume physical activity.

  • A beta-blocker does not resolve cardiovascular problems.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the OPD with complaints of shortness of breath, swelling of legs, fatigue, palpitations, dizziness and episodes of fainting. He is a chronic alcoholic. On examination, a dicrotic pulse is found on palpation, and a pansystolic murmur is heard on auscultation. ECHO is done, and a diagnosis of Dilated Cardiomyopathy is made. The following procedure is done as a part of the treatment, whose image is shown below. Which of the following is this procedure?
questions.solution:
Option B: Cardiac resynchronisation therapy

  • The image shows the presence of Cardiac resynchronisation therapy (CRT) device with three leads seen in the colour blue.
  • The leads are touching the right atrium and right ventricular endocardial surface.
  • The third lead is placed on the left side of the heart via the coronary sinus.
  • The procedure known as Cardiac Resynchronization Therapy, or CRT, is intended to assist your heart in beating at the appropriate rhythm. A pacemaker is utilised in order to bring back the regular timing pattern of the patient's heartbeat.
  • The timing of the contractions of both the upper heart chambers (atria) and the lower heart chambers is regulated by the CRT pacemaker. In addition to this, it adjusts the timing of the contractions of the left and right sides of the heart.
  • It's possible for fluid to collect in the lungs and legs if the heart isn't pumping blood around the body strong enough. This condition is known as heart failure. This problem can occur if the two lower chambers (ventricles) of your heart do not beat at the same time. In order to treat this condition, Cardiac Resynchronization Therapy (CRT) is used.

Option A: Implantable cardioverter defibrillator

  • The implantable cardioverter defibrillator is ruled out as it has two leads, while this image has 3 leads.
  • It is the treatment of choice if there is a family history of sudden cardiac death and left ventricular free wall thickness is greater than 30 mm.

Option C: Dual pacing

  • Dual pacing has two leads, while the one on the image has three leads.

Option D: Trans-venous pacemaker

  • The transvenous pacemaker is placed in the internal jugular vein and subclavian vein. The image shows the leads touching the right atrium, right ventricular endocardial surface, and on the left side of the heart via the coronary sinus.

questions.text: Investigation of choice in COPD?
questions.solution:
Option B: Spirometry

  • The main test for COPD is spirometry.
  • Spirometry can detect COPD before symptoms are recognized.
  • Spirometry is a type of lung function test that measures how much air you breathe out.

Other options

Option A: Chest X ray

  • This option is incorrect.

Option C: CT Chest

  • This option is incorrect.

Option D: MRI

  • This option is incorrect.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension comes to the office for a routine follow-up. She has occasional numbness in her feet. The patient takes ibuprofen for chronic back pain along with hydrochlorothiazide and metformin. Urinalysis shows albuminuria. Lisinopril therapy is initiated. The next day, the patient returns due to lightheadedness and near-syncope. Her blood pressure is 80/45 mm Hg. Which of the following is most likely the major factor contributing to this patient's current symptoms?
questions.solution:
Option D: Diuretic therapy

  • This patient with albuminuria was started on an ACE inhibitor for the treatment of early diabetic nephropathy.
  • Although most patients remain asymptomatic with only a mild reduction in blood pressure, first-dose hypotension can be a potential limiting factor when initiating ACE inhibitors.
  • Significant hypotension is most likely to occur in patients with high plasma renin activity, such as those with volume depletion (e.g., from diuretic use [hydrochlorothiazide in this patient]) or heart failure.
  • To prevent the development of first-dose hypotension, therapy should be started at low doses and slowly titrated upward as needed.

Other options

Option A: Autonomic neuropathy

  • Long-term diabetes can cause diabetic neuropathy, which can progress to involve the autonomic nerves in advanced cases.
  • One of the first symptoms of autonomic neuropathy is orthostatic hypotension. This patient is already on a diuretic and develops hypotension after starting an ACEI making drug interaction a more likely cause.

Option B: NSAID use

  • NSAID use has been known to cause hypertension and not hypotension, as is the case in our patient.

Option C: Diabetic nephropathy

  • Long-term diabetes can cause microvascular injury in the kidneys leading to protein loss in the urine. This will eventually develop into end-stage renal disease. (ESRD)
  • A patient with ESRD will have hypertension as a symptom and not hypotension.

questions.text: A 30-year-old nurse is evaluated for recurrent hypoglycemia. She feels shaky, anxious, and sweaty; her plasma glucose is 45 mg/dl during the attack at work. She then drinks coffee and feels better. These episodes have not happened outside the work environment. She takes no medications and is otherwise healthy. Which of the following is the most appropriate test for this patient to evaluate the cause of her hypoglycemia?

choices.text: Measurement of fasting insulin and glucose levels
Measurement of fasting insulin, glucose, and C-peptide levels
Measurement of insulin, glucose, and C-peptide levels during a symptomatic episode

questions.solution:
Option D: Measurement of insulin, glucose, and C-peptide levels during a symptomatic episode

  • A low blood glucose level is known as hypoglycemia.
  • Symptoms usually develop when blood glucose falls below 50mg/dL.
  • It happens due to an imbalance between glucagon and insulin.
  • The primary organ affected by hypoglycemia is the brain, which uses glucose as the primary energy source.
  • Hypoglycemia leads to:
    • Sympathetic activation causes palpitations, diaphoresis, anxiety, high blood pressure, and tremors.
    • Neuroglycopenic symptoms include lethargy, headache, visual disturbances, confusion, seizures, and coma.
    • Whipple’s triad can be seen, which includes;
      • Low blood glucose (<50mg/dl)
      • Symptoms of hypoglycemia,
      • Relief of symptoms after normalization of plasma glucose levels.
  • Causes of hypoglycemia include
    • Drug-induced (too much insulin or sulfonylurea intake)
    • Sactitious hypoglycemia (surreptitious intake of insulin)
    • Insulinoma, ethanol ingestion
    • Postoperative complications after gastric surgery(dumping syndrome), reactive hypoglycemia, adrenal insufficiency, liver failure, or disorders of carbohydrate metabolism.
  • Diagnosis is usually made by checking blood glucose levels.
  • Laboratory testing of serum insulin, c-peptide, and glucose levels during an episode may help find the aetiology of hypoglycemia.
    • If the insulin level is elevated during an episode, it suggests endogenous overproduction of insulin or exogenous insulin administration, causing factitious hypoglycemia.
    • Serum C-peptide levels
      • Determine the amount of insulin produced by cleavage from its precursors in the pancreas.
      • Insulin is synthesized in the rough endoplasmic reticulum of the pancreatic beta cells as proinsulin, stored in secretory granules.
      • Cleavage of proinsulin yields insulin and c-peptide, which are released by endocytosis.
      • High C-peptide levels with low glucose levels suggest either the presence of insulinoma or surreptitious intake of sulfonylureas.
      • Normal c-peptide levels with hypoglycemia suggest surreptitious insulin intake. Low C-peptide levels and hyperglycemia will indicate pancreatic failure.

The patient in the scenario above is a healthcare worker, and her symptoms develop only at work, so that it may be a case of surreptitious insulin intake.

Diagnosis

Insulin Levels

Glucose Levels

C-peptide levels

Proinsulin levels

Insulinoma
  • High
  • Low
  • High
  • High

Factitious insulin
  • Very high
  • Low
  • Low
  • Low

Sulfonylurea abuse
  • High
  • Low
  • High
  • Normal

Option A: Measurement of IGF-1

  • Insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) is synthesized in the liver in response to growth hormone. It has no significance in determining the cause of hypoglycemia in a patient.

Option B: Measurement of fasting insulin and glucose levels

  • Measurement of fasting insulin and glucose levels are used to diagnose a case of insulinoma (if suspected). Serum insulin levels will be high, and blood glucose levels will be low in an insulinoma.

Option C: Measurement of insulin, glucose and c-peptide levels

  • Measurement of serum insulin, glucose and c-peptide levels should be done during a symptomatic hypoglycemic episode to determine the cause of hypoglycemia.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient met with a road traffic accident & is brought to the emergency department in an unconscious state. His blood pressure is 85/60 mmHg, and pulse is 120 beats per minute. CT abdomen reveals a splenic laceration. An emergency splenectomy is performed, and the patient is shifted to Intensive Care. His blood pressure remains low in the postoperative period, even after the continuation of normal saline fluids. On examination, he is afebrile. He has hyperpigmentation of oral mucosa and darkness of the skin of the face and lower extremities. Repeat CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis shows no haemorrhage. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Return to the operating room for exploratory laparotomy
Perform an MRI of the spine.

questions.solution:
Option B: Administer Hydrocortisone 100 mg IV

  • The patient is suffering from an acute adrenal crisis after a physiological stressor, such as surgery.
  • Adrenal Crisis is a condition where the adrenal gland cannot meet the physiological needs of the body to produce excess amounts of cortisol in the period of stress.
  • The patient also has hyperpigmentation of the skin, which shows the underlying primary adrenal insufficiency as the predisposing factor for the disease.
  • A physiologic stressor (trauma or surgery) may trigger an adrenal crisis in patients with primary adrenal insufficiency
  • Acute adrenal insufficiency requires immediate initiation of rehydration (saline infusion at initial rates of 1 L/hr) with continuous cardiac monitoring.
  • Glucocorticoid replacement- initiated by bolus injection of 100 mg of hydrocortisone, followed by the administration of 100–200 mg of hydrocortisone over 24 hours.
  • Mineralocorticoid replacement can be initiated once the daily hydrocortisone dose is <50 mg, as at higher doses, hydrocortisone provides sufficient stimulation of mineralocorticoid receptors.

Option A: Return to the operating room for exploratory laparotomy

  • The patient is in the postoperative period, and he is suffering from an acute adrenal crisis.
  • The blood pressure is low due to adrenal insufficiency in this patient.
  • The CT scan reveals no intra-abdominal haemorrhage.
  • Therefore, repeat exploratory laparotomy is not indicated in this patient

Option C: Administer vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam

  • The patient is afebrile and there is no other symptom of infection present in the patient.
  • The hypotension is present due to adrenal insufficiency and not due to any sepsis. Therefore, antibiotics are not required.

Option D: Perform an MRI of the Spine

  • MRI of the spine is not indicated in this patient as the patient has no symptoms of backache.
  • He does not have a fever and no sign of a paraspinal abscess.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman who is a known case of hypothyroidism and is taking treatment for the same is diagnosed with endometrial fibroids and started on iron recently. She reports excessive fatigue and constipation in her follow-up visit. Her Blood pressure and cholesterol levels have been stable. A TSH is checked, and it is found to be elevated. What is the most likely cause of her elevated TSH?

choices.text: Poor absorption of levothyroxine due to ferrous sulfate

questions.solution:
Option D: Poor absorption of levothyroxine due to ferrous sulfate

  • Levothyroxine (T4) should not be taken with other medications that interfere with absorption.
  • It is prudent to separate the administration of these drugs and T4 by several hours.
  • The bile acid-binding resins used in the treatment of hypercholesterolemia, cholestyramine and colestipol, and colesevelam bind thyroid hormones and decrease their absorption.
  • In euthyroid patients without thyroid disease, the administration of these resins has no adverse effects.
  • However, hypothyroidism may occur in the following situations:
    The concomitant administration of bile acid-binding resins and T4 in patients with hypothyroidism.
    If both are required, T4 should not be taken until several hours after administration of the bile acid-binding resin.
    Although not yet reported in the literature, euthyroid patients with limited thyroid reserve due to subclinical thyroid disease or treatment with radioactive iodine would also seem at risk for developing hypothyroidism during treatment with bile acid-binding resins.
    Normal gastric acid secretion appears to be necessary for normal thyroid hormone absorption.
    Omeprazole, lansoprazole, and presumably other medications that reduce gastric acid secretion may interfere with thyroid hormone absorption.
  • Calcium carbonate also reduces the absorption of exogenous T4.
  • Raloxifene or ciprofloxacin administered simultaneously as T4 (levothyroxine) reproducibly interfered with the absorption of T4.
  • Sucralfate, ferrous sulfate, and aluminium hydroxide can also bind T4 in the gut, but their effect is negligible and less consistent than those described above.
  • Sevelamer, lanthanum carbonate, and chromium have reduced T4 absorption.
     

Option A: Celiac disease

  • Celiac disease affects the absorption of iron.
  • Moreover, it is rare at the age of 50.
  • Celiac disease presents with chronic diarrhoea and iron deficiency anaemia.
     

Option B: Colon cancer

  • Levothyroxin is not absorbed in the large intestine.
  • Therefore, colon cancer does not affect the levothyroxine level.


Option C: Medication non-compliance

  • Medication non-compliance would result in increased symptoms of hypothyroidism.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man comes to OPD with complaints of headache with some visual disturbance for the past six months. He also complains of decreased libido, excessive sweating and weight gain to the extent that his rings and shoes don't fit him anymore. What will be the most appropriate screening test for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: Serum IGF-1

  • The case described above is Acromegaly characterized by weight gain, sweating and especially acral enlargement hand and feet (shoes and ring doesn't fit him)
  • Age-matched serum IGF-I levels are elevated in Acromegaly. Consequently, an IGF-I level provides a useful laboratory screening measure when clinical features raise the possibility of Acromegaly.
  • The diagnosis of Acromegaly is then confirmed by demonstrating the failure of GH suppression to <0.4 μg/L within 1–2 h of an oral glucose load (75 g). When newer ultrasensitive GH assays are used, normal nadir GH levels are even lower (<0.05 μg/L. Oral glucose tolerance test)
  • Owing to the pulsatility of GH secretion, measurement of a single random GH level is not useful for diagnosing or excluding Acromegaly and does not correlate with disease severity.
  • IGF-2 is responsible for prenatal growth.
  • An oral glucose tolerance test with GH was obtained at 0, 30 and 60 minutes. Normal people can suppress growth hormone to <1g/L.

Option A: Serum IGF-2

  • IGF-2 is responsible for prenatal growth, so it will not be useful for diagnosing Acromegaly.

Option B: Oral glucose tolerance test

  • An oral glucose tolerance test is used when the IGF 1 levels are checked and returned as raised.
  • It is a confirmation test, but first-line screening is by checking IGF 1 status after overnight fasting.

Option C: GH levels

  • Checking single random GH levels in the body is not useful because of the pulsatility of GH levels in the body at different times

questions.text: While processing a patient's blood sample for serum electrolytes, Serum Na+ is found to be 130 mEq/L, and serum osmolality is found to be 290 mOsm/kg. After a thorough assessment, a diagnosis of pseudo hyponatremia is made. Which of the following condition can lead to Pseudohyponatremia?
questions.solution:
Option A: Multiple myeloma

  • Hyponatremia, a plasma Na+ concentration <135 mEq/L, is a very common disorder in upto 22% of hospitalized patients.
  • Hyperlipidemia or hyperproteinemia reduces the water content of a given volume of plasma.
  • Although the sodium concentration in the water phase is not affected, the sodium concentration per plasma unit is reduced.
  • If the analyzer measures sodium concentration per volume of plasma, the measurement will be reduced.
  • However, this error does not affect analyzers that directly measure the sodium concentration in the water phase of plasma. Serum osmolality measurements are also not affected by this artefact. This laboratory artefact is called pseudo hyponatraemia.
  • Pseudohyponatremia can occur in patients with myeloma with severe hyperproteinemia (usually greater than 10 g/dL).
  • In addition to the reduction in plasma water content caused by a high protein concentration, monoclonal proteins may artefactually lower the sodium concentration measured by volume-sensitive devices because of hyperviscosity and other factors that interfere with a proper dilution of the plasma sample.

Option B: SIADH

  • SIADH results in Euvolemic hyponatremia with urine sodium of more than 20 mEq/L and urine osmolality of more than 100 mOsm/kg.
  • This contrasts with psychogenic polydipsia, which leads to urine sodium less than 20 mEq/L and urine osmolality less than 100 mOsm/L.

Option C: Cerebral salt wasting syndrome

  • Cerebral salt wasting leads to Hypovolemic hyponatremia with more than 20 mEq/L urine sodium.

Option D: Rapid correction of hypernatremia

  • Rapid correction of hypernatremia does not result in pseduohyponatremia.
  • Rather it can lead to brain oedema, which may raise the ICP and leads to brain herniation.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents to the outpatient department with the complaint of Headache, drowsiness, and palpitations. On examination, his blood pressure is 160/110 mm Hg, and his pulse is 86 beats/min. ECG shows flattened T waves. Serum electrolytes reveal K+ = 2.9 mEq/L, Bicarbonate = 34 mEq/L, also there is decreased aldosterone. A diagnosis of Hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with severe hypertension has been made. Which of the following is the likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: Liddle syndrome

Liddle syndrome:

  • Autosomal dominant, gain-in-function mutations of ENaC subunits.
  • Activating kidneys to excrete potassium retaining excessive sodium & water, leading to hypertension.
  • ↓ Aldosterone and Hypokalemia with hypertension is a characteristic feature of Liddle syndrome.

Option B: Bartter syndrome

  • Primary defect at Na/K/Cl channel at the Ascending loop of henle.
  • Benign condition
  • May cause hypokalemia, acidosis and hypercalciuria.

Option C: Gitelman syndrome

  • Milder form of bartter syndrome.
  • Defect is at Na/Cl cotransporter at DCT
  • Presents with hypercalciuria.

Option D: Renal tubular acidosis

  • Renal tubular disorders are a heterogeneous group of diseases that involve dysfunctions of transporters and channels in the renal tubular system.
  • These dysfunctions may cause fluid loss and abnormalities in electrolyte and acid-base homeostasis.
  • The disorders are either primary (genetic) or acquired (e.g., drug adverse effects, renal disease).
  • In renal tubular acidosis (RTA), there is normal anion gap (hyperchloremic) metabolic acidosis in a patient with normal or almost normal renal function.
  • Types of RTA include distal tubular acid secretion (type 1), proximal tubular bicarbonate wasting (type 2), very rarely carbonic anhydrase deficiency (type III), and aldosterone deficiency/resistance (type 4).

questions.text: A 50 years male met with an accident and was brought to the emergency. O/E - BP = 100/70 mm Hg, Pulse= 96 bpm. X-ray Hip showed a bilateral Pelvic fracture. The patient's vitals are deteriorating, and he is suspected of developing Hypovolemic shock. The treating doctor advises transfusing 3 units of PRBC. The transfusion is started, but after 20 mins, the blood is found incompatible. Acute renal failure in this patient who received an incompatible blood transfusion with hemolytic reaction is best managed by:
questions.solution:
Option D: Stopping blood transfusion

  • Stop the transfusion immediately
  • Microvascular thrombosis and deposition of haemoglobin in the distal renal tubule can result in acute renal failure.
  • The extent of precipitation is inversely related to urine flow. I.V. fluids, vasopressors and diuretics should be given to maintain renal perfusion pressure and to produce diuresis.
  • If acute renal failure develops, haemofiltration should be considered.

Option A: 20% Mannitol

  • Mannitol can be used to cause diuresis and the excretion of toxins, but the first appropriate step will be stopping the transfusion

Option B: IV fluids with K+ supplementation

  • In hemolytic reaction, cells are lysed, and intracellular potassium is released, which causes hyperkalemia. Since there is already increased potassium, there is no point in its infusion

Option C: Alkalinizing the urine

  • Alkalinise the urine with IV sodium bicarbonate to keep haemoglobin soluble and reduce kidney tubular damage. Alkalization is monitored by urinary pH, which should be maintained greater than 6.5 or 7. But 1st step will be stopping the transfusion

questions.text: A 34-year-old female with a medical history of SLE, lupus nephritis, protein S deficiency, and recurrent DVT complained of pain associated with nausea, vomiting, and unintentional weight loss. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) was performed; however, the mucosal tear was noted following severe retching. Subsequently, the procedure was terminated. EGD was significant for distal oesophageal obstruction. On further workup, imaging modality showed compression of the posterior part of the oesophagus by the aberrant right subclavian artery. Which of the following would have been used as an investigation of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
Option C: CT angiography

  • The above clinical history & findings lead to the diagnosis of Dysphagia lusoria.
  • Dysphagia lusoria is a condition of the oesophagus constriction due to vascular abnormalities. The vascular anomaly is usually an aberrant right subclavian artery. The abnormal vessels constricting the oesophagus can cause dysphagia in early childhood or later life.
  • Most patients with dysphagia lusoria do not need any treatment. However, surgery can be performed considering the risks and benefits. CT angiography is the investigation of choice to establish the diagnosis of dysphagia lusoria.

Option A: Barium studies.

  • Barium study of the oesophagus may show the indentation on the posterior oesophageal wall by the artery. Still, it cannot opt as the investigation of choice for dysphagia lusoria.

Option B: Chest X-ray

  • A chest x-ray can demonstrate enlargement of the superior mediastinum. However, it cannot opt as the investigation of choice for dysphagia lusoria.

Options D: Oesophageal manometry

  • Oesophageal manometry can also not be opted as the investigation of choice for dysphagia lusoria as it is unable to show the vascular anomalies leading to dysphagia.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presented to the clinic with chronic complaints of burning sensation and discomfort over the epigastrium. He has a duodenal ulcer and H. pylori infection on endoscopy and biopsy. He has been prescribed proton pump inhibitors (PPI) & advised to follow up. Which of the following is a side effect of prolonged intake of PPI?
questions.solution:
Option A: Decreasing the effect of clopidogrel

  • Clopidogrel, an inactive prodrug, is converted to a thiolactone intermediate and then to an active metabolite that binds irreversibly to ADP receptors on the platelet surface.

  • Multiple cytochrome (CYP) enzymes catalyze these two stages, with CYP2C19 playing an essential role in both.

  • As with most CYP enzymes, CYP2C19 activity can be altered by other medicines, and CYP2C19 inhibitors can theoretically reduce clopidogrel's antiplatelet efficacy by interfering with its bioactivation.

  • PPIs' competitive suppression of CYP2C19 is the theoretical basis for their interaction with clopidogrel.

Option B: Wrist fracture

  • The incidence of all fractures, severe osteoporotic fractures, hip fractures, vertebral fractures, and other fractures rose with PPI usage, but not the risk of wrist and humerus fractures.

  • The risk of any fractures, major osteoporotic fractures, and other fractures increased for PPI adherence when the proportion of days covered (PDC) was less than 0.80.

Option C: Eradication of Clostridium difficile infection

  • PPIs significantly reduce the amount of stomach acid produced, which promotes spores' growth and capacity to transform into a vegetative form of C. difficile.

  • PPIs also hinder leukocyte activity by preventing phagocytosis and acidifying the phagolysosome.

Option D: Decreased risk of community-acquired pneumonia

  • Proton pump inhibitors are associated with an increased, not decreased, risk of community-acquired pneumonia (CAP).

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented with a skin lesion in his right axilla. A presumptive diagnosis of staphylococcal skin carbuncle is made & the patient is treated with empiric sulfamethoxazole. After 2 days, the patient comes to an emergency with excessive weakness, abdominal pain & dark-coloured urine. On physical examination, his vitals are normal & jaundice is present. Lab studies show a drop in Hb from 14 g/dl to 8 g/dl & significant rise in bilirubin levels. The urine dipstick is positive for bilirubin. His peripheral blood smear is shown below. What may be the possible diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Glucose 6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency

G6PD deficiency:

  • It is an x-linked recessive disorder due to the deficiency of the G6PD enzyme.
  • G6PD neutralises free radical-induced damage inside RBC.
  • Its deficiency leads to unopposed oxidative stress → intravascular hemolysis → hemoglobinemia, hemoglobinuria / black urine → acute tubular necrosis → death.
  • There are three types of triggers for oxidative damage to RBC:
  1. Fava beans
  2. Infections and
  3. Drugs (sulfa drugs, quinine, quinidine, NSAID, antibiotics such as nitrofurantoin, quinolone).
  • PBF shows bite cells, anisocytosis, and spherocytes with jaundice after receiving sulfamethoxazole, which diagnoses glucose 6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency.
  • Bite cells are formed due to the splenic removal of abnormal haemoglobin aggregates. (Heinz bodies)

Option B: Hemolytic-uremic syndrome

  • Hemolytic-uremic syndrome causes a microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia with prominent schistocytes.

Option C: Hereditary spherocytosis

  • It causes normocytic normochromic anaemia.

Option D: Iron deficiency anaemia

  • Iron deficiency causes microcytic and hypochromic anaemia.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents to the emergency department due to sudden, constant vertigo for the last 2 hours. It is associated with nausea, postural instability, and inability to walk. He has had a history of hypertension for 20 years. On physical examination, the patient has no problem with the fixation of the eyes when the examiner rotates his head. Left beating nystagmus on the left lateral gaze and right beating nystagmus on the right lateral gaze is seen along with skew deviation with quick vertical movements as the examiner uncovers each eye. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Cerebellar infarction

  • The examiner tested the patient’s head impulse test.
  • The head impulse test is tested as follows:
    • The examiner briskly rotates the patient’s head while having the patient fixate on his nose or some target.
    • The vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR) can match the velocity of the head in healthy individuals.
    • Due to vestibulopathy on the side to which the head is quickly rotated, the eyes lag during the quick head movement, fixation is lost, and a corrective saccade back to the target occurs.
  • Losing focus indicates a positive head impulse test.
  • The head impulse test is positive in conditions with peripheral vertigo. These include:
    • Meniere's disease
    • Vestibular neuritis
    • BPPV
  • The patient did not lose focus indicating a negative head impulse test.
  • The head impulse test is negative in conditions with central vertigo (cerebellar infarction in the question).

Option A: Meniere’s disease

  • Meniere’s disease presents with peripheral vertigo.
  • Head impulse test is positive for Meniere's disease.

Option C: Vestibular neuritis

  • Vestibular neuritis is a cause of peripheral vertigo.
  • Head impulse test is positive in cases of vestibular neuritis.

Option D: Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV)

  • BPPV is an example of peripheral vertigo.
  • Head impulse test is positive in BPPV.

questions.text: A 25-year-old college student is brought to the emergency department by police. The patient was found unresponsive at a party. Police report that the party involved drugs and the student is suspected of snorting cocaine. Medical history includes tobacco, alcohol and illicit drug abuse. His temperature is 36.5°C (99.5°F), his blood pressure is 200/100 mmHg, his pulse is 65 beats/min, and his respirations are 6 breaths/min. His GCS is 7/15. Neurological examination reveals a dilated right pupil that reacts sluggishly to light. Which of the following is not recommended for this patient?

choices.text: Administer hypertonic fluids to maintain sodium of 145mEq/dl
Initiate sodium nitroprusside to achieve mean arterial pressure below 130 mmHg

questions.solution:
Option C: Initiate sodium nitroprusside to achieve mean arterial pressure below 130 mmHg

  • The patient likely suffers from an intracranial haemorrhage from a cocaine overdose. 
  • Intracranial haemorrhage can cause a significant mass effect, which may increase intracranial pressure.
  • The increased intracranial pressure can begin a triad known as the Cushing triad. The Cushing triad comprises bradycardia, hypertension, and bradypnea. 
  • An increase in intracranial pressure can also lead to brain herniation. Progressive brain herniation can cause pupil abnormalities.
  • Uncal herniation can compress the ipsilateral oculomotor nerve as it exits the midbrain, resulting in a fixed, dilated pupil. This patient has a dilated right pupil, which depicts uncal herniation.

  • Sodium nitroprusside is not recommended to manage a hypertensive crisis in an intracerebral haemorrhage. 
  • The metabolism of sodium nitroprusside, which occurs in the red blood cell, liberates cyanide that can accumulate in those receiving high doses or prolonged infusions.
  • Cyanide causes blockage of the electron transport chain resulting in impaired oxygen utilisation.
  • This can lead to cardiovascular collapse and neurologic dysfunction.
  • The current guidelines recommend using nicardipine or labetalol to reduce blood pressure in a hypertensive crisis.

Option A: Administer mannitol at 1g/kg body weight

  • Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic used to lower raised intracranial pressure. 
  • Lowering raised intracranial pressure helps prevent or reduce the effects of brain herniation

Option B: Administer hypertonic fluids to maintain sodium of 145mEq/dl

  • 3% hypertonic saline can also be used to lower intracranial pressure. 

Option D: Neuromuscular paralysis

  • Neuromuscular paralysis is a useful method to reduce intracranial pressure.
  • This patient has a GCS of 7; airway compromise is always present in a GCS of less than 8. 
  • Therefore, neuromuscular paralysis and intubation are to be done to protect respiratory function.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male comes to the neurology department with proximal muscle weakness. The patient is also affected by respiratory difficulty. He has been drinking since he was 25 years of age. The patient is non-diabetic and non-hypertensive. His blood pressure is 135/90 mmHg, and his pulse is 65/min. Physical examination reveals the drooping of eyelids. Lab value suggests antibodies against postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors. Which of the following statement is mostly associated with this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Muscle movement worsen with exercise

  • This patient suffers from proximal muscle weakness, drooping eyelids and postsynaptic receptor antibodies, diagnosed with myasthenia gravis.
  • Myasthenia gravis is a most common neuromuscular junction disorder.
  • In myasthenia gravis, antibodies are present against the postsynaptic Acetylcholine receptors. It results in decreased postsynaptic receptor activation and depressed muscle contraction.
  • The symptoms worsen with muscle usage.
  • Acetylcholine esterase inhibitor reverses the symptoms.

Option A: Muscle movement increases with exercise

  • Autoantibodies against presynaptic voltage-gated Ca2+ channels characterise Eaton-Lambert syndrome.
  • Clinical manifestations are
    • Proximal muscle weakness
    • And autonomic dysfunction (constipation, dry mouth)
    • Absent deep tendon reflexes.
  • Dysphagia and dysarthria also are seen.
  • Ocular symptoms are ptosis and diplopia due to CN involvement
  • Repeated electrical stimulation enhances muscle power due to incremental response
  • It is associated with small cell carcinoma of the lung.

Option C: Ascending muscle paralysis

  • Guillain-Barre Syndrome is an autoimmune condition that destroys Schwann cells by inflammation and demyelination of motor fibres, sensory fibres and peripheral nerves.
  • It is characterised by the following;
  • Ascending muscle paralysis
  • Decrease deep tendon reflexes 
  • Facial paralysis
  • Respiratory failure
  • It is associated with respiratory infections (viral infections like Zika) or gastrointestinal infections (campylobacter jejuni).
  • Other abnormalities are also present, like sensory deficit, cardiac abnormalities, hypertension or hypotension.
  • Labs show an increase in CSF protein with normal cell count.
  • Dx - lumbar puncture:
    • Cells - Normal
    • Sugar - Normal
    • Colour – Normal
    • Proteins ↑
  • Respiratory support is mainly needed in such patients.
  • Rx - IV Immunoglobulins.

Option D: A specific rash pattern is present

  • Dermatomyositis presents with symmetrical proximal muscle weakness.
  • It mainly involves the shoulder muscles and pelvic muscles.
  • Pelvic girdle muscles are more involved than upper body muscles and result in difficulty for:
    • Walking up the stairs 
    • Lifting from the seat
    • Doing overhead arm movements
  • The perimysial inflammation characterises it on biopsy with CD4+ T cells.
  • Clinically it is similar to polymyositis, but the early rash features recognise it:
    • Gottron papules (red scaly papules on hand)
    • Heliotrope oedema of eyelids and Facial erythema
    • Shawl and face rash.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female came to the hospital. She was undergoing treatment for SLE and came for a follow-up. A urine lab test was taken on lab investigation. There is proteinuria. You suspect renal involvement, for which a biopsy was done, which shows a wire loop appearance without glomerular proliferation. What is this class of lupus nephritis called?
questions.solution:
Option A: Diffuse nephritis

Diffuse lupus nephritis (class IV):

It is the commonest and most severe form of lupus nephritis.

  • Class IV lupus nephritis is defined as involving 50% or more of the glomeruli in the biopsy.
  • Lesions in the affected glomeruli can be segmental, meaning they spare at least half of the glomerular tuft, or global, meaning they involve more than half of the glomerular tuft.
  • Subendothelial immune complex deposits can lead to circumferential thickening of the capillary wall and form "wire loop” structures by light microscopy.
  • Class IV disease (diffuse proliferative nephritis) is the most severe and prevalent subtype.

Clinical findings:

  • Clinically, haematuria, and proteinuria occur, often with nephrotic syndrome, hypertension, hypocomplementemia, elevated anti-dsDNA titers, and elevated serum creatinine.
  • Kidney failure is common.

Treatment:

  • Corticosteroids and immunosuppressant drugs

Option B: Membranous nephritis

  • It is caused by diffuse thickening of the capillary walls due to the deposition of sub-epithelial immune complexes, which looks like idiopathic membranous nephropathy.
  • The immune complexes are often accompanied by increased production of basement membrane-like material.

Clinical findings:

  • Signs of nephrotic syndrome.
  • Microscopic haematuria and hypertension may also be observed.
  • It can also lead to thrombotic complications such as renal vein thromboses or pulmonary emboli.
  • Kidney failure is uncommon.

Option C: Sclerotic nephritis

Advanced sclerosing lupus nephritis (class VI)

  • It is characterized by sclerosis of more than 90% of the glomeruli and represents end-stage renal disease.

Clinical findings:

  • Active glomerulonephritis is not common.
  • This stage is distinguished by gradually progressing kidney dysfunction and relatively bland urine sediment.

Option D: Focal nephritis

Focal lupus nephritis (class III)

    • Defined as the involvement of less than 50% of all glomeruli.
    • The lesions may be segmental or global.
    • Affected glomeruli may exhibit swelling and proliferation of endothelial and mesangial cells associated with leukocyte accumulation, capillary necrosis, and hyaline thrombi.

Clinical findings:

  • Immunofluorescence reveals positive for IgG, IgA, IgM, C3, and C1q.
  • Clinically, haematuria, and proteinuria are present, with or without the nephrotic syndrome, hypertension, and elevated serum creatinine.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male came to your OPD to quit alcohol consumption. He has drinks daily for the last 5 years. His consumption is 2-3 beers daily and around 8-10 beers on weekends. He never drinks & drives and never misses his work. But he had hung over in the office after weekends. In the last few months, he had reported a few blackouts due to binge drinking. Which laboratory tests will you perform on this patient to identify heavy alcohol consumption?
questions.solution:
Option A: Carbohydrate deficient transferrin

  • Carbohydrate-deficient transferrin (CDT) is a biomarker for chronic alcohol intake of more than 60 g ethanol/d.
  • It has been reported to be superior to conventional markers like gamma-glutamyltransferase (GGT) and mean corpuscular volume MCV).

Option B: 5-nucleotidase

  • 5′-Nucleotidase (5′NT) is associated with the canalicular and sinusoidal plasma membranes. Its function is undefined.
  • 5′NT is also found in the intestine, brain, heart, blood vessels, and endocrine pancreas.
  • Serum levels of 5′NT are unaffected by sex or race, but age affects the level; values are lowest in children and increase gradually, reaching a plateau at approximately age 50 years.

Option C: SGPT raised

The most common diseases that cause abnormally high SGOT and SGPT are:

  • Hepatitis A or B or C
  • Chronic viral hepatitis,
  • Cirrhosis of the liver (fibrosis of the liver because of prolonged inflammation of the liver),
  • Liver damage from alcohol,
  • Hemochromatosis (a genetic condition caused due to long-standing liver damage), and
  • Reduced blood flow to the liver (from shock or heart failure).

Option D: MCHC

  • MCHC is calculated by multiplying the haemoglobin result from the CBC panel by 100 and then dividing by the hematocrit result.
  • The reference range for MCHC in adults is 33.4–35.5 grams per deciliter (g/dL).
  • If your MCHC value is below 33.4 grams per deciliter, you have low MCHC. Low MCHC values occur if you have anaemia due to iron deficiency. It can also indicate thalassemia. This is an inherited blood disorder in which you have fewer red blood cells and less haemoglobin present in your body. Learn more about low MCHC and its possible causes.
  • If your MCHC value is above 35.5 grams per deciliter, you have high MCHC.

questions.text: A forty year old male is brought to the emergency department by his neighbour. The patient complains of severe abdominal pain, which radiates to the back. The neighbour states that the patient is an alcoholic. The patient is admitted with the suspicion of acute pancreatitis. A few hours after admission, the patient starts vomiting and feels dizzy while standing. On examination, he has severe tenderness in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen and decreased bowel sounds. A bluish discolouration is noticed around his umbilicus. Further examinations would show which of the following findings.

choices.text: A CT of the abdomen is likely to show severe necrotizing pancreatitis
Abdominal plain film is likely to show pancreatic calcification

questions.solution:
Option A: A CT of the abdomen is likely to show severe necrotizing pancreatitis

  • Acute pancreatitis is an acute inflammation of the pancreas.
  • Clinical findings include
    • Low-grade fever
    • Tachycardia
    • Hypotension
    • Severe abdominal pain of increasing intensity, which radiates to the back
    • Absent bowel sounds
    • Bluish discolouration in the periumbilical area (Cullen's sign) is due to hemoperitoneum.
    • Blue-red-purple or green-brown discolouration of the flanks (Grey Turner’s sign)
  • The Cullen's and Grey turner's signs indicate severe necrotizing pancreatitis with haemorrhage.
  • Below is a CT scan image showing acute pancreatitis with necrosis

Option B: Abdominal plain film is likely to show pancreatic calcification

  • Pancreatic calcifications occur in chronic pancreatitis.

Option C: Concomitant appendicitis

  • The patient's signs and symptoms are not suggestive of appendicitis.

Option D: A pancreatico-aortic fistula

  • The patient's signs and symptoms are not suggestive of a pancreatico-aortic fistula.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to your clinic with his son complaining of chest pain with exertion. He has had this pain for the past few weeks, which occurs only after walking and is relieved when he sits down or takes a break. He is a long-time smoker and has smoked 2 packs-per-day for the past 30 years. His son tells you that 5 years ago, he was admitted to the same hospital for myocardial infarction (MI). His heart rate is 72 beats/min, and his blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg. Physical examination is unremarkable. An ECG was performed, which is shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Perform stress test

  • This ECG shows a normal sinus rhythm.
  • Prominent Q waves in the leads III and AVF indicate a previous inferior wall myocardial infarction.
  • Markedly peaked T waves are noted in V2 and V3.
  • The patient is a known case of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) and currently has chronic stable angina.
  • Stable angina is described as chest pain that occurs on exertion and is relieved by rest or nitroglycerin.
  • Stress tests (exercise or pharmacological) are performed to decide the need for revascularization procedures like a percutaneous coronary intervention with stenting or coronary artery bypass graft.

Option B: Perform cardiac biomarkers

  • Cardiac biomarkers are elevated during an ongoing myocardial infarction (MI).
  • There are no signs suggesting an active MI in this patient.
  • ECG and history of the patient suggest that he has chronic stable angina.
  • Cardiac biomarkers will not be elevated since infarction has not yet occurred.

Option C: Perform percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI)

  • Stress tests must be performed to decide the need for a revascularization procedure.
  • This patient's current ECG has no findings suggestive of infarction that would benefit from PCI.

Option D: Perform transvenous pacing

  • Temporary transvenous pacing is recommended in cases with medically intractable symptomatic or hemodynamically significant bradycardia caused by SND (sinus node dysfunction) or atrioventricular block in individuals who have experienced an acute MI.
  • This patient's current heart rate is within normal limits, and there is no suggestion of an active MI.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female is brought to the hospital with her sister due to a persistent depressed mood. She also experienced low energy levels, negative thoughts, poor sleep, and increased appetite for the last 1 month. She was also hospitalized 3 years ago for symptoms of aggressive behaviour, overspending, and decreased sleep. She is a non-smoker and nonalcoholic. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
Option D: Quetiapine

  • This patient's current symptoms of persistent depressed mood, low energy levels, negative thoughts, poor sleep, and appetite are consistent with a depressive episode.
  • Symptoms of aggressive behavior, overspending, and decreased sleep are features of mania.
  • The presence of depressive mood and elated episodes are features of bipolar disorder type 1.
  • Bipolar disorder type 2 refers to a hypomanic episode with a depressive episode.
  • Antipsychotics are commonly used for treating bipolar disorder.
  • Quetiapine is one of the 1st line treatments for bipolar depression.
  • Quetiapine is an atypical antipsychotic.
  • Atypical antipsychotics are preferred over typical antipsychotics for fewer adverse effects.

Option A: Bupropion

  • Bupropion is an atypical antidepressant.
  • Antidepressants can worsen bipolar symptoms.

Option B: Escitalopram

  • Escitalopram is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor.
  • It is a drug of choice for depression, panic disorder, generalized anxiety disorder, OCD, social anxiety disorder, and bulimia.

Option C: Haloperidol

  • Haloperidol is a highly potent typical antipsychotic.
  • It can be used in bipolar disorder associated with psychosis.

questions.text: A 19–year–old male presents to the psychiatric emergency due to extreme restlessness, fidgetiness, and irritation for 1 week. It is associated with an inability to sit quietly. He is a known case of schizophrenia and is taking 20mg of haloperidol. Which of the following is the most effective treatment for this patient?

choices.text: Increase in the dose of haloperidol

questions.solution:
Option B: Addition of an anticholinergic drug

  • The symptoms described in the case, including extreme restlessness, fidgetiness, and an inability to sit quietly, are suggestive of a condition called "akathisia." Akathisia is a common side effect of antipsychotic medications like haloperidol and is characterized by inner restlessness and a compelling need to move. In this case, the most effective treatment for akathisia is Addition of an anticholinergic drug.

  • Benztropine is an anticholinergic used to treat akathisia. However, it is less potent than propranolol.

Option A: Increase in the dose of haloperidol

  • Haloperidol is a first-generation antipsychotic.
  • Increasing the dose will increase the symptoms of akathisia instead of treating it.

Option C: Addition of beta-blocker

  • The addition of a beta-blocker may provide some relief of symptoms, as beta blockers can have a calming effect, but they are not typically the first-line treatment for akathisia.

 

Extrapyramidal Effects

Clinical features

Pharmacotherapy

Acute dystonia

Sudden sustained contraction of the neck, mouth, tongue, and eye muscles presenting as:

  • Oculogyric crisis, ocular muscles spasm, and opisthotonos
  • Torticollis
  • Laryngospasm
  • Grimacing

Earliest to develop. Occurs within days of drug usage.

Anticholinergic drugs:

  • Benztropine
  • Diphenhydramine

Acute akathisia
  • Constant purposeless involuntary movement from one place to another.
  • Most common EPS.
  • Occurs within days to weeks
  • Propranolol
  • Lorazepam
  • Benztropine

Tardive dyskinesia

Gradual onset after prolonged therapy (>6 months). Usually presents after years of treatment.

Dyskinesia of the mouth, face trunk, and extremities causing:

  • chewing and sucking movements
  • grimacing
  • choreoathetoid movements
  • Deutetrabenazine
  • Valbenazine

Malignant neuroleptic syndrome

Most serious side effect. Presents as:

  • Hyperthermia
  • Severe muscular rigidity and dystonia
  • Akinesia
  • Mutism
  • Fluctuating level of consciousness
  • Agitation
  • Tachycardia
  • High blood pressure

Laboratory findings include:

  • Increased WBC count
  • Increased level of CPK
  • Increased level of liver enzymes
  • Increased levels of plasma myoglobin and myoglobinuria
  • Occasionally renal failure
  • Immediately stop antipsychotics
  • Medically cool the patient
  • Monitor vital signs
  • Dantrolene (skeletal muscle relaxant)
  • Bromocriptine or Amantadine

Drug-induced parkinsonism

Gradual onset tremor, rigidity, and bradykinesia.

Occurs within weeks to months
  • Benztropine
  • Amantadine

Option D: Addition of another antipsychotic drug

  • Antipsychotics lead to EPS. Akathisia is one of the EPS.
  • Adding another antipsychotic will increase akathisia.

questions.text: A 41-year-old executive believes that the company's management has denied her promotion by fabricating reports about her competence and forging her signature on key documents to incriminate her. She goes to the police station and files a complaint, as well as a request for security. There is no problem in managing her job and household activities. She has been experiencing these ideas for the last 2 months and is referred to a psychiatrist for further evaluation. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Persistent delusional disorder

  • Delusions are false fixed beliefs that cannot be assured when the facts are contrary to them.
  • When a person exhibits a delusion for more than 1 month without any co-existing psychiatric conditions, it is referred to as a persistent delusional disorder.
  • In this question, there is a single delusion that management is against her and her actions are according to that delusion.
  • The fact that this patient can maintain her household activities suggests that she can control the aspects of her life that are unaffected by the delusion.
  • Antipsychotic drugs are frequently used for the treatment of persistent delusional disorder.
  • Cognitive behavioral therapy is also common these days.

Option A: Paranoid schizophrenia

  • This is the wrong choice, as occupational impairment is common in paranoid schizophrenia.
  • Paranoid schizophrenia has classic presentations of paranoia accompanied by positive (delusions, hallucinations, speech disorders) and negative symptoms (social withdrawal, apathy, low confidence) of schizophrenia along with cognitive impairment.

​​​​​​​Option B: Late-onset psychosis

  • This is the wrong option, as occupational impairment is common in late-onset psychosis, which is not seen in this patient.
  • Psychosis also causes illusions and hallucinations.
  • Therefore, delusional disorder is the correct choice.

​​​​​​​Option B: Late-onset psychosis

  • This is the wrong option.
  • Because obsessive-compulsive disorder relates more to intrusive thoughts and inappropriate repetitive actions by the patients, which they recognize as abnormal, while delusions are false beliefs in which the patient holds firm conviction.
  • Obsessive-compulsive disorder is not associated with delusions.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents to a casualty with a history of regular and heavy use of alcohol for 10 years and morning drinking for one year. The last alcohol intake was 3 days back. There is no history of head injury or seizures. On examination, there is no icterus, signs of hepatic encephalopathy, or focal neurological signs. The patient has coarse tremors, visual hallucinations, and disorientation to time. Which of the following is the best medicine to be prescribed for such a patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Diazepam & thiamine

Delirium tremens

→ Most severe alcohol withdrawal syndrome.

→ Clinical features:

  • Clouding of consciousness with disorientation to time and place
  • Poor attention and distractibility
  • Visual hallucination and illusions which are often vivid and very frightening
  • Autonomic disturbances like tachycardia, fever, hypertension, sweating, and pupillary dilatation
  • Tachycardia, fever, and hypertension differentiate delirium tremens from alcoholic hallucinosis in which these signs are normal.
  • Psychomotor agitation and ataxia

Treatment:

  • Drug of choice is benzodiazepines like diazepam.
  • Prophylactic thiamine to prevent the development of Wernicke’s encephalopathy.

HOW TO REMEMBER: Triad of delirium tremens is HOT= Hallucinations, clouding of consciousness, tremors.

Option A: Diazepam & Lithium

  • Diazepam is the treatment of choice for delirium tremens. However, lithium is a mood stabilizer used in mood disorders. Hence this option is incorrect.

Option B: Haloperidol & naltrexone

  • This option is incorrect
  • Haloperidol is an antipsychotic drug, and naltrexone is used to treat opioid dependence.

Option D: Naltrexone & dantrolene

  • This option is incorrect
  • Naltrexone is used to treat opioid dependence, and dantrolene is used in malignant hyperthermia.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents to the OPD with a lump in her left breast. On examination, a 4 cm mass is noted in her left breast, with the left axillary lymph nodes fixed and matted. Overlying breast skin is normal, with no edema, swelling, or ulceration. No metastasis is seen on imaging. Which of the following is the most appropriate management method?

choices.text: Breast conservation surgery + Axillary Lymph Node sampling + Radiotherapy
Simple mastectomy + Axillary Lymph Node sampling
Neoadjuvant chemotherapy + Modified radical mastectomy + Radiotherapy
Halsted radical mastectomy followed by Radiotherapy

questions.solution:
Option C: Neoadjuvant chemotherapy + Modified radical mastectomy + Radiotherapy

  • The patient has a 4 cm mass in her left breast with clinically palpable axillary lymph nodes and no metastasis.
  • She has locally advanced breast cancer.
  • As per TMN staging, she has stage IIIC breast cancer.
  • Following are treatment options for various stages of breast cancer
    • Treatment for EARLY INVASIVE BREAST Carcinoma: Stage I, IIA, IIB
      • Breast conservation surgery (BCS), If BCS contraindicated: Simple mastectomy + ALNS
      • Axillary Lymph Node sampling (ALNS)
      • Radiotherapy
    • Treatment for LOCALLY ADVANCED BREAST Carcinoma: Stage IIIA, IIIB, IIIC
      • Neoadjuvant chemotherapy
      • Modified radical mastectomy
      • Radiotherapy
    • Treatment for Metastatic breast cancer: stage IV
      • Hormone therapy preferred over chemotherapy

Option A: Breast conservation surgery + Axillary Lymph Node sampling + Radiotherapy

  • It is a treatment option for stage I, IIA, and IIB breast cancer.
  • It involves removing only the cancerous portion of the breast with a surrounding tumor-free margin, followed by axillary lymph node sampling for possible involvement.
  • Radiotherapy is recommended following BCS to achieve remission and shows a better long-term prognosis.

Option B: Simple mastectomy + Axillary Lymph Node sampling

  • Simple mastectomy + Axillary lymph node sampling is a treatment option for stage I, IIA, and IIB breast cancer.
  • This approach is used when BCS is impossible or when a patient does not wish to undergo Radiotherapy following BCS.

Option D: Halsted radical mastectomy followed by Radiotherapy

  • Halsted radical mastectomy consists of the removal of the breast, muscles, and axillary lymph nodes.
  • It was the standard surgery until the 1970s for advanced breast cancers.
  • The current standard of mastectomy is Modified radical mastectomy (MRM), which is different from Halsted radical mastectomy in keeping both the pectoral muscles intact and using smaller incisions.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents to the outpatient department with a lump in her left breast that she noticed one month ago. She has no family history of breast cancer. The mass is rubbery, mobile, and non-tender to palpation.  There are no overlying skin changes or axillary lymphadenopathy. Ultrasound shows a 2-cm round cyst with smooth margins and no internal septations or solid components. Which of the following is the most appropriate management of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Aspiration of the cyst with cytologic analysis

questions.solution:
Option A: Reassurance and re-examination

  • This patient with a palpable mass and ultrasound features of a small cyst with smooth margins and no solid components or internal septations most likely has a simple cyst.
  • A simple cyst does not need immediate intervention, and reassurance and re-examination are recommended.
  • If the ultrasound features of the cyst suggest a low risk of malignancy, fine needle aspiration is done.
  • If the cyst disappears with aspiration and the contents are not grossly bloody → fluid does not need to be sent for cytologic analysis.
  • If the lesion does not completely disappear or recurs multiple times (more than twice is a reasonable rule) after aspiration or the fluid is bloody→ fluid should be sent for cytology to evaluate for solid components.
  • Cysts appear to arise from the destruction and dilation of lobules and terminal ductules seen in the last decade of reproductive life.
  • Multiple and bilateral cysts can mimic malignancy.
  • Direct aspiration or ultrasonography can confirm a palpable mass as a cyst.
  • Ultrasound findings of a single, small cyst with smooth borders and no solid components or internal septations suggest that the cyst is most likely benign.
  • On the other hand, multiple cysts may be multilocular, with irregular margins, internal septations, and solid components.

Option B: Fluoroscopically guided needle biopsy

  • Fluoroscopically guided needle biopsy is indicated for evaluating suspicious masses or cysts with an increased risk of malignancy.
  • This patient has a simple cyst that poses a small risk of malignancy and does not require further evaluation.

Option C: Aspiration of the cyst with cytologic analysis

  • If the ultrasound features of a breast cyst suggest a complex cyst with an increased risk of malignancy or the cyst is large, causing discomfort, aspiration of the cyst can be done.
  • If the fluid is bloody or the cyst is complicated, the fluid can be sent for cytologic analysis.
  • This patient has a small, simple cyst, and fluid cytologic analysis is unnecessary.

Option D: Immediate excisional biopsy

  • Excision of a cyst is indicated if the cytology reveals findings of atypia or if the cysts recur multiple times.
  • This patient most likely has a benign simple cyst that does not need an excisional biopsy.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman complaints of fever and anterior neck pain that had persisted for more than one month. Four weeks before admission, she had a sore throat and otalgia, symptoms that had improved after medication at private clinics. Two days later, fever and anterior neck pain developed. On physical examination, the swelling was non-tender and no signs of discharge/suppuration. The patient was treated with antipyretics, but her fever persisted. Lab findings indicate low TSH, elevated free T4 and T3.FNAC  showed follicular destruction and giant cell formation.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Subacute thyroiditis

  • The most likely diagnosis is subacute thyroiditis, as the swelling is painful and preceded by a viral upper respiratory illness and the microscopy shows follicular destruction and giant cell formation.

  • Subacute thyroiditis:

    • Painful thyroiditis is thought to be viral or results from a post-viral inflammatory response often preceded by an upper respiratory tract infection
    • Sudden or gradual onset of neck pain radiating to jaw or ear
    • 4 phases: initial hyperthyroid, then euthyroid phase, hypothyroid, resolution, and return to the euthyroid state
    • Most commonly occurs in 30 to 40-year-old women.
    • The gland is enlarged, exquisitely tender and firm.
    • ESR is raised
    • FNAC is diagnostic - demonstrates giant cells of an epitheloid foreign body type, which characterize the lesion
    • Microscopic pathology shows large follicles infiltrated by mononuclear cells, neutrophils and lymphocytes.
    • Self-limited and treatment is primarily symptomatic

Option A: Acute thyroiditis

  • Acute suppurative thyroiditis is an infection of the thyroid gland by Streptococcus and anaerobes.
  • More common in children and preceded by an upper respiratory tract infection or otitis media. It usually occurs in those with immunosuppression and results from seeding an infectious agent via hematogenous, direct spread from the pyriform sinus fistulae/thyroglossal duct cyst or penetrating trauma.
  • Presents with severe neck pain radiating to the jaws or ear, fever, chills, odynophagia, and dysphonia.

Option C: Tubercular lymphadenitis

  • May present with neck swelling, hoarseness of voice, dyspnea, dysphagia
  • On gross examination, show cystic areas with foci of necrosis
  • Microscopy shows caseous necrosis, multinucleated giant cells, and epitheloid cell granulomas.

Option D: Hashimoto's thyroiditis

  • Hashimoto's thyroiditis is the most common inflammatory thyroid disorder due to an autoimmune process resulting in lymphocyte-mediated damage of thyroid follicular cells.
  • The patient presents with signs of hypothyroidism. The gland is enlarged, nodular and painless.
  • On microscopy, it diffusely infiltrated by small lymphocytes and plasma cells, showing well developed germinal centre.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents to surgery OPD with a complaint of swelling in the front of the neck for the last 7 months. Her neck examination reveals a swelling in the midline of the neck with multiple nodules, which moves with deglutition. Her clinical features and laboratory investigation suggest multinodular goiter. She has been scheduled for a total thyroidectomy. Which of the following statements about the complications of thyroidectomy is true?

choices.text: A thyrotoxic crisis occurs because of inadequate preoperative preparation
The most common cause of respiratory obstruction is nerve injury
The recurrent laryngeal nerve is more commonly injured than the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve
Parathyroid insufficiency characteristically occurs on days 5-10 after Surgery due to vascular infarction

questions.solution:
Option A: A thyrotoxic crisis occurs because of inadequate preoperative preparation.

  • The case mentioned above underwent total Thyroidectomy for multinodular goitre. Thyroid complications, including thyroid storm, occur due to inadequate preoperative preparation.
  • Thyroid insufficiency and thyrotoxicosis crisis (storm) occurs due to inadequate preoperative preparation of a phytotoxic patient. 
  • Complications of Thyroidectomy include:
    • Hemorrhage
      • It is the most frequent life-threatening complication of Thyroidectomy
      • Most often develops within 24 hours
      • Arterial bleed — Central compartment pressure exceeds venous pressure —Venous edema of the larynx — Airway obstruction
      • Immediate release of sutures and evacuation of the hematoma and wound exploration to be done
    • Respiratory obstruction
      • Laryngeal edema (due to intubation injury)
      • Other causes- recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy, tension hematoma
    • Nerve injuries
      • Injured nerve – External branch of a superior laryngeal nerve (aka External laryngeal nerve) due to its proximity to the superior thyroid artery.
      • This leads to a loss of tension in the vocal cord with diminished power and range in the voice.
      • Recurrent laryngeal nerve - may be unilateral or bilateral, transient or permanent.
      • Cervical sympathetic trunk
    • Parathyroid insufficiency
      • MC cause – Vascular infarction of parathyroid gland (if inferior thyroid artery is ligated away from parathyroid gland during Surgery)
      • Parathyroid insufficiency most commonly presents on the 2nd – 5th day of Surgery.
      • Manifestations are carpopedal spasms, tingling, and numbness over the perioral region.
      • Treatment:
        • Mild to moderate symptoms (calcium level >8gm/dl): oral calcium supplementation
        • Severe symptoms (<8gm /dl): IV calcium gluconate
    • Thyroid insufficiency
    • Thyrotoxic crisis (storm)
      • Inadequate preoperative preparation of a thyrotoxic patient
      • Acute exacerbation of hyperthyroidism
    • Wound infection
    • Hypertrophic or keloid scar
