Option B: The most common cause of respiratory obstruction is nerve injury.

  • The most common cause of respiratory obstruction is arterial bleeding leading to the formation of tension hematoma.
  • Arterial bleeding leads to increased central compartment pressure compared to venous pressure.
  • It causes venous edema of the larynx, obstructing the airway.
  • Immediate release of sutures and evacuation of the hematoma and wound exploration will be done.

Option C: The recurrent laryngeal nerve is more commonly injured than the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve

  • During Thyroidectomy, the most common injured nerve is the External branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (also known as the External laryngeal nerve) due to its proximity to the superior thyroid artery.

Option D: Parathyroid insufficiency characteristically occurs on days 2-5 after Surgery due to vascular infarction

  • Parathyroid insufficiency occurs due to vascular infarction of the parathyroid gland.
  • It most commonly presents on the 2nd – 5th day of surgery, and its manifestations are carpopedal spasm, tingling, and numbness over the perioral region.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old female presented to the clinic with nausea, vomiting, muscle weakness, fatigue, confusion, oliguria, 10 kg weight loss, and back pain at night. Her mammogram five years ago was abnormal, but she did not follow up with her doctor regarding the results. Her serum chemistry report:

Sodium 138 mEq/L

Potassium 4.5 mEq/L

Chloride 104 mEq/L

Calcium 15 mg/dL

Bicarbonate 22 mEq/L

Blood urea nitrogen 20 mg/dL

Creatinine 1.1 mg/dL

Which of the following is the most likely cause of this electrolyte abnormality?
questions.solution:
Option C: Hypercalcemia of malignancy

  • The patient has presented with a hypercalcemic crisis due to significantly elevated serum calcium levels. She has a weight loss of 10 kg despite a healthy diet.
  • The most likely underlying cause of the hypercalcemic crisis is the hypercalcemia of malignancy. Her history of abnormal mammogram results, back pain at night, and weight loss suggest she has breast cancer.
  • Hypercalcemic crisis:
    • It is a medical and surgical emergency due to severe hypercalcemia from uncontrolled PTH secretion or other conditions causing hypercalcemia in association with end-organ dysfunction
    • Patients with parathyroid cancer or familial hyperparathyroidism are more likely to present with a hypercalcemic crisis
    • Calcium levels are markedly elevated and may be as high as 16 to 20 mg/dL. It generally occurs when serum calcium exceeds 14 mg/dL
    • Present acutely with nausea, vomiting, fatigue, muscle weakness, confusion, obtundation, decreased level of consciousness, oliguria/anuria, and hyperkalemia
    • Stepwise approach for management of Hypercalcemic crisis
      • Step 1: Confirm the diagnosis.
      • Step 2: Restore normal hydration - Through IV fluids (0.9% normal saline at a rate of at least 200mL/hr) to maintain a urine output of >100 ml/hr.
      • Step 3: 
        • Use of loop diuretics (but the patient's blood pressure must be stable)
        • Calcitonin or bisphosphonates- Preferred drugs for hypercalcemic management after restoring normal hydration with IV fluids
        • Other drugs - Glucocorticoids, cinacalcet, mithramycin, and gallium nitrate

Option A: Parathyroid adenoma

  • Although parathyroid adenoma does cause hypercalcemia, this patient’s clinical presentation suggests hypercalcemia of malignancy. 

Option B: Parathyroid hyperplasia

  • Although parathyroid hyperplasia does cause hypercalcemia, this patient’s clinical presentation suggests hypercalcemia of malignancy. Such high levels of serum calcium are usually seen in hypercalcemia of malignancy.

Option D: Paget’s disease

  • This option is incorrect because serum calcium levels are usually normal in Paget’s disease.

questions.text: A 39-year-old male was referred to your hospital from a local hospital, where he was followed up for liver cirrhosis induced by 4 years of chronic alcoholism. His condition was complicated by alcohol-induced encephalopathy, delirium tremens, portal hypertension, and arrhythmia. On endoscopic examination, the existence of abdominal ascites, pedal edema, clammy skin, and esophageal varices. Child-Turcotte-Pugh (CTP) Scoring was done, which placed him in class C. What of the following probable treatment?
questions.solution:
Option A: Liver transplantation

  • This patient has cirrhosis; the complication is portal hypertension manifested in variceal bleeding with ascites.
  • The child's class 'C' score means no surgical intervention should be done → Best treatment is liver transplantation.
  • Patients with variceal bleeding who are transplantation candidates include
    • Alcoholic cirrhotic patients with limited hepatic functional reserve (Child-Pugh class B and C).
    • There is poor quality of life secondary to the disease (encephalopathy, fatigue, bone pain ), and intervention should be done.
  • Child-Pugh classification:
Clinical and lab criteria Point 1 Point 2 Point 3
Encephalopathy None Grade 1 or 2 Grade 3 or 4
Ascites None Mild to moderate (diuretic responsive) Severe (diuretic refractory)
Bilirubin (mg/dL) <2 2-3 >3
Albumin (g/dL) >3.5 2.8 - 3.5 <2.8
Prothrombin time      
Seconds prolonged  <4 4 - 6 >6
International normalized ratio <1.7 1.7 - 2.3 >2.3

Option B: Major surgery

  • Major surgery is indicated in Class B, Child-Pugh Classification.

Option C: Minor surgery

  • Minor surgery is indicated in Class A, Child-Pugh Classification.

Option D: TIPS

  • TIPS is a transjugular intrahepatic portal-systemic shunt.
  • This procedure is used to relieve portal hypertension.
  • Hepatic encephalopathy is a notorious complication of TIPS.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions exhibit the given findings on ultrasound?
questions.solution:
Answer

Option C: Adenomyomatosis

  • The ultrasound image above shows a comet tail artifact in the gallbladder, which is suggestive of adenomyomatosis.
  • Adenomyomatosis is a benign hyperplastic cholecystitis with no malignant potential that results from hyperplasia of both the mucosa and muscularis propria of the gallbladder wall.
  • Intramural diverticula are called Rokitansky–Aschoff sinuses, which trap bile that accumulates cholesterol crystals appearing as cystic spaces in a thickened gallbladder wall with a characteristic comet tail artifact.
  • The gallbladder wall thickening in adenomyomatosis may be focal or diffuse. Focal wall thickening is most common in the fundus.
  • It is seen as a sessile lesion commonly in the fundus with characteristic microcysts within the lesion and is frequently larger than 1 cm.

Other Options

Option A: Gallbladder stone

  • Ultrasound is considered the gold standard for detecting gallstones.
  • Greyscale ultrasound
    • Highly reflective echogenic focus within the gallbladder lumen, normally with prominent posterior acoustic shadowing regardless of pathological type (acoustic shadowing is independent of the composition and calcium content)
    • Gravity-dependent movement is often seen with a change of patient position (the rolling stone sign)

Option B: Gallbladder polyp

  • Gallbladder polyps may be found in approximately 5% of patients who undergo ultrasonography and consists of pseudo tumours and adenomas. 
  • Pseudotumors are further divided into adenomyomatosis and cholesterol polyps and have no malignant potential. 
  • True adenomatous polyps occur in 0.3-0.5% of the population. The risk of malignant transformation increases with the increasing size of the polyp.
  • Cholesterol polyps appear as pedunculated echogenic lesions of the gallbladder, are usually smaller than 1cm, and are frequently multiple.

Option D: Xanthogranulomatous cholecystitis

  • Xanthogranulomatous cholecystitis (XGC) is an uncommon inflammatory disease of the gallbladder that may be difficult to differentiate from malignancy, both on imaging and pathologically. It is characterized by the presence of multiple intramural nodules.

questions.text: A 40-year-old chronic alcoholic reported right upper quadrant discomfort and audible bruit on examination. AFP was more than 20 mg/mL, with arterial enhancement on CT. Which of the following statement is most appropriate regarding treatment options for the diagnosis?

choices.text: Complete excision by partial or total hepatectomy & transplantation is the only treatment modality with curative potential
Sorafenib is given for metastatic and unresectable cases
Liver transplantation is the definitive treatment
Only 15-20 % of cases have an unresectable tumour

questions.solution:
The above clinical picture suggests Hepatocellular carcinoma (Raised AFP with arterial enhancement on CT).

Hepatocellular carcinoma

  • Most common primary malignant neoplasm of the liver
  • It is the fifth most common malignancy worldwide
  • More common in men

Risk factors

  • Viral hepatitis (B or C)
  • Alcoholic cirrhosis
  • Hemochromatosis
  • NASH
  • Aflatoxin produced by Aspergillus species
  • Hydrocarbons, Vinyl chloride, Thorotrast

Clinical features

  • Right upper quadrant pain and weight loss
  • Presents at an advanced stage
  • May rupture and cause hypovolemic shock
  • Can cause hepatic vein occlusion (Budd Chiari syndrome)
  • Obstructive jaundice
  • Hemobilia
  • Fever of unknown origin
  • Paraneoplastic syndromes
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Erythrocytosis

Diagnosis

  • Hypervascular - Blood supplied predominantly from the hepatic artery
  • CT - Appears hypervascular during the arterial phase and relatively hypodense during the delayed phase due to early washout of the contrast medium by the arterial blood
  • MRI - Variable on T1 weighted images and usually hyperintense on T2 weighted images
  • Portal vein invasion common - The presence of an enhancing portal vein thrombus is highly suggestive of hepatocellular carcinoma
  • Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) levels are elevated. A level greater than 400ng/mL is diagnostic for a liver mass greater than 2cm with arterial enhancement. AFP can be <20 ng/mL in more than 40% of patients with HCC

Treatment

  • Only 10% to 20% of patients are considered to have a resectable disease
  • Liver resection and transplantation is the only treatment option with curative potential.
  • Of this, transplantation is preferred because
  • Most HCCs are cirrhotic and hence do not have enough reserve
  • HCCs are commonly multifocal
  • Recurrence rates are high at 5 years after resection

Treatment options

  • Surgical
  • Liver resection ( treatment of choice)
  • Patients without cirrhosis with HCC
  • Child’s class A cirrhosis with preserved liver function and no portal hypertension
  • Liver transplantation
  • Child’s class C
  • Treatment of choice if resection is not possible because of poor liver function and the HCC meets transplant criteria
  • Sorafenib, molecular targeted therapy - For advanced, unresectable HCC

Option A: Complete excision by partial or total hepatectomy & transplantation is the only treatment modality with curative potential

  • Although complete excision by partial or total hepatectomy & transplantation is the only treatment modality with curative potential, option B, which states that sorafenib is given for metastatic and unresectable cases, is also correct.

Option B: Sorafenib is given for metastatic and unresectable cases

  • Although sorafenib is given for metastatic and unresectable cases, option A, which states that complete excision by partial or total hepatectomy & transplantation is the only treatment modality with curative potential, is also correct.

Option D: Only 15-20 % of cases have an unresectable tumour

  • Only 10% to 20% of patients are considered to have a resectable disease; the rest have unresectable tumours.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented to the outpatient department with abdominal pain for the past 3 hours. He consumes 20 drinks of alcohol per week. Presently, he has severe vomiting. He also complains of dizziness when standing. On examination revealed tenderness in the epigastrium radiating to the back. A reddish discolouration was noted in the flanks. Which of the following is the investigation of choice?

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen for necrotising pancreatitis

questions.solution:
Option C: CT scan of the abdomen for necrotising pancreatitis

  • The history and clinical features of the patient (Abdominal tenderness, hypotension due to blood loss, Grey Turner's sign) are suggestive of severe pancreatitis.
  • Hence a contrast CT scan of the abdomen will reveal severe necrotising pancreatitis.
  • The cardinal symptom of acute pancreatitis is epigastric or periumbilical pain (the nature of pain is constant) that radiates to the back. Up to 90% of patients have nausea or vomiting that typically does not relieve the pain
  • Dehydration, poor skin turgor, tachycardia, hypotension and dry mucous membrane are commonly seen in patients with acute pancreatitis. Severely dehydrated and older patients may also develop mental status changes
  • Rare physical examination findings include
    • Reddish/bluish discolouration of the flanks is known as Grey Turner's sign
    • Another feature of pancreatic necrosis is a bluish discolouration around the umbilicus, known as Cullen's sign
    • Both are indicative of retroperitoneal bleeding associated with severe pancreatitis.
    • But they are not pathognomic of pancreatitis

Option A: CT abdomen for appendicitis

  • Appendicitis patients will initially present with generalised abdominal pain, which will localise into the right iliac fossa pain after a few hours. This patient had epigastric pain and reddish-blue discolouration of the flanks suggestive of necrotising pancreatitis

Option B: USG

  • Ultrasound of the abdomen does not give physicians a good picture of acute pancreatitis, which is why it is not recommended. Ultrasound of the abdomen for acute pancreatitis is only done in pregnant patients due to the threat of radiation exposure from a CT scan

Option D: X-ray abdomen

  • X-ray of the abdomen is of no use in acute pancreatitis as the changes will not be visible on the x-ray. Chronic pancreatitis calcifications can be visible on x-ray.

questions.text: What is the gold standard of investigation for diagnosing gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)?
questions.solution:
Option C: 24-hour pH monitoring

  • Gold standard Investigation for GERD
  • Esophageal pH monitoring is used to evaluate gastroesophageal reflux disease and determine the effectiveness of medications that prevent acid reflux.
  • This test measures the amount of acid refluxing or backing up from the stomach into the esophagus.
  • The test involves placing a catheter (a thin tube), or a special device called a pH probe into the esophagus. The catheter or device will measure the acid level (known as pH level) for 24 to 96 hours. 

Option A: Barium swallow

  • IOC for diagnosis of Hiatus hernia and Zenker’s diverticula
  • A barium swallow, also called an esophagogram, is an imaging test that checks for problems in the upper GI tract.
  • The test uses a special type of x-ray called fluoroscopy.
  • A chalky white substance is swallowed. It is often mixed with water to make a thick drink that looks like a milkshake. When swallowed, this liquid coats the inside of the upper GI. Barium absorbs X-rays and looks white on X-ray film.

Option B: Endoscopy

  • IOC for diagnosis of Barrett's esophagus
  • An endoscopy is a test to look inside the body.
  • A long, thin tube with a small camera inside, called an endoscope, is passed into the body through a natural opening such as the mouth.
  • Endoscopy allows for collecting tissue samples (biopsy) to test for diseases and conditions causing anemia, bleeding, inflammation, or diarrhea. It can also detect some cancers of the upper digestive system.

Option D: Esophageal manometry

  • IOC for diagnosis of motility disorders of the esophagus like Achalasia cardia, Diffuse esophageal spasm, and Nut cracker's esophagus.
  • The esophagus is a long, muscular tube that connects the throat to the stomach.
  • After swallowing, esophagus contracts and pushes food into the stomach; esophageal manometry measures the contractions.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male is admitted to the ICU following a thoracotomy for a traumatic esophageal perforation. He has a high TLC count and an abnormal coagulation profile, as well as being febrile and hypotensive. An intern puts in an NG tube, but it quickly fills with blood and continues to bleed. What would be the endoscopic finding for this case of stress gastritis?

choices.text: Single deep ulcer in the fundus
Multiple, shallow ulcers with areas of erythema and focal hemorrhage in the antrum
Multiple, shallow ulcers with areas of erythema and focal hemorrhage in the fundus
Multiple deep ulcers in the antrum

questions.solution:
Option C: Multiple, shallow ulcers with areas of erythema and focal hemorrhage in the fundus 

  • Stress ulcers are caused by acute gastric or duodenal erosive lesions that can develop as a result of shock, sepsis, major surgery, trauma, or burns. Resulting in life-threatening bleeding from the stomach. 
  • The condition is characterized by repeated, superficial erosions that do not ulcerate and start in the proximal stomach, which is the region of the stomach that secretes acid (the fundus) and advances distally. 
  • The lesions are often many and superficial, and they are characterized by distinct patches of erythema, as well as focal hemorrhage or an adhering clot in certain cases. 
  • In most cases, these involve the fundus and the body. 
  • Ischemic injury to the mucosa as a result of decreased splanchnic blood flow is the primary pathology, and increased gastric secretion is not the cause of this condition. 
  • In the presence of a disease affecting the central nervous system, a Cushing ulcer may develop. 
  • A curling ulcer develops as a consequence of thermal burn damage that affects more than thirty percent of the body's surface area.  
  • Endoscopic findings include multiple shallow ulcers with areas of erythema and focal hemorrhage in the fundus. 

Option A: Single deep ulcer in the fundus 

  • A single deep ulcer in the fundus cannot be the endoscopic finding in stress-induced ulcers. 

Option B: Multiple, shallow ulcers with areas of erythema and focal hemorrhage in the antrum 

  • Multiple, shallow ulcers with areas of erythema and focal hemorrhage in the fundus are seen on endoscopy. 

Option D: Multiple deep ulcers in the antrum 

  • Multiple deep ulcers in the antrum cannot be the endoscopic finding in stress-induced ulcers.

questions.text: Which bacteria is responsible for peritonitis in patients undergoing dialysis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Staphylococcus Epidermidis

  • Continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis (CAPD) involves multiple exchanges (3-4) daily, followed by an overnight dwell.
  • In the patient undergoing CAPD, peritonitis is caused by the introduction of microbes to the sterile peritoneum (intraluminal contamination, touch contamination and periluminal contamination) in the setting of compromised host defences (The continuous presence of a large amount of fluid in the peritoneal cavity can impair host defences)
    • This results in contamination of the peritoneum with pathogenic skin bacteria, i.e., staphylococcus epidermidis.
    • Contamination with skin bacteria occurs when the patient is performing exchanges or connecting/disconnecting from the transfer set.
      • A patient on continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis (CAPD) connects and disconnects from the transfer set at least four times per day, thus 1460 times per year, raising the possibility of infection even among maximally skilled patients.

Option A: Staphylococcus Aureus

  • Staphylococcus is also a skin pathogen and a source of contamination for the causation of peritonitis, but it is not as prevalent as staphylococcus epidermidis.

Option C: Escherichia coli

  • Escherichia coli is the commonest causative pathogen of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis but not in peritonitis in the settings of CAPD as it is not a part of the flora.

Option D: Bacteroides

  • Bacteroides are one of the causative organisms for peritonitis, but not in the setting of CAPD, as it is not a skin pathogen but rather a part of gut flora.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male presented to the clinic with complaints of abdominal pain associated with nausea, vomiting, weight loss, and melena. Endoscopy and abdominal CT scan contrast showed a mass in the region of the ampulla of Vater; a biopsy confirmed the diagnosis to be adenocarcinoma. What would be the best surgical treatment for adenocarcinoma in this region?
questions.solution:
Option A: Pancreaticoduodenectomy

  • The best surgical treatment option for adenocarcinoma is pancreaticoduodenectomy.
  • It is the best treatment because adenocarcinomas are usually multiple and sessile masses that tend to recur if a conservation approach is used by going only for a duodenectomy. Recurrence is even possible after this radical procedure.
  • Surveillance is necessary even after a pancreaticoduodenectomy to diagnose the recurrence before it has metastasized.

 

Option B: Segmental intestinal resection with lymphadenectomy

  • Localized small intestinal carcinoid tumours are treated surgically with this approach.
  • Lymph nodes are resected because of the high chances of metastasis.

 

Option C: Wide local resection

  • It is the surgical procedure of choice in jejunal and ileal malignancies.
  • Wide resection of the mesentery and associated lymph nodes are removed down to the superior mesenteric artery.

 

Option D: Right hemicolectomy

  • It is the surgical procedure of choice for distal ileal carcinomas.
  • Lymph nodes along the ileocolic artery usually drain the distal ileal carcinomas.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male comes to the outpatient department complaining of ball-rolling movements and projectile vomiting of undigested food particles. There is no history of allergy or drug abuse. Vital signs are within normal range. Physical examination reveals visible gastric peristalsis from left to right and a positive succussion splash test. Endoscopy reveals a gastric mass obstructing the pylorus. A biopsy of the lesion revealed gastric adenocarcinoma. Which of the following anemia is a risk factor for the development of gastric carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Option A: Pernicious anemia

  • It is an autoimmune disease due to the CD4+ cell-mediated immune response or antibodies against the stomach's parietal cells.
  • In pernicious anemia, there is progressive destruction of parietal cells, and it results in:
    • Decrease hydrochloric acid secretion, which increases gastric pH.
    • Decrease intrinsic factor secretion impairs vitamin B₁₂ absorption.

Option B: Megaloblastic anemia

  • It is a type of megaloblastic anemia that occurs due to vitamin B₁₂ or folate deficiency.
  • In this anemia, the bone marrow produces stem cells that produce enlarged red blood cells.
    • Fatigue
    • Pallor
    • Shortness of breath.
  • Vitamin B₁₂ deficiency occurs due to the following:
    • Pernicious anemia
    • Gastrectomy
    • Zollinger-Ellison syndrome
    • Pancreatic insufficiency
  • Folate/vitamin B9 deficiency occurs due to the following:
    • Decrease intake of green vegetables, fish, and meat.
    • Cohn’s or ulcerative colitis
    • Hemolytic anemia
    • Increase alcohol intake.

Option C: Aplastic anemia

  • It is a type of anemia in which bone marrow does not produce new blood cells.
  • It is an autoimmune disease in which T-cell-mediated autoimmune destruction of bone marrow occurs.
  • It mostly occurs due to the following:
    • Chemotherapy
    • Toxins (benzene)
    • Certain drugs (like chloramphenicol, carbamazepine, and phenytoin)
    • Autoimmune disorder.
    • Parvovirus (short-lived)
  • It manifests the following:
    • Fatigue
    • Pale skin
    • Shortness of breath
    • Severe bruises
    • Increased risk of infection

Option D: Hemolytic anemia

  • It is a type of anemia that occurs due to the early breakdown of red blood cells.
  • Red blood cells have a 120-day life span; if its breakdown occurs, bone marrow has less time to form new RBCs.
  • There are many types of hemolytic anemia:
    • Sickle cell anemia
    • Thalassemia
    • G6PD deficiency
  • It causes the following signs/symptoms:
    • Jaundice
    • Tachycardia
    • Dyspnea
    • Fatigue
    • Enlarged spleen or liver

questions.text: A 20-year-old female presents to the OPD with complaints of purple spots on her body and frequent nose and gum bleeding episodes. On probing her history further, it was found that she hasa known case of idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura and has been on steroid treatment for two months. On examination, the patient has a non-palpable purpura with gingival bleeding. Her platelet count is 8000/cu.mm. The patient is taken in for elective splenectomy. What is the most common post-splenectomy complication?
questions.solution:
Option B: Left lower lobe atelectasis

  • After splenectomy, pulmonary complications like left lower lobe atelectasis, pleural effusion, and pneumonia develop.
  • Left lower lobe atelectasis is the most common pulmonary complication.
  • General anesthesia and surgical manipulation lead to atelectasis by causing diaphragmatic dysfunction and decreased surfactant activity.
  • Post-operative atelectasis is treated with adequate oxygenation and re-expansion of the alveoli. Supplemental oxygen should be titrated to achieve an arterial oxygen saturation greater than 90%.
  • Severe hypoxemia associated with severe respiratory distress should lead to intubation and mechanical support.

Option A: Hematemesis

  • Hematemesis after splenectomy can develop due to complications like portal hypertension or vascular injury to short gastric vessels.

Option C: Pleural effusion

  • Pleural effusion is one of the pulmonary complications which develop after splenectomy.
  • It is not the most common complication.

Option D: Acute dilatation of stomach

  • Gastric dilatation and resultant volvulus occur when the pylorus is malpositioned after manipulation.
  • There is severe gastric distension with gas, food, and/or fluid, resulting in secondary life-threatening complications.
  • Some studies advocate gastropexy.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common complication of appendectomy in the early postoperative period?
questions.solution:
Option A: Wound infection

  • The treatment of choice for acute uncomplicated appendicitis is emergency appendectomy.
  • Postoperative complications after appendectomy are relatively infrequent and reflect the severity of peritonitis that existed at the time of operation and intercurrent co-morbid that may predispose to complications.
  • Wound infection is the most common complication in 5-10 percent of all cases.
  • This commonly presents with erythema and pain of the wound on the 4th or 5th postoperative day and often soon after hospital discharge.
  • Treatment includes wound drainage and antibiotics as required.
  • A mixture of organisms, including anaerobes, gram-negative bacilli, Bacteroides species, and anaerobic streptococci is responsible for causing wound infection.

Option B: Ileus

  • A period of ileus is expected after appendectomy and may last for a few days after removing a gangrenous appendix.
  • Persistent ileus for more than 4 to 5 days, particularly with fever, indicates continuing intra-abdominal sepsis and should prompt additional investigations.
  • This complication is not as common as wound infection.

Option C: Adhesive intestinal obstruction

  • It is the most common late complication of appendectomy.
  • Often, a single-band adhesion is responsible for producing intestinal obstruction.
  • Sometimes, chronic pain in the right iliac fossa is due to adhesion formation after an appendectomy, where laparoscopy is used to confirm the presence of adhesions and also to divide those adhesions.
  • This complication is not as common as wound infection.

Option D: Portal pyaemia

  • A rare but very serious complication is gangrenous appendicitis, characterised by high-grade fever and jaundice.
  • It is caused by septicemia in the portal venous system, leading to an intrahepatic abscess.
  • Percutaneous drainage of hepatic abscesses and systemic antibiotics are the treatment for such cases.
  • This complication is not as common as wound infection.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman with anorexia nervosa-binge eating/purging type (AN-BP) was admitted to your hospital for the c/o abdominal pain radiating to the back. According to her medical history, she had initiated dieting after entering college at the age of 18. Initially, she practiced only dietary restrictions but gradually began self-induced vomiting. Based on the medical history she provided, her weight (50 kg) decreased gradually and was 40 kg by the time she got married at 22. During this time, she had begun consuming a commercially available laxative. She was diagnosed with AN on a visit to a nearby mental clinic but refused hospitalization. Throughout this period, the patient continued to restrict her diet and abuse laxatives. You transfer the patient to the radiology department for a routine USG which revealed calculi in the renal pelvis of both kidneys. The most probable type of stone to develop in this patient is:
questions.solution:
− Chronic laxative abuse →chronic dehydration→ ammonium urate stones.

Conditions associated with ammonium urate stones:

  1. Laxative abuse
  2. Recurrent UTI
  3. Recurrent uric acid stone formation
  4. Inflammatory bowel disease

questions.text: A 10 months old baby boy is brought by her parents to the urology outpatient department with complaints of an abnormal-looking penis and passage of urine from the underside of the penis almost near the scrotum. On examination, the opening of the urethra is located where the penis meets the scrotum with mild chordee (abnormality where the penis is bent downwards). Surgery was planned for the patient, identify and the correct order of correction of the above-given condition in this patient?

choices.text: Straightening of the penis – Balanoplasty – Urethroplasty
Straightening of the penis – Urethroplasty – Balanoplasty

questions.solution:
Option C: Straightening of the penis – Urethroplasty – Balanoplasty

  • The above-given case is penoscrotal hypospadias, as it presents with an abnormal-looking penis, the passage of urine from the underside of the penis and the opening of the urethra where the penis meets the scrotum.
  • The best time for Surgery for hypospadias: is 6 - 12months of age.
  • Hypospadias is a congenital disability in which the opening of the urethra is not present at the tip of the penis
  • Types of hypospadias:
    • Sub coronal: the opening of the urethra is present somewhere near the head of the penis.
    • Mid-shaft: the opening of the urethra is present on the shaft of the penis.
    • Peno-scrotal: the opening of the urethra is where the penis and scrotum meet.
  • The patient presents with an opening of the urethra other than the tip, downward curvature of the penis, a hooded appearance of the penis and abnormal spraying during urination.
  • Hypospadias is present congenitally.
  • Diagnosed usually by physical examination.

Successful hypospadias surgery incorporates the following steps:

  • Straightening of the penis (arthroplasty)
  • Reconstruction of the urethra (urethroplasty)
  • Meatus (meatoplasty)
  • Glans (glanuloplasty)
  • The skin of the penis & scrotum, whenever necessary.

In hypospadias, after straightening the penis, urethroplasty is done. Balanoplasty is done after urethroplasty.

questions.text: A 72-year-old female came to the medical OPD with elevated blood pressure and type II diabetes mellitus. She underwent angiography because of a painful, non-healing ulcer over the ankle of the left leg. The angiography showed arterial occlusive disease. Which of the following is the best for treating arterial occlusive diseases in this case?

choices.text: Revascularize the area along with debridement

questions.solution:
Option B: Revascularize the area along with debridement

  • Treatment of arterial ulcers includes vascular surgery to revascularize the area, debridement of devitalized tissue, antibiotic administration and bed rest.
  • The arterial occlusive disease occurs when the arteries throughout the body gradually narrow. It can affect the arms and legs.
  • Arterial insufficiency ulcers and ischemic ulcers mostly affect the lateral surface of the ankle or the distal digits.
  • Characteristic features:
    • Punched-out appearance.
    • Pulses are not palpable.
    • Associated skin changes (thin shiny skin, absence of hair, brittle nails)
  • Diagnosis:
    • The lesion can be easily identified clinically.
    • Arterial doppler and pulse volume recording for baseline assessment of blood flow.
    • Radiography may be necessary to rule out osteomyelitis.

 

Option A: Elevation of the affected extremity

  • Elevation of the affected extremity will decrease perfusion and causes ischemia.
  • Ulceration and gangrene may occur, resulting in the loss of either limb.

 

Option C: Oxygen therapy

  • Oxygen therapy has not been found to be treating arterial occlusive diseases in the best possible way.
  • Oxygen therapy is generally a safe option, but it can cause side effects, including dry or bloody nose, tiredness, and morning headaches.
  • Different types of devices can provide oxygen. Some use tanks of liquid or gas oxygen.

 

Option D: Heart transplantation

  • A compromised heart is replaced with a healthier heart in heart transplantation surgery.
  • It is done when the patient's condition does not improve with medications and other surgeries.
  • Risk includes multi-organ failure, infection, and even cancer.
  • A person has to take lifelong medications and immunosuppressants.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a known case of esophageal cancer presented to the surgical outpatient department for his elective esophagectomy. Preemptive ligation of the thoracic duct (TD) is occasionally performed during cardiothoracic procedures to prevent chylothorax. Landmarks for localizing this structure are thus crucial to the surgeon during such procedures. Which area is historically used for identifying this structure in the thorax?
questions.solution:
Option D: Poirier’s triangle

  • The thoracic duct can easily be identified within Poirier's triangle.
  • The borders of Poirier's triangle are:
    • Inferior-Arch of Aorta
    • Anterior- Left subclavian artery
    • Posterior- Vertebral column
  • The thoracic duct traverses the triangle on the esophagus that forms the floor of the triangle.

Option A: Calot's triangle

  • It is bounded:
    • Medially by the hepatic duct
    • Laterally by the cystic duct
    • Superiorly by cystic artery
  • It is dissected during cholecystectomy.

 

Option B: Hesselbach’s triangle

  • The borders of hesselbach's triangle are:
    • Medial border: Lateral margin of the rectus sheath. 
    • Superiolateral border: Inferior epigastric vessels.
    • Inferior border: Inguinal ligament
  • It is a potential area of weakness in the abdomen through which a hernia can protrude.

 

Option C: Passaro's triangle

  • The borders of Passaro's triangle are:
    • The confluence of the cystic and common bile duct superiorly
    • The second and third portions of the duodenum inferiorly
    • The neck and body of the pancreas medially, both dorsally and ventrally
  • It is a source of origin for most gastrinomas.

questions.text: A 31-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department after a burn on his left arm. He works in the glass manufacturing industry. He has a Hydrofluoric (HF) acid burn caused by the explosion of a 5-liter acid container. On physical examination, second and third-degree burns involving 5% of his TBSA are noted, as shown in the image below. The lesions induced by the HF burn on the left forearm and the trunk are immediately cleaned with plenty of water; then, his clothes are removed. The common electrolyte abnormality that can be expected in this patient would be?
questions.solution:
Option B: Hypocalcemia

  • At high concentrations, hydrofluoric acid can penetrate deep tissues and cause liquefaction necrosis.
  • It is an extremely toxic and damaging acid.
  • Hydrofluoric acid causes hypocalcemia
  • Insoluble calcium fluoride is the cause of hypocalcemia and pain associated with tissue toxicity.
  • Calcium-based therapies are the mainstay of treating Hydrofluoric acid burns
  • Topical application of calcium gluconate onto wounds and IV administration of calcium gluconate for systemic symptoms
  • Intra-arterial calcium gluconate infusion provides effective treatment of progressive tissue injury and intense pain

Option A: Hyponatremia

  • Burn patients have water loss and can cause hypernatremia, not hyponatremia.
  • This commonly occurs in severely burned patients due to insensible water loss.

Option C: Hyperkalemia

  • Hyperkalemia commonly occurs in electrical burns. This patient’s burn injury with hydrofluoric acid is more likely to cause hypocalcemia.

Option D: None of the above

  • Absorbed fluoride can result in life-threatening hypocalcemia by binding fluoride ions to calcium.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy comes to the hospital with painful benign bony swelling around the knee. Further investigations suggest that the patient present with osteochondroma. Which of the following will be responsible for the pain in such patients?
questions.solution:
Option A: Bursitis

  • Osteochondroma is usually a benign, painless swelling but the pain associated with it is usually due to bursitis.
  • The patient, usually in adolescence, presents with a painless swelling around a joint, usually around the knee.
  • The usual location is metaphyseal, but often it comes to lie as far as the diaphysis.
  • There may be signs of swelling. These are:
    • Pain due to bursitis swelling region or due to fracture of the exostosis.
    • Signs by compression of the neurovascular bundle of the limb.
    • Limitation of joint movements because of the mechanical block by the swelling.
  • Diagnosis is made by X-ray, where we can see a bony growth.
  • The lesion can be treated thoroughly, and the cavity, if it is big, is filled with bone grafts.
  • The prognosis is good.

Option B: Limitation of the joint movements

  • The limitation of joint movements is not a feature of osteochondroma.
  • Osteochondroma is usually a painless swelling tumor.
  • Limitation of joint movements can only be caused due to swelling, which causes the mechanical block.

Option C: Compression of the neurovascular bundle

  • Compression of the neurovascular bundle is a rare condition that causes exercise-induced pain.
  • It is caused by musculotendinous abnormalities.

Option D: Inflammation of the joint

  • Painful swelling in patients with osteochondroma is not due to the inflammation of the joint.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the hospital with complaints of severe back pain. He gives no history of any other abnormalities. He has no history of any chronic illness. He is otherwise vitally stable and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities. The X-ray revealed a similar image depicted here. The doctor is suspecting a malignant lesion. Which of the following will be the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Option D: Metastasis

  • The above-given image shows the metastasis of the vertebra.
  • The cancerous cells move from their original infected site of the body to the body and cause bone metastasis.
  • Spread is usually via the bloodstream; occasionally, visceral tumors spread directly to adjacent bones (e.g., the pelvis or ribs).
  • The commonest sites for bone metastasis are the vertebrae, pelvis, the proximal half of the femur, and the humerus.
  • Metastases are usually osteolytic, and pathological fractures are more common.
  • Bone resorption is due to the direct action of tumor cells or tumor-derived factors, which stimulates osteoclastic activity.
  • Osteoblastic lesions are not common; they usually occur in prostatic carcinoma.
  • The patients with bone metastasis survive for 6-45 months.

Option A: Osteosarcoma

  • Radiation-induced sarcoma (after 10-15 years of radiotherapy).
  • Radio-resistant bone tumor.
  • Matrix (osteoid) forms a bone tumor.
  • Osteosarcoma & soft tissue sarcomas are associated with germline retinoblastomas.

Option B: Synovial sarcoma

  • Misnomer (do not arise from synovium).
  • Characteristic translocation → (X:18) gives rise to the SYT-SSX fusion gene.
  • Mostly it occurs near the joint bursae.
  • It is a biphasic tumor with epithelial and mesenchymal components.
  • Treatment – excision.

Option C: Chondrosarcoma

  • A malignant bone tumor arises from cartilage cells.
  • Mottled calcification is seen in x-rays in such cases.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents to the office with complaints of burning pain in her hands for the past many months. He also complains of numbness, tingling, and burning. He also complains that his symptoms radiate to 3 digits and the radial ½ of the ring finger. He is a machinery worker. Examination shows the below findings. Which of the followings is not a cause for the development of this condition?
questions.solution:
Option D: Menorrhagia

  • Prolonged or heavy menstrual bleeding due to hormonal imbalance.
  • This condition is not related to the question
  • The image shows atrophy of thenar eminence, as seen in carpal tunnel syndrome.
  • It is due to the entrapment of the median nerve at the wrist beneath the flexor retinaculum.
  • Patients present with pain and paresthesia over the radial three and a half-digits.
  • There may be a weakness of thumb opposition.
  • In chronic cases, the thenar eminence is wasted.

Carpal Tunnel Syndrome:  This is an entrapment of the median nerve at the wrist beneath the flexor retinaculum.

  • Etiology Idiopathic (most common)
  • Endocrinal disorders—Hypothyroidism, diabetes mellitus, acromegaly
  • Hyperparathyroidism, pregnancy, rheumatoid arthritis, gout, amyloidosis, alcoholism, and sarcoidosis.
  • Injury-related—Synovitis of the tendon sheath
  • Malunited fractures (Colle's fracture)

Option A: Alcoholism

  • Alcohol causes carpal tunnel syndrome

Option B: Sarcoidosis

  • Sarcoidosis causes carpal tunnel syndrome

Option C: Gout

  • Gout causes carpal tunnel syndrome

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department after he fell while playing football and hit his right elbow. Physical examination reveals severe pain and tenderness in his elbow with a limited range of motion. An x-ray was performed that showed a fracture of the medial epicondyle of the right humerus. Which is the most common nerve injured in the given clinical scenario?
questions.solution:
Option A: Ulnar

  • The ulnar nerve (C8-T1) arises from the medial cord of the brachial plexus.
  • It descends downward in the upper arm medial to the axillary artery.
  • At the elbow, it runs posterior to the medial epicondyle of the humerus.
  • It passes through the two heads of the flexor carpi ulnaris and enters the flexor compartment of the forearm.
  • At the wrist, the ulnar nerve passes superficial to the flexor retinaculum and enters the hand through Guyon’s canal.
  • On the hand, it terminates by dividing into superficial and deep branches.
  • It supplies the following muscles:
  • Flexor carpi ulnaris.
  • Medial half of the flexor digitorum profundus.
  • Intrinsic muscles of the hand except for the thenar muscles and two lateral lumbricals.
  • The sensory supply of the ulnar nerve includes:
  • Palmar and dorsal aspects of the medial side of the hand.
  • Palmar and dorsal aspects of the ulnar one and half fingers.

  • As it passes behind the medial epicondyle of the humerus, the ulnar nerve is susceptible to injury in case of its fracture.

Option B: Median

  • The median nerve is injured in case of supracondylar fracture of the humerus.

Option C: Radial

  • The radial nerve is most commonly injured in case of a fracture of the humerus shaft.

Option D: Axillary

  • The axillary nerve is most commonly injured in case of a fracture of the humerus neck.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl with a genetic history of a known connective tissue disorder presents with kyphoscoliosis to a neurosurgeon. After a thorough evaluation by a groupof doctors, her surgery for correction of scoliosis deformity is planned under general anaesthesia in the coming week. During surgery, the anesthesiologist monitors evoked potential responses to prevent any iatrogenic neurological insult. Which type of evoked potential is used in this patient for monitoring?

choices.text: Both somatosensory evoked potentials and motor evoked potentials

questions.solution:
Option C: Both somatosensory evoked potentials and motor evoked potentials

  • Indications for intraoperative monitoring of evoked potentials (EPs) include surgical procedures associated with possible neurological injury:
    • Spinal fusion with instrumentation
    • Spine and spinal cord tumour resection
    • Brachial plexus repair
    • Thoracoabdominal aortic aneurysm repair
    • Epilepsy surgery
    • Cerebral tumour resection
  • Evoked potentials can detect ischemia in the spinal cord or cerebral cortex.
  • EP monitoring non-invasively assesses neural function by measuring electrophysiological responses to sensory or motor pathway stimulation.
    • Commonly monitored EPs are brainstem auditory evoked responses, sensory evoked potentials (SEPs), and increasingly motor evoked potentials (MEPs).
  • For SEPs, a brief electrical current is delivered to a sensory or mixed peripheral nerve by a pair of electrodes. If the intervening pathway is intact, a nerve action potential will be transmitted to the contralateral sensory cortex to produce an EP.
  • Although SEPs usually identify spinal-cord damage, sensory EP preservation does not guarantee normal motor function.
  • The advantage of using MEPs as opposed to SEPs for spinal-cord monitoring is that MEPs monitor the ventral spinal cord and, if sensitive and specific enough, can be used to indicate which patient might develop  a post-operative motor deficit.
  • Motor-evoked potentials are more sensitive to spinal-cord ischemia than are SEPs.
  • Multiple anecdotal reports and an increasing number of case series suggest that MEP monitoring during surgery on the spine or its blood supply is useful. These series suggest that combined SSEP monitoring and MEP monitoring may eliminate false negative monitoring patterns during spine surgery.

Option A: Somatosensory evoked potentials

  • Somatosensory evoked potentials are produced by stimulating a sensory system and recording the resulting electric responses at various sites along the sensory pathway up to and including the cerebral cortex.
  • They are useful for surgeries that risk sensory tracts, like spine surgeries, repair of thoracic and abdominal aorta aneurysms, brachial plexus exploration, or surgery of the brain area involving the thalamus or sensory tract.

Option B: Nerve action potential

  • Monitoring peripheral nerves via nerve action potential is used in patients with prolonged weakness and sensory loss after nerve injury.
  • Intraoperatively, the nerve is first stimulated proximal to the lesion, and the nerve action potential is recorded directly from the nerve distal to the lesion.
  • If there is nerve conduction across the lesion, lysis of the scar is performed, and the incision is closed, but if conduction does not occur, nerve cable grafting is performed on the section of the damaged nerve.

Option D: Brain stem auditory evoked potential

  • Brainstem auditory evoked potential is useful for procedures involving auditory pathways (like resection of acoustic neuronal) and posterior fossa surgeries.
  • They have also been used to assess the effects of general anesthesia on the brain.
  • The middle latency auditory EP may be a more sensitive indicator than the bispectral index regarding anaesthetic depth.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presented to the emergency with a complaint of fever and increasing pain in the right iliac fossa for one day. The inflamed appendix is seen on ultrasound, and he is diagnosed with subacute appendicitis. An immediate laparoscopic appendectomy is performed under general anaesthesia by the surgeon. The anaesthetist intubated the patient and connected him to the volume control mode of ventilation. Pneumoperitoneum was created, and the patient was positioned in a Trendelenburg position. During surgery, the patient started desaturating, and the capnogram suddenly showed a flat line. Which of the following is an exclusion to the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: Endobronchial intubation

  • Endobronchial intubation is placing the endobronchial tube (ETT) in either the left or right mainstream bronchus.
  • Endobronchial intubation will show a fall in EtCO2 but not a flat capnogram.
  • Effects of endobronchial intubation:
    • During single-lung ventilation, perfusion to the unventilated lung is still present. It leads to an intrapulmonary shunt and can precipitate hypoxemia.
    • Decreased pulmonary compliance and increased peak inspiratory pressure.
    • Decreased oxygen saturation.
    • The ventilated lung is at increased risk for barotrauma due to increased tidal volumes.
  • The characteristic features of the capnogram in endobronchial intubation depend on the extent of endobronchial intubation.
  • The EtCO2 can increase if the consequent lung ventilation results in hyperventilation.
  • If the ETT tube is far down, it will result in overall reduced ventilation (small tidal volumes), and then EtCO2 can decrease (not adequate ventilation).
  • If the endobronchial intubation results in airway obstruction, the capnogram may have prolonged phase 2 and phase 3 with an increased slope. Such capnograms occur during the Caesarian section with general anaesthesia.

  • A sudden drop of end-tidal CO2 to zero followed by an absence of a CO2 waveform is usually caused by the following:
    • Extubation
    • Oesophageal intubation
    • Complete breathing system disconnection
    • Ventilator malfunction
    • Obstructed critical tube

Option A: Disconnection of the endotracheal tube

  • There is a sudden drop in the end-tidal CO2, and a flat line can be seen on a capnograph.

Option B: Accidental extubation

  • It will result in an end-tidal CO2 value to zero and will be represented by a flat line on the capnograph.

Option C: Ventilation failure

  • It will cause an instant drop of EtCO2 to a value as low as zero and be seen as a flat line on a capnogram.

questions.text: An emergency laparoscopic cholecystectomy is planned for a 35-year-old female with a Bombay negative blood group . An estimate of a 500 ml of blood loss is made, and it is decided to arrange fluids to address it. What fluid will be arranged for the replacement of blood loss?
questions.solution:
The correct option for fluid replacement after an estimated blood loss of 500 ml would typically be Lactated Ringer's (LR) Solution.

Explanation of the Correct Option:

Lactated Ringer's (LR) Solution is a balanced crystalloid solution that contains sodium, chloride, potassium, calcium, and lactate. It closely resembles the electrolyte composition of extracellular fluid and is often chosen for fluid replacement in cases of blood loss.

The rationale behind using LR Solution for blood loss replacement includes:

  1. Electrolyte Balance: LR Solution provides a balanced electrolyte composition, which helps maintain proper electrolyte levels and minimize disturbances in the body's ion concentrations.

  2. Lactate Buffering: The inclusion of lactate in LR Solution helps buffer metabolic acidosis that can occur due to tissue hypoperfusion resulting from blood loss.

  3. Tissue Perfusion: The balanced electrolyte composition and lactate content in LR Solution contribute to maintaining tissue perfusion and oxygen delivery to tissues, which is crucial after blood loss.

  4. Compatibility with Blood Products: LR Solution is generally compatible with blood products, making it suitable for use alongside or after blood transfusions if necessary.

Now let's briefly discuss the other options:

  1. Normal Saline (0.9% NaCl): Normal saline is a common isotonic solution used for fluid replacement. However, it lacks the buffering capacity provided by LR Solution, which makes LR Solution a preferred choice, especially for larger volumes of fluid replacement.

    3. 5% Albumin Solution: Albumin is a colloid solution that can be used in certain situations, such as for hypoalbuminemia or in critical care. However, it might not be the first choice for routine blood loss replacement unless there are specific indications.

    4. Dextran Solution: Dextran is another colloid solution that can help increase blood volume. However, it is less commonly used nowadays due to potential side effects like anaphylactic reactions and interference with blood coagulation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with polytrauma after an RTA to the emergency department.  He is unconscious, and his blood pressure is not recordable. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation started according to ACLS guidelines. The monitor shows asystole. Which of the following is least likely to be included in the resuscitation guideline for this patient?

choices.text: Chest compressions should be started as a first-line measure
Advanced airway and capnography should be considered
Defibrillation is done as early as possible
Adrenaline is the drug of choice

questions.solution:
Option C: Defibrillation is done as early as possible

  • In Asystole, defibrillation is not done
  • Asystole:
    • Asystole is a cardiac arrest rhythm in which there is no discernible electrical activity on the ECG monitor. Consequently, it is sometimes referred to as a "flat line." Confirmation that a "flat line" is truly asystole is an important step in the ACLS protocol. Ensure that asystole is not another rhythm that looks like a "flat line." Fine VF can appear asystole, and a "flat line" on a monitor can be due to operator error or equipment failure
  • The following are common causes of an isoelectric line that are not asystole:
    • Loose or disconnected leads
    • Loss of power to the ECG monitor
    • Low signal gain on the ECG monitor.
  • Asystole for many patients results from a prolonged illness or cardiac arrest, and the prognosis is very poor.
  • Few patients will likely have a positive outcome, and successful treatment of cardiac arrest with asystole usually involves identifying and correcting an underlying cause.
  • Treatment of asystole:
    • A vasopressor is a medication that produces vasoconstriction and a rise in blood pressure. The vasopressor that is used for the treatment within the right branch of the Cardiac Arrest Algorithm is epinephrine. Epinephrine is primarily used for its vasoconstrictive effects.
    • Vasoconstriction is important during CPR because it will help increase blood flow to the brain and heart. When treating asystole, epinephrine can be given as soon as possible, but its administration should not delay the initiation or continuation of CPR. After the initial dose, epinephrine is given every 3-5 minutes.
    • Rhythm checks should be performed after 2 minutes (5 cycles) of CPR. Limit rhythm checks to less than 10 seconds to minimise interruptions in CPR. Pulse checks should be performed when a rhythm check reveals a rhythm change to an organised rhythm that could generate a pulse.
    • Defibrillation is not done.

Option A: Chest compressions should be started as a first-line measure

  • Chest compression is an essential step as the priority in cardiac arrest

Option B: Advanced airway and capnography should be considered

  • The ACLS guidelines prioritise airway securing in managing a patient with cardiac arrest.
  • Capnography provides a noninvasive estimate of cardiac output and organ perfusion during cardiac arrest. It can therefore be used to monitor the quality of CPR and predict the return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC).

Option D: Adrenaline is the drug of choice

  • Adrenaline is the drug of choice for the management of shock in the pediatric population with cardiac arrest.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man was diagnosed with acoustic neuroma and was referred to the radiological department for an X-ray of the internal auditory canal. Which of the following is the preferred view for this case?
questions.solution:
Option C: Stenver's view

  • The Stenvers view is an oblique radiographic projection that shows the bony labyrinth, internal acoustic meatus, and petrous temporal bone.
  • Due to significantly improved anatomic information, fine slice multi-detector CT of the petrous bone has superseded the Stenver view.
  • The modified Stenvers view has replaced it for evaluating electrode placement after the insertion of a cochlear implant.
  • The central beam is 12 degrees cephalad and 45 degrees cephalad from the IR plane.
  • An oblique coronal projection can simulate a similar projection on reconstructed CT images.

Figure 1 Stenver's view
 

Option A: Caldwell's view

 

 

Figure 2 Caldwell's view

  • Caldwell's view is a caudally angled radiograph, and its posteroanterior projection exposes the orbits to the least amount of radiation possible.
  • The paranasal sinuses, particularly the frontal sinus, are easier to visualize at this angle.
  • Assessing four inflammatory disorders, including sinusitis, secondary osteomyelitis, and sinus polyps or cysts, might be helpful.
  • This view is the best for visualizing the frontal sinus.

 

Option B: Water's view

 

Figure 3 Water's view

  • An angled posteroanterior radiograph of the skull with the patient looking slightly upwards is known as the occipitomental (OM) or Waters view.
  • In addition to facial fractures, it can be used to check for blowout fractures of the orbit.
  • It is the view of choice for visualizing the maxillary sinus.

Option D: Lateral view

Figure 4 Lateral view

  • A non-angled lateral radiograph of the skull is called the lateral skull view.
  • This view does not try to highlight any one area of the skull; instead, it gives a general overview of the complete skull.
  • In addition to evaluating for neoplastic alterations and Paget disease, this projection is also utilized to check for skull fractures. A horizontal beam lateral projection in a trauma situation may show air-fluid levels in the first sphenoid sinus, a sign of a basal skull fracture.
  • This view is also helpful in visualizing the sella turcica, sphenoid sinus, and nose fractures.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents to the emergency ward with complaints of bilateral flank pain for one day. The patient gives a history of no other abnormalities. His blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg, and his pulse is 89/M. On examination, there is a pulsatile abdominal mass. The patient's contrast-enhanced CT abdomen is done, shown in the image given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Ruptured aortic aneurysm

Ruptured Abdominal aortic aneurysm (RAAA)

  • This is a case of ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm

  • CT scan (most precise)

  • Ruptured Abdominal aorta aneurysm presents with a classical triad of pain in the flank or back, hypotension, and a pulsatile abdominal mass; however, only about half have the full triad. Tachycardia develops. Shock may occur.

  • The patient will complain of the pain and may feel cold, sweaty, and faint on standing.

  • The following symptoms are listed with an approximate frequency of presentation.

    • Abdominal pain (60%)

    • Back pain (70%)

    • Syncope (30%)

    • Vomiting (20%).

Primary signs of abdominal aorta aneurysm rupture-

  • Periaortic stranding

  • Retroperitoneal Hematoma

  • Extravasated night of iv contrast

  • Secondary signs of Ruptured Abdominal aortic aneurysm

  • High attenuating crescent

  • Focal discontinuity of intimate calcification

  • Draped aorta

Option B: Aortic dissection

  • Longitudinal intimal tear forming a false lumen. Associated with hypertension, bicuspid aortic valve, inherited connective tissue disorder (Marfan syndrome)

  • Can present with sudden onset chest pain radiating to back and sometimes with unequal BP in arms.

  • Chest x-ray show mediastinal widening.

    • it is of two types

    • Stanford type A (proximal) involves ascending aorta, and may extend to the aortic arch or descending aorta.

    • Stanford type B involves only desending aorta(below the left subclavian artery can be treated by beta blockers, then vasodilators

Option C: Acute pancreatitis

  • Auto-digestion of pancreas by pancreatic enzymes

  • Causes: idiopathic, gallstones, ethanol, trauma, steroids, mumps, autoimmune disease, scorpion sting, Hypercalcemia, ERCP, Drugs(sulfa drugs, NRTIs and protease inhibitors)

  • Increased serum Amylase or lipase.

  • In acute pancreatitis, the patient presents with persistent vomiting and epigastric tenderness.

Option D: Angiomyolipoma

  • A benign tumor of fat and muscle tissue that usually is found in the kidney. Angiomyolipomas rarely cause symptoms, but may bleed or grow large enough to be painful or cause kidney failure.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man presents to the primary health care centre for a yearly routine check-up. He complains of fatigue, abdominal bloating, and intermittent constipation. On examination, his BP is 130/80, pulse rate is 88 bpm, and he is lethargic, pale, and anxious look. A barium study is advised. A barium study image is shown below. According to findings, what is the most likely diagnosis in a given image?
questions.solution:
Option C: CA-colon

  • The most likely diagnosis here is CA-colon.
  • The Radiological hallmarks of the classic colonic apple core lesion are short, sharply defined regions of annular colonic narrowing with overhanging margins, ulcerated mucosa, and eccentric, irregular lumen. An apple core lesion can have several causes, the most serious being malignant neoplasm.

  • Colon cancer is a type of cancer that begins in the colon. It is the final part of the digestive tract. Colon cancer usually affects older adults, yet it can occur at any age.
  • Clinical features may include spurious diarrhoea, weight loss, fatigue, and tenesmus.
  • Family history is an important risk factor.
  • Treatment for colon cancer generally includes surgery to remove cancer, radiation therapy, and chemotherapy.

Option A: Sigmoid volvulus

  • The largest and most dilated bowel loops are seen with sigmoid volvulus with loss of haustra.
  • The coffee bean sign is a radiologic feature of sigmoid volvulus.

 

Option B: Intussusception

  • Intussusception occurs when peristalsis pulls one segment of the bowel into itself or a neighbouring loop of the bowel.
  • The claw sign is a radiologic feature of intussusception.

Option D: Crohn's disease

  • Crohn's disease causes inflammation of the tissues in the digestive tract, mainly involving the terminal ileum and parts of the colon.
  • Kantor string sign is a characteristic feature of Crohn's disease.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient chronic alcoholic male, after a large binge of alcohol, presents to the emergency department in a subconscious state. He vomited several times, a few of them mixed with blood. He had a history of heartburn and dyspeptic symptoms for the past few tears. On physical exam, he had a temperature of 102°F, a pulse of 110/minute, a respiratory rate of 20 per minute, and a blood pressure of 90/60 mm Hg. On physical examination, there was abdominal guarding and tenderness. A plane-erect chest X-ray reveals air under the diaphragm. The probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Option A: Perforated peptic ulcer

  • History of:
  • Heartburn and dyspepsia.
  • Acute onset of bloody vomiting after binge alcohol.
  • General and physical examination findings and air under the diaphragm on chest X-ray.
  • All these indicate the air under the diaphragm on chest X-ray, and all these indicate the perforation of peptic ulcer.

  • In the above diagram, the arrow shows the air under the diaphragm, a suggestive feature of perforated peptic ulcers.
  • The above clinical picture suggests a perforated peptic ulcer, the most common cause of pneumoperitoneum (air under the diaphragm).
  • Perforation results in pneumoperitoneum, and the best view to see this is a chest x-ray in an erect position which detects air under the domes of the diaphragm.
  • Risk factors for peptic ulcer perforation are:
  • Old age more than 60.
  • Smoking.
  • Helicobacter pylori infection.
  • Use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.
  • Chronic stress.

Option B: Acute MI

  • Acute MI have radiating pain from the chest towards the left arm.
  • There is no radiological finding on x-rays in MI.

Option C: Dissected abdominal aorta

  • It also has no findings on x-rays.
  • It has retrosternal pain, which is excruciating pain.

questions.text: A couple complains of inability to conceive despite staying together for 4 years and having unprotected intercourse. All the tests of the wife are normal. Her husband began puberty at the age of 13 years. He is a cyclist by profession. He does not smoke, drink or take any medications. Semen analysis shows a volume of 0.8ml, and sperm count is 0, fructose is absent. What is the next best step for this patient to diagnose his cause of fertility?
questions.solution:
Option B: Ultrasound for obstruction

  • In this case, the patient has no sperm count and absent fructose in the semen.
  • Absent fructose in semen indicates either a congenital absence of seminal vesicle or an obstruction in the ejaculatory duct system.
  • The best way to detect obstruction is to perform a transrectal ultrasound.
  • Transrectal ultrasound (TRUS) in a male shows:
  • Seminal vesicles, prostate and ejaculatory duct obstruction.
  • This should be done when there is
    • Azoospermia or severe oligospermia with a normal testicular volume.
    • Ejaculatory duct abnormality (cysts, dilatation or calcification).
    • Genital abnormality (Hypospadias).

Option A: Testicular FNAC 

  • It is a qualitative and quantitative test that gives useful information on both azoospermia and oligospermia.
  • It provides cytologic and histologic diagnoses.
  • It is used for the evaluation of male infertility.
  • It helps to differentiate a post testicular, obstructive aetiology of male infertility from an intrinsic testicular cause.
  • However the next best step here is a TRUS

Option C: Local palpation of vas

  • During ejaculation, smooth muscle in the walls of the vas deferens contracts reflexively, thus propelling the sperm forward.
  • It is least commonly palpated during routine physical examination.
  • However next best step here is an ultrasound

Option D: Karyotyping

  • It can be used to detect male infertility.
  • As azoospermia can be a genetic disorder.
  • So, it detects male infertility due to genetic causes.
  • However, it is not always required, specifically here as an obstructive cause is suspected.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman who is pregnant for the first time visits the gynecology outpatient department with a complaint of not having her menstrual period for 36 weeks. She also reports experiencing abdominal pain on and off for the last seven days and has a history of Strassman metroplasty. During the abdominal examination, uterine contractions are observed, and the cervix is found to be dilated to 3 cm. What is the recommended course of action in this case?

choices.text: Induction of labor with prostaglandins after pelvic assessment
Start oxytocin drip and monitor closely.
Give antispasmodics and send the patient back.

questions.solution:
Option B: Elective Lower segment caesarian section(LSCS)

  • The patient has presented in labour with uterine contractions and dilatation of the cervix.
  •  Unification surgical procedures (Strassman operation, Tompkins operation, or Jones’ wedge metro­plasty operation) or Hysteroscopic resection of uterine sep­tum are the corrective procedures for Uterine anomalies.
  • These are done for a history of recurrent pregnancy losses.
  • Therefore, the mode of delivery in all these corrective procedures is Caesarean section due to the risk of scar rupture in labour.

Indications for LSCS

  • Cephalopelvic disproportion or contracted pelvis
  • Placenta previa
  • Fetal hypoxia
  • Previous Caesarean: >=2, previous classical Caesarean, previous hysterotomy
  • Pelvic tumours
  • Active genital herpes
  • Transverse lie, complicated breech, non-cephalic presenting twin
  • Uterine rupture
  • Scarred uterus such as previous myomectomy, unification surgery
  • Other medical or surgical complications necessitating surgery

Option A: Induction of labour with prostaglandins after pelvic assessment

  • Induction or augmentation of labour are contraindicated in such cases as vaginal delivery must not be done

Option C: Start oxytocin drip and monitor closely

  • Oxytocin is a drug used for augmentation of uterine contraction
  • It is contraindicated in patients who have a history of previous corrective uterine surgery.
  • As it may lead to rupture of the previous uterine scar.

Option D: Give antispasmodics and send the patient back

  • It is an incorrect option because there is no role of antispasmodics or even tocolytics at 36 weeks in labour.

questions.text: A woman presents 4 months after delivery of a healthy full-term newborn. She complains that she has not had her periods since delivery. She is exclusively breastfeeding her infant. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of her amenorrhea?
questions.solution:
Option A: Prolactin-induced inhibition of GnRH

  • Lactational amenorrhea:
  • The physiological basis of anovulation and amenorrhea is elevated levels of serum prolactin associated with suckling.
  • Elevated serum prolactin levels suppress the normal pattern of pulsatile release of GnRH and hence LH and prevent the normal growth of follicles.
  • With the cessation of breastfeeding, the pulsatile pattern of LH returns to normal, sensitivity to estrogen negative feedback declines, follicle growth can continue, and ovulation will occur.

Option B: Prolactin-induced stimulation of FSH

  • Prolactin inhibits the release of GnRH and thus reduces the secretion of LH and FSH, both of which result in anovulation and amenorrhea.

Option C: Inadequate breastfeeding

  • Adequate and exclusive breastfeeding is important for the occurrence of this amenorrhea and resulting contraception.
  • Suckling during lactation reduces GnRH secretion, which leads to a decrease in the levels of LH secreted from the pituitary and estrogen levels.
  • It lasts for 3 to 6 months or longer.
  • Three criteria, all of which must be met to ensure adequate protection from an unplanned pregnancy:
  •  1) amenorrhea
  •  2) fully or nearly fully breastfeeding (no interval of >4–6 hours between breastfeeds)
  •  3) <6 months postpartum.

Option D: Oxytocin-induced inhibition of FSH

  • Oxytocin does not stimulate or inhibit the release of FSH.
  • The two main physical functions of oxytocin are
    • stimulating uterine contractions in labour and childbirth
    • to stimulate contractions of breast tissue to aid in lactation after childbirth.

questions.text: A primigravida presents in active labor at full-term pregnancy. The pelvic examination reveals a 5 cm dilated cervix, with face presentation such that the chin is placed anteriorly in the pelvis and a clinically adequate pelvis. Electronic fetal monitoring shows reactive fetal tracing. Which of the following is the most appropriate step in managing this patient?

choices.text: Perform forceps rotation in the second stage of labor to convert mentum anterior to mentum posterior and to allow vaginal delivery
Allow to labor spontaneously until complete cervical dilation is achieved, and then perform an internal podalic version with breech extraction

questions.solution:
Option B: Allow spontaneous progress of labour

  • If the face presentation is mento-anterior, then vaginal delivery is possible.
  • Sub-mentovertical (10 cm) or sub-mentobregmatic (9.5 cm) diameters of engagement are suitable for vaginal delivery.
  • The sterno-bregmatic (16–18 cm) is the engaging diameter in the mento-posterior position because the chest and head both attempt to cross the brim simultaneously.
  • For mento-posterior, it is recommended to have an elective caesarean section as the engaging diameter is greater than the pelvic inlet as well as outlet.

 

Option A: Perform immediate cesarean section

  • Face presentation with mento-posterior warrants immediate cesarean.

 

Option C: Perform forceps rotation in the second stage of labour to convert mentum anterior to mentum posterior and to allow vaginal delivery

  • Because the mentum is already anterior and may be delivered vaginally, conversion to mento-posterior is not performed because it would put the face in an unfavourable position.

 

Option D: Allow to labour spontaneously until complete cervical dilation is achieved, and then perform an internal podalic version with breech extraction

  • For face presentation, an internal podalic version is not performed.
  • Transverse lie in the second twin is the only indication of IPV.

questions.text: A primigravida came with complaints of pain abdomen at 39 weeks of pregnancy. The doctor examines and finds that there are regular contractions every half an hour and the cervix admits one finger. This stage is said to be prolonged if it lasts more than?
questions.solution:
Option D: 20 hours

  •  The stage described in the question is the latent phase of labour which starts with the onset of true Labour pains till the start of active labour (cervical dilatation of 4 cms).
  • True Labour pains here are suggested by uterine contractions occurring at intervals and associated with cervical dilatation
  • Latent phase in a Primigravida is prolonged if its more than 20 hours, multigravida if its more than 14 hours

 

Labour Pattern

Primigravida

Multigravida

Prolonged latent phase

> 20hours

>14 hr

Protracted dilatation

< 1.2 cm/hr

< 1.5 cm/hr

Protracted descent

< 1 cm/hr

< 2 cm/hr

Arrest of dilatation

No dilatation for > 2 hrs

Arrest of descent

No descent for > 1 hr

 

 

Stages of Labour

First

 

 From the onset of true labour pains to full cervical dilatation

 
Second

 

 Full cervical dilatation to delivery of the baby

 
Third

 

 Delivery of baby to delivery of the placenta

 
Fourth

 

 Stage of observation, till 1 hour after delivery of the placenta

 

 

First stage is further divided into

Latent phase

 

 Cervical dilatation ≤ 3 cm

 

 Irregular contractions
  • Tocolytics in preterm labour given only in this phase
Active phase

 

 Cervical dilatation ≥ 4 cm

 

 Tocolytics in preterm labour cannot be given in the act

 

 

Option A: 3 Hours

  •  The stage described in the question is the latent phase of labour which starts with the onset of true Labour pains till the start of active labour.
  • The true answer is 20 hours, not 3 hours

 

Option B: 8 Hours

  •  The stage described in the question is the latent phase of labour which starts with the onset of true Labour pains till the start of active Labour
  • 8 hours is not the correct option

 

Option C: 12 Hours

  • The stage described in the question is the latent phase of labour which starts with the onset of true Labour pains till the start of active labour (cervical dilatation of 4 cms).
  • True Labour pains here are suggested by uterine contractions occurring at intervals and associated with cervical dilatation

questions.text: A 25-year-old pregnant female (gravida 1, para 0) at 32 weeks of gestation has come to the hospital for regular follow-up. She is diagnosed with gestational diabetes at 26 weeks of gestation. Her Hb1c is 6.8%. Her fundal height is found to be 36 cm, and her abdominal skin appears excessively stretched and shiny. Her previous antenatal USG reports were normal. What could be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Polyhydramnios

  • Fundal height normally corresponds (in centimetres) to gestational age in weeks (from 16 to 36 weeks).
  • The possible reason for increased fundal height could be:
    • Polyhydramnios
    • Twin pregnancy
    • Fibroids
    • Big baby (foetal macrosomia)
    • Hydatidiform mole
  • According to the above-given case scenario, the most probable cause is polyhydramnios as the patient is a known case of gestational diabetes which is a risk factor for polyhydramnios.
  • Polyhydramnios presents clinically as-
    • Fundal height is more than the normal level according to gestational age.
    • Excessively stretched and shiny abdominal skin
    • Respiratory distress
  • Diabetes, foetal anomalies, and foetal infections are risk factors for polyhydramnios.
  • Complications of polyhydramnios include preterm labour, cord prolapse, and malpresentation.

Option A: Uterine fibroids

  • Uterine fibroid doesn't suddenly appear during pregnancy. It must be present before the onset of pregnancy.
  • Normal previous USG report rules out fibroid.

Option C: Twin gestation

  • Twin gestation may also present with overdistension but should have been diagnosed on an earlier scan.

Option D: Oligohydramnios

  • Oligohydramnios is associated with decreased fundal height according to gestational weeks.
  • Features of excessively stretched and shiny abdominal skin are not consistent with oligohydramnios.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the emergency department complaining of fever and lower abdominal pain for the last 1 day. She delivered a preterm boy of 33 weeks gestation 2 days ago via cesarean delivery. Her temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals uterine tenderness and purulent lochia. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Clindamycin plus gentamicin

This patient’s symptoms of fever, uterine tenderness, and purulent vaginal discharge suggest endometritis/ chorioamnionitis.

  • Risk factors for endometritis:
  • Prolonged rupture of membranes
  • Cesarean birth
  • Vacuum or forceps-assisted vaginal delivery
  • Prolonged labour
  • Chorioamnionitis
  • Clinical features include:
  • Fever
  • Purulent lochia
  • Lower abdominal pain
  • Uterine tenderness
  • Tachycardia
  • Treatment
    • Antibiotics are used in case of the treatment of endometritis. The combination of clindamycin and gentamicin is the first-line treatment.

Option A: Analgesics

  • Analgesics are not enough. Antibiotics are required to eradicate bacterial infection.

Option B: Betamethsone

  • Steroids are contraindicated in bacterial infections

Option D: Fluconazole
