  • Topical clotrimazole or oral fluconazole treats vulvovaginal candidiasis, which presents as thick white vaginal discharge.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female was evaluated in the postpartum unit 2 hours after delivery with hypotension, tachycardia and vaginal bleeding. The uterus is enlarged and boggy. She receives oxytocin during the third stage of labour. Oxytocin is a uterotonic. Uterotonics are drugs that stimulate uterine contractions. About uterotonics, all of the following statements are true except:

choices.text: Oxytocin sensitivity is increased during delivery.
Prostaglandins may be given for inducing abortion during the second trimester.
Lactation and genital stimulation enhances oxytocin release
Oxytocin is used for inducing abortion in the first trimester

questions.solution:
Option D: Oxytocin is used for inducing abortion in the first trimester

Oxytocin receptors, and hence oxytocin sensitivity, are maximum during advanced pregnancy. Oxytocin is a great drug for inducing and augmenting labour in the last trimester. However, use in the first trimester will not be beneficial as oxytocin receptors are negligible.

Drugs used for Medical Abortion

  • Tab Mifepristone Orally
    • It is an antiprogestin that kills the fetus
    • Dose is 200 - 600 mg
    • This is followed 24-48 hrs later by misoprostol
  • Tab Misoprostol (PGE1) Vaginally
    • PG that causes uterine contractions and expels products
    • Dose: 800 µg
    • Expels the fetus
    • Vaginal route is best
  • Prostaglandins: method of choice for T2 abortions
    • Misoprostal [PGE 1]: Orally, Rectally or Vaginally
    • Dinoprostone [PGE 2]: Gel Form is given vaginally, induces uterine contractions & causes expulsion of the fetus
    • Carboprost [PGF2 a] : IM only

Option A: Oxytocin sensitivity is increased during delivery

  • Oxytocin receptors, and hence oxytocin sensitivity, are maximum during advanced pregnancy; thus, it is a great drug for inducing and augmenting labour in the last trimester.

Option B: Prostaglandins may be given for inducing abortion during the second trimester

  • Prostaglandins are used for second-trimester abortions.
  • Prostaglandins increases uterine tone and softens the cervix during labour

Option C: Lactation and genital stimulation enhance oxytocin release

  • Nipple and genital stimulation induces oxytocin release

questions.text: An 18-year-old primigravida, at 30 weeks of gestation, comes to the outpatient department for a routine antenatal check-up. On ultrasound with antenatal doppler, her fetal parameters correspond to 30 weeks, and the umbilical artery shows an S/D ratio of 2.8. She is advised to continue with her prenatal supplements and daily fetal movement counts. The patient returns after 4 weeks, and her ultrasound is repeated. She has no high-risk factors and is perceiving fetal movements well. What is the S/D ratio in the umbilical artery expected at this visit?

choices.text: Constant at 2.8 with a diastolic notch

questions.solution:
Option B: <2.8

  • The systolic/diastolic (S/D) ratio of flow velocities is measured as an index of peripheral resistance.
  • The S/D ratio in the umbilical artery normally declines from approximately 4 to <3 during 20 to after 30 weeks of gestation.
  • Finally, it reaches 2 at birth.
  • As this patient presents at 34 weeks of gestation, the S/D ratio of the umbilical artery at this visit must be <2.8.
  • Doppler indices show a continuous reduction throughout the second half of pregnancy without any plateau or increase near term.
  • The S/D ratio of the uterine artery usually remains unchanged between 1.8 to 1.9.

Option A: >2.8

  • The S/D ratio must have decreased drom last visit and not increased

Option C: Constant at 2.8

  • The S/D ratio declines continuously throughout the 2nd half of pregnancy.

Option D: Constant at 2.8 with a diastolic notch

  • A diastolic notch is the earliest sign of fetal compromise.
  • But this patient perceives fetal movement well, and there are no other risk factors for fetal compromise.

questions.text: A 29-year-old married woman presents with the complaint of infertility. She is unable to conceive, has regular menstrual cycles, and has mild dysmenorrhea. Her pelvic scan shows an intramural fibroid of 3 cm and a follicular ovarian cyst. A tubal assessment by HSG is normal as well. The husband's semen analysis is normal, and so is his hormonal profile. Which of these is the most likely cause of infertility?
questions.solution:
Option C: Endometriosis

A young woman with infertility with regular menstrual cycles, normal pelvic imaging, and normal-spermic partner with or without dysmenorrhea satisfies the criteria of unexplained infertility, and the prevalence of endometriosis in such cases is as high as 50%.

Presentation of endometriosis:

  • Infertility
  • Pain: dysmenorrhea (congestive type secondary dysmenorrhea), dyspareunia (in lesions over POD), or chronic pelvic pain
  • Pelvic mass
  • Menstrual abnormalities
  • GI symptoms: pain, nausea, vomiting, bloating, distension
  • Specific symptoms of extra pelvic endometriosis
  • The examination may reveal a cystic pelvic mass suggestive of ovarian endometriosis or a fixed retroverted uterus (suggestive of pelvic adhesions), tenderness or nodularity in POD (suggestive of peritoneal deposits).

https://www.virginiacenterforwomen.com/blog/458705-what-is-endometriosis\

Option A: Polycystic ovarian disease

This option is false because the patient has regular cycles, which almost rule out PCOD. Also, PCOD is not associated with dysmenorrhea; here, no polycystic ovarian morphology is seen on USG (although not necessary for diagnosing PCOD).

Option B: Fibroid uterus

This option is false because the fibroid here is too small to be significant and would be the last cause of infertility here when all other reasons are ruled out.

Option D: Tubal factor

This option is false because normal HSG rules out the tubal factor.

questions.text: Which type of ovarian tumor is most likely to cause torsion?
questions.solution:
Option A : Dermoid tumor

The most common ovarian tumor to undergo torsion is a benign teratoma (dermoid). It is also the most common ovarian tumor seen in pregnant women.

Dermoid cyst / Benign cystic teratoma

  • All 3 germ cell layers present
    • Endoderm : bone and teeth
    • Mesoderm : sebaceous secretions
    • Ectoderm : hair, endocrine glands
  • 10-15% are bilateral
  • Can have malignant transformation →Sq cell carcinoma
  • Most common ovarian tumors in pregnancy
  • Most common ovarian tumors to undergo torsion.

Adnexal torsion

  • Result of increased weight of the ovary may be due to reduced venous return from the ovary
  • More often in the right adnexa, presumably because the sigmoid colon limits the mobility of the left ovary.
  • Occurs when the ovary is enlarged secondary to cysts or neoplasms.
  • Reduces venous return from the ovary.
  • Hemorrhagic infarction within the ovary may occur when the torsion is persistent.

Option B : Dysgerminoma

  • Dysgerminoma can also undergo torsion but less likely compared to teratoma

Option C and D : Ovarian fibroma and Brenners tumor

  • Ovarian fibroma and brenner tumors are less likely to undergo torsion

questions.text: A 55-year-old post-menopausal woman presents to the gynaecology department with complaints of pruritic white lesions on the vulva over the last 6 months. A punch biopsy of a representative area is obtained after the examination. She is suspected of having Lichen sclerosis. Which of the following histologic findings is consistent with the diagnosis of the patient's current condition?

choices.text: Blunting or loss of Rete pegs
Increase in the number of cellular layers in the epidermis

questions.solution:
Option A: Blunting or loss of Rete pegs

  • Lichen sclerosis is a precancerous condition of the vulva. The lesions of small bluish-white papules coalesce into white papules.
  • The histological appearance of lichen sclerosis consists of moderate hyperkeratosis with epithelial thinning, acanthosis, basement membrane thickening, and loss of rete hyalinization in the dermis.

  • The symptoms include pruritus ('Itch-scratch' cycle), dyspareunia, and dysuria.
  • Anyone can get lichen sclerosis, but post-menopausal women are at higher risk.
  • Lichen sclerosis can become cancerous over the years. It can cause squamous cell carcinoma.
  • Carcinoma of the vulva of keratinizing types, which is unifocal and seen in older patients, is found in areas adjacent to lichen sclerosis and squamous hyperplasia.
  • Lichen sclerosis can be diagnosed by skin biopsy.
  • Treatment commonly used is testosterone cream, cortisone cream, or ointment.

 

Option B: Excessive hyalinization

  • Excessive hyalinization is not a consistent finding in lichen sclerosis.
  • However, hyperkeratosis can be present.

 

Option C: Acute inflammatory infiltration

  • The early picture may show some oedema and inflammation.
  • However, the inflammation is lichenoid, and lymphocytic infiltrate is usually seen.

 

Option D: Increase the number of cellular layers in the epidermis

  • Some degree of epidermal hyperplasia may be present in lichen sclerosis, but it is not a common finding.

questions.text: A 38- year woman operated on a lower segment uterine fibroid. She had an uneventful surgery. Post-operatively the urine output decreased, up to 20 ml/hr. Rapid IV fluid infusions were given with an injection of Lasix, and output increased to 70 ml/hr. The urine was clear. A patient complained of flank pain which was gradually progressing. What is the most common cause of such presentation?
questions.solution:
Option B: Unilateral ureteric injury.

  • Decreased urine post-operatively and flank pain point towards ureteric injury. Here flank pain usually suggests that the ureter has been ligated and is causing proximal hydroureteronephrosis. Increased urine output with fluid and Lasix is due to increased urine production and excretion from the normal ureter.
  • Bladder injury usually presents with decreased output, hematuria, or urinary leak from the vault.
  • Management of postoperative ureteric injury:
    • CT urogram and a urinalysis.
    • If an obstruction is noted on a CT scan, it is usually present near the ureterovesical junction. The immediate step is the attempted passage of a stent through the ureter under cystoscopic guidance. If a catheter can be passed through the ureter, it should be left in place for at least 4 to 6 weeks, allowing sutures to absorb and the obstruction or kinking to release.
    • If the catheter cannot be passed through the ureter, the best course is to perform abdominal exploratory surgery and repair the ureter at the site of obstruction.
    • A temporary percutaneous nephrostomy tube may be considered if exploratory surgery cannot be performed immediately.

Option A: Acute renal failure

  • Acute renal failure causes the following symptoms:
    • Oliguria.
    • Oedema.
    • Fatigue or tiredness.
    • Shortness of breath.
    • Confusion.
    • Nausea.
    • Seizures or comas in severe cases.
    • Chest pain or pressure.
  • Progressive flank pain is not a symptom of acute renal failure.

Option C: Bladder injury

  • It is a false statement as bladder injury causes hematuria, not oliguria, and flank pain is unrelated to bladder injury.

Option D: Haemorrhage

  • Bleeding is not related to progressive flank pain. It may cause anaemia, hypovolemia, shock etc.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with her husband due to vomiting, constipation and abdominal distention. A Plain X-ray of the abdomen reveals multiple air-fluid levels. Vaginal examination shows a loop of extra tissue resembling the intestine protruding from the cervix. Which of the following history must be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: History of dilatation and curettage

Figure: The uterine perforation after dilation and curettage

  • This patient has presented with symptoms of intestinal obstruction with the intestine protruding through the cervix, suggestive of uterine perforation. In the non-pregnant state, perforation of the uterus usually occurs during dilatation and curettage.
  • Prolapsed intestines could be due to evacuation pull by an ovum forceps through the perforation or by a suction curette.
  • Dilatation and curettage procedures are primary tools for the diagnostic evaluation and treatment of abnormal uterine bleeding.
  • Perforation of the uterus is common during a state of pregnancy or malignancy (Soft Uterus) and more common in medical termination of pregnancy for advanced gestation.
  • The atrophic uterus of post-menopausal women may also be perforated easily during D&C.
  • IUCD insertion also causes perforation, especially if done in a hurry.
  • In case of a perforation, if the uterus is empty, simple observation will suffice. However, in complicated cases hysterectomy is done. Often abdominal viscera prolapse through the perforation, and hence a laparotomy is done to repair the defect of the bowel or bladder.

Option A: History of IUCD insertion

  • IUCD insertion can also cause uterine perforation, but it is unlikely to damage to this extent.

Option C: History of laparoscopic surgery

  • Multiple types of complications can occur during laparoscopic surgeries. Perforation of viscus is one of them.
  • But laparoscopic surgery would not cause an unnoticed perforation of the uterus or any other organ as the procedure is done under vision.

Option D: History suggestive of carcinoma endometrium

  • Endometrial cancer can invade through the myometrium but not cause such an acute adverse injury.

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida presents to the maternity emergency with active labor at the 38th week of gestation. The patient is shifted to the labor room and is being managed on escalating doses of oxytocin. The patient's pulse is 98/min, blood pressure is 110/70, respiratory rate is 18/min, and temperature is 37.2 C. Pelvic examination shows a fully dilated cervix and vertex positioned above station 0 with caput. CTG shows persistent decelerations after each contraction. Which of the following is the next best step in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: Cesarean section

  • The patient is showing persistent late type of decelerations suggestive of non-reassuring fetal heart status. Therefore delivery must be expedited with either instrumental delivery or caesarean section.
  • Since an important prerequisite for forceps or ventouse application is that the fetal skull should have reached the pelvic floor (+2 station or below), but in this patient, the head is above station 0, so ideal management is emergency LSCS  (lower segment cesarean section).

Indications of LSCS

  • Cephalopelvic disproportion or contracted pelvis
  • Placenta previa
  • Fetal hypoxia
  • Previous cesarean  >2, previous classical cesarean, previous hysterotomy
  • Pelvic tumours
  • Active genital herpes
  • Transverse lie, complicated breech, non-cephalic presenting twin
  • Uterine rupture
  • Scarred uterus such as previous myomectomy or unification surgery
  • Other medical or surgical complications necessitating surgery

Option A: Increase oxytocin drop rate

  • Increasing the oxytocin drop rate will increase uterine contractions, which may lead to quick progression towards delivery, but decelerations and non-assuring fetal heart status require immediate delivery.

Option B: Ventouse delivery

  • In ventouse delivery, the plastic or metallic cup is attached to the head of the baby with suction. However, it requires a fetal station of +2 or below. Therefore it cannot be suggested in this case.

Option C: Outlet forceps delivery

  • Forceps delivery is indicated when delivery is arrested while the skull has reached the pelvic floor and is visible without separating the labia.
  • In this case, the fetal head is above station 0, so forceps delivery cannot be done.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents to the hospital with a history of missed periods and a positive pregnancy test. She has been on oral anticoagulation after a valve replacement surgery 1 year back. After confirming viability, the doctor switches her to heparin for the first trimester and returns to warfarin after 12 weeks. What should be the course of anticoagulation in the third trimester?

choices.text: Continue with warfarin till delivery as embryogenesis is already over

questions.solution:
Option B: Restart heparin at 36 weeks

  • The patient needs anticoagulation after valve replacement surgery to prevent thromboembolism.
  • She should be given heparin from 36 weeks onwards as it has a short half-life.
  • Warfarin has a longer half-life. If labor begins while the patient is on warfarin, there is a risk of increased bleeding during delivery.

Option A: Continue with warfarin till delivery, as embryogenesis is already over

  • Warfarin has a longer half-life. If labor begins while the patient is on warfarin, there is a risk of increased bleeding during delivery.

Option C: Restart heparin only in labor

  • Warfarin has a longer half-life. If it is substituted with heparin in labour, it will continue its effect for the next 2 to 5 days. There will be an increased risk of bleeding during delivery.

Option D: Stop anticoagulation at 36 weeks

  • The patient has undergone valve replacement surgery. Anticoagulation should not be discontinued because of the risk of thromboembolism.

questions.text: A 30-year-old infertile patient presents with chronic lower abdominal pain, congestive dysmenorrhea, and dyspareunia. She has regular cycles and today is the 25th day of her period. On vaginal examination, there is pelvic tenderness and nodularity in the posterior fornix. The most probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Option B: Endometriosis

This option is correct because a patient with endometriosis may present with infertility, chronic pelvic pain, congestive dysmenorrhea and dyspareunia.

Presentation of endometriosis:

  • Infertility
  • Pain: dysmenorrhea (congestive type secondary dysmenorrhea), dyspareunia (in lesions over POD), or chronic pelvic pain
  • Pelvic mass
  • Menstrual abnormalities
  • GI symptoms: pain, nausea, vomiting, bloating, distension
  • Specific symptoms of extra pelvic endometriosis

Examination findings of endometriosis

  • Per speculum: bluish spots in the posterior fornix
  • Per vaginum: pelvic tenderness, nodularity in POD, fixed retroverted uterus, adnexal mass
  • Per rectal: nodularity in POD and uterosacral

Note: An important differential here would be PID which may present similar history and findings. However, a nodular POD is more suggestive of endometriosis.

Also, we must remember that almost 30% of infertile women have endometriosis!

Option A: Ruptured ectopic pregnancy

This option is false because a ruptured ectopic pregnancy presents a history of amenorrhea/ early pregnancy with acute abdomen pain; here, pain is chronic and is associated with dysmenorrhea.

Option C: Cervical carcinoma

This option is false because cervical cancer presents with abnormal vaginal bleeding, vaginal discharge, and cancer cachexia.

Option D: Pelvic congestion syndrome

Chronic pain, congestive dysmenorrhea, and pelvic tenderness may all be seen in pelvic congestion, but the history of infertility and nodularity in POD point more towards endometriosis.

Pelvic congestion syndrome is likely when there is

  • Emotional stress
  • A larger mean ovarian vein diameter
  • Compression of the left renal vein at the origin of the superior mesenteric artery (“nutcracker syndrome”)
  • Diagnosis: Transuterine venography or MRI are the primary methods for diagnosis
  • Treatment is hormonal suppression with Low-estrogen, progestin-dominant continuous OCs, high-dose progestins, and GnRH analogs often provide pain relief.
  • Other methods are ovarian vein embolization or hysterectomy and salpingo-oophorectomy

questions.text: A patient with peritoneal endometriotic implants is given medroxyprogesterone acetate for management. What is the mechanism of action involved here?
questions.solution:
Option A: Decidualization and endometrial atrophy

  • This option is correct because progesterones act by exerting an anti-estrogenic effect, and their continuous administration causes decidualization and endometrial atrophy.
  • The treatment over 6 – 9 months produces a state of pseudopregnancy, which ultimately causes regression of disease.
  • It does not affect ovulation.

Progestins used commonly are:

  • Medroxyprogesterone acetate: oral and injectable
  • Mirena IUCD
  • Dienogest
  • Dydrogesterone
  • Megestrol acetate
  • Lynestrol

Option B: Prevention of retrograde menstruation

Continuous progestins can prevent retrograde menstruation by causing amenorrhea, but that is an indirect effect, and it would only, if at all, prevent further development of endometriosis and not regress the existing implants. Retrograde menstruation (transplantation theory) is one of the theories of the occurrence of endometriosis and is still not a definitive cause.

Option C: Thickening of cervical mucous

Progesterones cause thickening of cervical mucous. This action is useful for their role in contraception by acting as a barrier to sperm transport but has no use in treating endometriosis.

Option D: Prevention of ovulation

Progesterones may inhibit ovulation. However, inhibition of ovulation does not treat endometriosis.

questions.text: When planning ART (Artificial Reproductive Techniques) cycles for couples, which factor is not a concern for ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS)?
questions.solution:
Option D: Age > 35 years

  • Ovarian Hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) is a medical complication that is completely iatrogenic and unique to stimulatory infertility treatment. Its symptoms are the result of ovarian enlargement and fragility, extravascular fluid accumulation, and intravascular volume depletion. Advanced age is not a risk factor for OHSS.

Risk factors for OHSS are :

  • Polycystic ovary syndrome
  • Polycystic ovarian morphology with elevated AMH levels (>3.36ng/mL)
  • Previous episodes of OHSS
  • High E2(estradiol) concentrations
  • More than 20 preovulatory follicles
  • Patient factors: Young age, Low BMI
  • High or repeated HCG doses
  • GnRH agonist protocols
  • Pregnancy

OHSS is exclusively seen in infertility-treated patients who have received ovulation induction, with/ without HCG trigger for follicle rupture.

Option A: AMH levels of >3.3 ng/mL

  • Polycystic ovarian morphology with elevated AMH levels of  >3.36ng/mL is a risk factor for the development of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome.

Option B: Estradiol concentration> 3500 pg/mL

  • High estradiol concentrations > 3500 pg/mL are a risk factor for the development of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome.

Option C: Previous history of OHSS

  • The previous history of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome is one of the most important risk factors for OHSS.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents to the doctor with complaints of irregular cycles for a few months. Her cycles are 35-45 days long, lasting for 3 to 4 days with mild to moderate blood flow. There is, however, no passage of clots and no dysmenorrhea. Which of the following accurately describes this condition?
questions.solution:
Option B: Oligomenorrhea

  • Oligomenorrhea is the medical term for having infrequent menstrual periods. A normal menstrual cycle occurs every 28 days and lasts from four to seven days. The period can range from every 21 days to every 35 days and still be considered normal.
  • However, in oligomenorrhea, periods are unpredictable. There may be intervals of more than 35 days without a period. Instead of having periods monthly, menstrual cycles can range from six to eight periods a year.
  • Following are the frequent abnormalities in the menstrual cycle.
    • Oligomenorrhea → Infrequent and irregularly timed bleeding episodes usually occur at intervals of more than 35 days.
    • Polymenorrhea → Frequent episodes of menstruation usually occur at intervals of 21 days or less.
    • Menorrhagia → Enhanced menstrual flow or increased duration at regular menstrual cycles.
    • Hypomenorrhoea → Decreased bleeding and shorter days of bleeding.
    • Metrorrhagia → Irregular bleeding in between the cycles
    • Menometrorrhagia → Enhanced menstrual flow as well as irregular bleeding between the cycles

Option A:  Amenorrhoea

  • It is a false option.
  • Amenorrhea refers to absent periods.

Option C:  Polymenorrhea

  • It is a false option.
  • It means frequent episodes of menstruation, usually occurring at intervals of less than 21 days

Option D: Menorrhagia

  • It is a false option.
  • It means Increased menstrual flow/Increased duration at regular cycles.

questions.text: A 6-year-old male child was brought to the hospital with a complaint of fever associated with abdominal pain. On examination, the patient presents with right upper quadrant tenderness with hepatomegaly. CT abdomen reveals the below-depicted image. Which of the following is the most common organism responsible for this infection?
questions.solution:
Option A: Staphylococcus aureus

  • The above clinical scenario describes the pyogenic liver abscess.

Liver Abscess:  

  • In children with pyogenic liver abscesses, the most common pathogenic organisms include Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus spp.; Escherichia coli, Klebsiella pneumoniae, Salmonella, and anaerobic organisms.

  • Pyogenic liver abscess is more common than amoebic liver abscess in children.

  • Right lobe involvement > left lobe involvement.

  • Signs and symptoms: Fever, chills, night sweats, malaise, fatigue, nausea, abdominal pain with right upper quadrant tenderness, and hepatomegaly.

  • Jaundice is uncommon

  • Ultrasound or CT can confirm the diagnosis.

  • Treatment: Percutaneous ultrasound or CT-guided needle aspiration or open surgical drainage and antibiotics

Option B: Haemophilus influenzae

  • Haemophilus influenzae can cause meningitis, bacteremia and pneumonia, and epiglottitis.

  • Children whose spleen is removed surgically or sickle cell disease patients with functional asplenia are at risk of infections from encapsulated organisms such as Haemophilus influenza. 

Option C: Entamoeba Histolytica

  • Entamoeba histolytica also causes a liver abscess. 

  • However, it is less common than a pyogenic liver abscess.

  • Most uncomplicated amoebic liver abscesses can be treated successfully with conservative management, such as metronidazole or tinidazole.

  • Paromomycin or diloxanide must also be taken to eliminate all the amoeba in the intestine and prevent relapse. ​​

Option D: Klebsiella pneumoniae

  • It is a gram-negative bacteria that can cause different types of healthcare-associated infections.

  • It can cause atypical pneumonia (especially in alcoholics).

  • Atypical pneumonia is caused by atypical organisms that are not detectable on Gram stain and can not be cultured using standard methods.

  • Bloodstream infections, wound or surgical site infections, and meningitis.

questions.text: A 4-month-old male baby presents to the pediatrician with persistent diarrhea. The patient had a history of recurrent attacks of pneumonia and otitis media, for which he had to be hospitalized. No live vaccines were administered to the patient. Further history reveals the diagnosis of severe combined immunodeficiency. Which of the following features is associated with the condition of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: GVHD

The patient, in this case, is diagnosed with SCID and graft vs host disease is most likely associated with this disease.

SCID (Severe Combined Immunodeficiency)

  • In this disease, numerous genetic mutations occur that result in the defective development of functional B and T cells.
  • It is caused by
    • ADA deficiency
    • JAK3 deficiency
    • RAG mutations
  • It may develop mostly if many lymphocytes are introduced into the patient's body or peripheral blood lymphocytes are administered instead of bone marrow cells and cord blood.
  • Due to immune-competent cells attacking an immunosuppressed host, GVHD can still be seen.

Option A: Autoimmune diseases.

  • In SCID, both B and T cells are deficient, so the patient’s immune system is not strong enough to develop any autoimmune disease.
  • So, SCID is not associated with autoimmune diseases.

Option B: Granuloma formation

  • Granuloma is formed in chronic inflammation when the body's immune system forms macrophages to protect against any pathogen.
  • But in SCID immune system is very weak due to a deficiency of B and T cells, so no granuloma formation can occur in this patient.

Option D: Graft rejection

  • Graft rejection can't be done in SCID patients due to a deficiency of T and B cells, which causes a weak body immune system.
  • Combined deficiency of B & T cells is seen in SCID, so autoimmune diseases, granuloma formation & graft rejection are absent.

questions.text: A 2.5-year-old male child was admitted to the pediatric department with complaints of recurrent vomiting episodes and jaundice for 1 year. On examination, the patient has hepatomegaly. Patient labs show hypoglycemia. These episodes seem to have a relationship with the intake of sweet food. The mother also provides additional information about the child's aversion to sugary foods. Which of the following enzymes is most likely deficient in this child?
questions.solution:
Option B: Aldolase B

  • The absence of the enzyme aldolase B is a defining feature of the autosomal recessive condition known as inherited fructose intolerance. Fructose-1-phosphate is broken down into glyceraldehyde and dihydroxyacetone phosphate by the crucial enzyme aldolase B. Fructose-1-phosphate accumulates, toxic to the liver.
  • Intracellular phosphate reserves are lost as fructose-1-phosphate builds up.
  • Severe metabolic abnormalities such as hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, and hypophosphatemia are symptoms of the disease.
  • Following the introduction of weaning foods into the diet, the infant exhibits symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, poor feeding, tiredness, and jaundice.
  • Any patient with the aforementioned clinical characteristics, in addition to hypoglycemia, hypophosphatemia, hyperuricemia, lactic acidosis, and hypermagnesemia, should be suspected of having inherited fructose intolerance.
  • The physical examination may show hepatomegaly, persistent growth limitation, and stomach pain.
  • A macrovesicular fatty alteration in the liver is brought on by hereditary fructose intolerance. Hepatocyte degeneration, fatty alterations, fibrosis, and regenerating nodules are visible under the microscope.
  • The first step in evaluating a patient for genetic fructose intolerance is typically a urine test for reducing chemicals in the presence of suggestive symptoms. Typically, the glucose dipstick test comes back negative. Genetic testing and measuring the aldolase activity in a liver biopsy sample are examples of confirmatory testing.
  • Supportive treatment makes up the majority of acute management.
  • The cornerstone of hereditary fructose intolerance management is the complete avoidance of foods containing fructose, sucrose, and sorbitol-containing goods.

Option A: Glucose-6-phosphatase

  • Von Gierke disease is an AR deficiency of Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency.
  • Clinical signs include severe fasting hypoglycemia, glycogen buildup in the liver and kidneys, elevated blood lactate, triglycerides, uric acid, hepatomegaly and nephromegaly.
  • Treatment consists of taking glucose/cornstarch regularly and avoiding fructose and galactose.

Option C: Branching enzyme

  • Andersen disease (type IV GSD) is due to a deficiency of the Branching enzyme that generates α-1,6-glucosidic branches.
  • The disease commonly presents in early infancy with hepatosplenomegaly and failure to thrive. Other findings include muscular weakness, hypotonia, infantile cirrhosis, cardiomyopathy early childhood death.
  • Hypoglycemia occurs late in the disease.

Option D: Galactose 1 phosphate uridyl transferase

  • The absence of galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase enzyme characterises classic galactosemia.
  • Damage is caused by the accumulation of toxic substances (including galactitol, which accumulates in the eye's lens, causing cataracts).
  • Symptoms include bilateral cataracts, failure to thrive, jaundice, hepatomegaly, intellectual impairment, and oedema.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is brought and admitted by an intern who was on her rotation to Kolkata. She visited the family (strictly vegetarian) allotted to her for the first time. She proceeded with her framed question and marked the family as having low socioeconomic status according to the Udai Parikh scale. The child also looked emaciated and lethargic. On examination, hepatomegaly is present. His weight for age was < -3 Z score, MUAC, 115 mm. What else is to be present in growth-retarded children for the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Edema and mental changes

  • Above mentioned child is suffering from Kwashiorkor.
  • These children have hypoalbuminemia, resulting from inadequate nutrients for protein synthesis. This decreases the intravascular oncotic pressure and results in third spacing, causing oedema.
  • Oedema is assessed by pressing on the third to fourth tarsal bones on the dorsum of the foot for 3-5 seconds and then assessing for pitting oedema for 2-3 seconds.
  • Oedema in malnutrition is classified as follows,
  • Mild (1+) – oedema involves only the feet
  • Moderate (2+) – oedema involves the feet and legs and/or the upper limbs
  • Severe (3+) – Generalized oedema or moderate plus facial oedema.
  • In malnutrition, abnormal brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) findings, such as cerebral atrophy, dilated ventricles, and periventricular white matter changes, are seen.
  • The malnourished child has poor psychosocial development.

Option B: Hypopigmentation and anaemia

  • Protein-energy malnutrition manifests in skin hyperpigmentation which is called flaky paint dermatitis.
  • It is a nonspecific scaly dermatitis, often red-brown, and resembles flaking paint.
  • Anaemia, however, is present due to iron deficiency.

Option C: Edema and hypopigmentation

  • Hyperpigmentation is present on the skin, along with oedema in protein energy malnutrition.
  • However, lightly pigmented areas are present in hair, and these alternating bands are termed flag signs.

Option D: Hepatomegaly and jaundice

  • Hepatomegaly occurs due to excessive fat deposition in the liver.
  • Jaundice is rarely present.

questions.text: A 32-year-old multigravida is at 38 weeks of gestation; she is an unbooked case, and an intern is asked to take the lady's history. Her vitals are normal, and there is no specific history she remembers other than that she has diabetes. Oxytocin is given for labour induction, and an ultrasound is conducted to determine the baby's status. The family is informed regarding the complications their baby might have. What is the most specific congenital abnormality that this baby can have?
questions.solution:
Option D: Transposition of great arteries

  • A baby born alive with a cardiovascular abnormality has a fivefold increased risk in mothers who already have diabetes.
  • The abnormalities specifically linked to maternal diabetes include tricuspid atresia, truncus arteriosus, and transposition of the major arteries.
  • Most common congenital heart disease in a baby born to a diabetic woman: VSD
  • Most specific congenital heart disease in a baby born to a diabetic woman: TGA

Option A: Ventricular Septal defect

  • Aortic stenosis, transposition of the major arteries, and ventricular septal defect are the most common cardiac defects in Infants of diabetic mothers.
  • IDMs are also more likely to have significant artery defects, such as truncus arteriosus and double outlet right ventricle.

Option B: Atrial septal defect

  • Maternal diabetes has been associated with a slightly increased risk of certain congenital heart defects, including ASDs.

Option C: Meningomyelocele

  • Spina bifida is a birth abnormality in which your baby's spine and spinal canal do not close before delivery, including myelomeningocele.
  • Myelomeningocele is typically detectable throughout pregnancy, and surgery to close the opening in your baby's spine can be done either during pregnancy or after delivery.

questions.text: A neonate weighing 1.3 kg was born at 32 weeks of gestation and was transferred to the nursery for prematurity. After 1 hour, the nurse reports the infant is tachypneic with a heart rate of 150 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 76/min, a temperature of 95°F, and an oxygen saturation of 98%. His blood sugar level is normal, and he is not dehydrated. The lungs are clear with bilateral breath sounds, no murmur, and the X-ray chest is normal. Which of the following is the next step in managing the neonate?

choices.text: Obtain a complete blood count and differential
Place the infant under a warmer

questions.solution:
Option D: Place the infant under a warmer

  • The baby is a pre-term infant. He is prone to develop hypothermia because of less subcutaneous fat and low body weight.
  • Large surface area to body mass ratio, immature skin, high water content, poor metabolic activity and decreased cutaneous blood flow are the factors which are responsible for hypothermia in a pre-term baby.
  • One of the main steps to prevent this complication and resultant morbidity is to put the baby under a warmer device.
  • A radiant warmer is a warming device to provide heat.
  • This helps maintain the baby's temperature and limit the metabolism rate.
  • Warm ambience and thermal supplies should be used to keep the room temperature within the required range.

Option A: Administer 5ml of D50 intravenously

  • This is not indicated in this setting, as the patient has average blood glucose and is not dehydrated.
  • This can also put the patient at risk of fluid overload.

Option B: Obtain a complete blood count and differential

  • Investigating the blood picture can be a later step in managing this case
  • This will help to exclude neonatal sepsis, but it is not an immediate step.

Option C: Perform a lumbar puncture

  • This is an invasive procedure.
  • No temperature rise, bulging fontanelle and excessive cry suggest any central nervous system infectious aetiology.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to urology OPD by his father with a complaint of increased penile size and excessive pubic hair. Upon further investigation, his three younger brothers have no history of similar issues. On examination, bilateral testicular enlargement is evident. A comprehensive hormonal evaluation showed an elevated serum testosterone value (4.0 nmol/L) and a prepubertal gonadotropin hormone value. What is the most common cause of peripheral precocious puberty in males?
questions.solution:
Option A: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia

  • Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) is a rare inherited autosomal recessive disorder in which there is a deficiency of one of the enzymes required to synthesize specific hormones (glucocorticoid, mineralocorticoid, and androgen). Congenital adrenal hyperplasia affects the adrenal glands present at the top of each kidney.
  • Many individuals with congenital adrenal hyperplasia present with enlarged adrenal glands, also known as hyperplastic adrenomegaly, which produce excessive male steroid hormone.
  • Due to an enzyme deficiency, the body will be unable to produce one or more of these hormones, which will lead to the overproduction of another type of hormone precursor to compensate for the loss.
  • Males with congenital adrenal hyperplasia have large size of genitalia before reaching puberty. Other symptoms include fast body growth, deep voice, early beard, excessive pubic hair and premature completion of development, leading to short stature if they are not diagnosed and treated in early life.

Option B: Constitutional

  • In males, puberty begins at the age of 9 to 11 years.

  • The sequence of puberty in males is as follows: Testicular enlargement → Penis enlargement → Pubic hair growth→ Peak growth velocity →Axillary hair →Facial hair
  • Precocious puberty is the onset of puberty of fewer than eight years in girls and less than nine years in boys.

Option C: Klinefelter’s syndrome

  • Boys with Klinefelter’s syndrome do not begin or complete pubertal development.
  • There is the failure of the testes to grow normally, incomplete virilization and gynecomastia.

Option D: CNS pathology

  • Many space-occupying lesions, like hamartoma, CNS irradiation, hydrocephalus, etc., can cause precocious puberty.
  • These are associated with other neurological deficits.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy comes with his parents to the hospital with reports showing > +2 S.D height during childhood, and the parents complain that the child did not gain height after that. Which of the following conditions is not associated with tall stature during childhood but normal adult height?
questions.solution:
Option C: Precocious puberty

  • Precocious puberty is a condition in which a child's body starts maturing earlier than usual, including the development of secondary sexual characteristics and rapid growth. It can lead to early closure of growth plates, which can limit further height growth. In this case, a child might have a growth spurt at a younger age but may not reach a significantly taller adult height.
  • So, the condition not associated with tall stature during childhood but normal adult height is Precocious puberty because it can actually limit the final adult height due to early growth plate closure.

Option A: Klinefelter’s syndrome(47XXY)

  • It has extra chromosomes and only occurs in males. Tall stature- Height of a child > +2 S.D of expected according to age and sex of the child.
  • These individuals have the following characteristics:
    • Gynecomastia
    • Infertility
    • Incomplete puberty
    • Small testes, usually undescended
    • Hypotonia
    • Depression 
    • Diabetes
  • Tall stature during childhood but normal adult height is seen in:
    • Constitutional tall structure
    • Exogenous obesity
    • Soto’s syndrome

Option B: Constitutional tall structure

  • This refers to individuals who are naturally taller than their peers due to their genetics, but they follow a normal growth pattern and eventually achieve a normal adult height. It is considered a normal variation in height.

Option D: Soto’s syndrome

  • It is also known as cerebral gigantism. It is an autosomal disorder. The characteristics of this disease include:
    • Long narrow face,
    • Small pointed chin and
    • The affected individual who is taller has an intellectual disability and behavioural problems.
    • Large head size.
  • It is a rare genetic disorder caused by a mutation in nuclear receptor binding SET domain protein 1(NSD1) on chromosome 5.
  • It is characterized by excessive physical growth during the first few years of life.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presented in the ENT outpatient department with a complaint of pain in the left ear with fluid discharge and decreased hearing over the last 6 months. On otoscopic examination, the patient has purulent discharge with large central perforation. The patient was prescribed antibiotics and did not respond. After failure to initial medical antibiotic treatment, the patient is recommended for surgical option and will most likely undergo surgery next week. Based on the given information, the surgical procedure will likely involve one of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Option C: Both A and B

  • The above-given patient is a case of chronic suppurative otitis media, which will manage with tympanoplasty.
  • Tympanoplasty is the surgical operation performed for the reconstruction of the tympanic membrane and/or middle ear ossicles.
  • Myringoplasty is the reconstruction of the tympanic membrane. Ossiculoplasty is the reconstruction of the ossicular chain.
  • Tympanoplasty = Myringoplasty ± Ossiculoplasty.

Tympanoplasty:

It is an operation to,

  • Eradicate disease in the middle ear.
  • To reconstruct the hearing mechanism. It may be combined with mastoidectomy if the disease process so demands.
  • The type of middle ear reconstruction depends on the damage present in the ear.
  • The procedure may be limited only to the repair of the tympanic membrane (myringoplasty), or to the reconstruction of the ossicular chain (ossiculoplasty), or both (tympanoplasty).
  • Reconstructive surgery of the ear has been greatly facilitated by the development of the operating microscope, microsurgical instruments, and biocompatible implant materials.

Types of tympanoplasty Wullstein classified tympanoplasty into five types:

  • Type I: Defect is perforation of the tympanic membrane, which is repaired with a graft. It is also called myringoplasty.
  • Type II: Defect is perforation of tympanic membrane with erosion of malleus. The graft is placed on the incus or remnant of the malleus.
  • Type III: Malleus and incus are absent. The graft is placed directly on the stapes head. It is also called myringostapediopexy or columella tympanoplasty.
  • Type IV: Only the footplate of stapes is present. It is exposed to the external ear, and a graft is placed between the oval and round windows. A narrow middle ear (cavum minor) is thus created to have an air pocket around the round window. A mucosa-lined space extends from the eustachian tube to the round window. Sound waves, in this case, act directly on the footplate while the round window has been shielded.
  • Type V: Stapes footplate is fixed, but the round window is functioning. In such cases, another window is created on the horizontal semicircular canal and covered with a graft. It is also called a fenestration operation.

Option A: Tympanic membrane

  • This option is incorrect.
  • Chronic suppurative otitis media can be treated by tympanoplasty.
  • Tympanoplasty is the surgical operation that is performed not only for the reconstruction of the tympanic membrane but also performed for middle ear ossicles.

Option B: Ossicular chain

  • This option is also incorrect because tympanoplasty is performed not only for the reconstruction of the ossicular chain but also performed for tympanic membrane reconstruction.

Option D: None of the  above

  • This option is also incorrect because tympanoplasty is the surgical operation performed for the reconstruction of the tympanic membrane and/or middle ear ossicles.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the ENT outpatient department complaining of hearing loss and unsteadiness while standing and walking for the past 2 months. She needs to support herself against a wall to avoid falling. The patient has not had any recent injuries and has no history of serious illness. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows an unsteady gait. She sways when asked to stand upright with her feet together. She cannot hear fingers rubbing next to her ears or repeat words whispered in her ears. MRI revealed the below image. Which of the following is the earliest reflex to be lost in this condition?
questions.solution:
Option D: Corneal reflex

The above clinical features are present in bilateral vestibular schwannoma. Loss of corneal reflex (due to 5th nerve involvement).

  • Vestibular schwannoma (VS) is a benign tumour arising from abnormally proliferative Schwann cells, which envelope the lateral portion of the vestibular nerve in the internal acoustic meatus.
  • Earlier name – acoustic neuroma (obsolete now).
    • Most common benign tumor of the cerebellopontine angle (CP angle).
    • Usually unilateral but bilateral in neurofibromatosis II.
  • Site of origin
    • Inferior vestibular nerve in IAC (60-90%) → most common
    • Sometimes sup vestibular nerve.
    • It rarely arises from the cochlear nerve.
      • Arises from Schwann cells in the myelin sheath.

Clinical features:

  • Sensorineural hearing loss - slow & progressive (most common presentation).
  • Tinnitus.
  • Vertigo/dizziness (not prominent).
  • Signs: Earliest - loss of corneal reflex (due to 5th nerve involvement).
  • Hitzelberger sign: Loss of sensory supply by the facial nerve in the posterosuperior wall of EAC
  • Dx: Gadolinium-enhanced MRI→ (IOC)
  • Treatment:
  • Large tumor– surgical excision
  • Small tumor
    • Old patient, slow-growing tumour - serial MRI every 6M.
    • Young patient, fast-growing tumour - gamma knife excision.
  • Approaches for surgical excision→ when there is no hearing present.
  • Translabyrinthine approach→ if hearing present.
    • Middle cranial fossa approach (limited access).
    • Retro sigmoid/suboccipital approach.
  • After Sx excision, the tumour is sent for histopathology. Anatomy A cells- more common, densely packed cells with small spindle-shaped nuclei. Anatomy B cells-loosely arranged vacuolated pleomorphic cells.
  • The best audiometric test for acoustic neuroma is BERA.
  • The most diagnostic finding suggestive of acoustic neuroma on BERA has increased interaural latency of wave V of > 0.2 ms.

Option A: Pharyngeal reflex

  • It is brainstem reflux elicited by touching the posterior part of the throat by a tongue depressor.
  • The patient elevates the soft palate and pharyngeal muscle contract, which indicates a positive test.
  • The pharyngeal reflex is mediated by the efferent motor pathway of CN X and the afferent sensory pathway of CN IX.
  • Loss of pharyngeal reflex indicates the damage of CN IX, CN X, or brain damage.
  • It causes dysphagia and hoarseness due to palatal, pharyngeal, and laryngeal paralysis.

Option B: Laryngeal reflex

  • The laryngeal reflex is a mechanism to protect the larynx and prevent the entering of materials into the upper airways.
  • Loss of laryngeal reflex causes hoarseness of sound, difficulty in breathing, stridor, and cough.

Option C: Stapedial reflex

  • This is involuntary muscle contraction in the ear due to the loud voice.
  • When there is intense sound present, the stapedius and tensor tympani muscles of the ossicles contract.
  • This reflex can be helpful for testing a particular type of hearing loss.
  • Loss of stapedial reflex is due to the CN VIII abnormality, and it causes conducting hearing loss.

questions.text:
A neonate during the 1st week of life presents to the clinic with excessive watering and ropy mucous discharge in the conjunctival sac. On examination, the following structure is found to involve, as shown below:



Which of the following describes correct about the direction of the involved structure?
questions.solution:
Option B: Downward, Backward, and Laterally

  • Nasolacrimal duct opens in anterior part of inferior meatus.
  • The direction of the nasolacrimal duct is backwards (Inwards), laterally, and downwards (Mnemonic: NLD).
  • Tears are actively pumped through the outflow system from the puncta and canaliculi and on into the lacrimal sac.
  • This sits in the bony lacrimal fossa, separated from the middle meatus of the nose by the maxilla and lacrimal bone.
  • The lacrimal sac extends superiorly under the medial canthal ligament as its fundus.
  • The nasolacrimal duct exits from the lower end of the sac and passes in a downward, lateral and posterior direction.
  • It courses anterior to maxillary ostium.
  • The opening of the nasolacrimal duct is guarded by Hasner’s mucosal valve.

Option A: Downward, Backward and Medially

  • The nasolacrimal duct does not move medially.
  • Rather, it travels down and laterally.

Option C: Downward, Forward, and Medially

  • The Direction of the Nasolacrimal Duct has inward, downward and lateral in direction.

Option D: Downward, Forward, and Laterally

  • Nasolacrimal duct opens in anterior part of inferior meatus.
  • The Direction of the Nasolacrimal Duct is Backwards (Inwards), laterally, and downwards (Mnemonic: NLD).

questions.text:
A 65 years old diabetic from low socioeconomic status came to your ENT OPD with complaints of bad breath from the nose for 2 days. She does not complaint of any fever. She reports that she is non-compliant with her medications. Her diabetes is not controlled. Nasal endoscopy revealed below depicted image:



Which of the following is the best treatment?
questions.solution:
Option A: Chloroform diluted with water is correct

Nasal Myiasis

  • Nasal myiasis is a parasitic infestation of the nasal cavity.
  • These parasites continue to grow and destroy the surrounding tissue.
  • The above clinical features are seen in nasal myiasis/maggots.
  • All visible maggots should be picked up with forceps after the instillation of 10% chloroform water; otherwise, many of them try to retreat into darker cavities when light falls on them.
  • These patients are treated conservatively, using saline irrigation and debridement.
  • A patient with maggots should be isolated with a mosquito net to avoid contact with flies which can perpetuate this cycle.
  • All patients should receive instructions for nasal hygiene before leaving the hospital.

Option B: Liquid Paraffin

  • Liquid paraffin is used for impacted wax in the ear to loosen it.
  • It acts as laxatives and also used to treat constipation associated with piles, anal fissure, hernia, cardiovascular disorder, endoscopy, bowel clearance before radioscopy, pre/post-operative conditions, elderly and bed-ridden patients.

Option C: Systemic Antibiotics

  • Systemic antibiotics are used only in infective conditions.
  • There is no role for antibiotics in nasal myiasis.

Option D: Lignocaine Spray

  • There is no role of lignocaine spray in nasal myiasis.
  • This spray is used to numb the mucosa of the oral or nasal cavity before certain medical procedures.

questions.text: A 10-year-old male presented to the ENT outpatient department due to recurrent upper respiratory infections with denasal speech and was diagnosed as a case of chronic adenoid hypertrophy. The patient underwent adenoidectomy. He returns for the follow-up with the complaint of fluid leakage through the nose while eating. Which of the following complications is the most likely cause of this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
Option C: Velopharyngeal Insufficiency

Complications of adenoidectomy:

  • Hemorrhage: seen in the immediate postoperative period.
  • Injury to eustachian tube opening.
  • Injury to pharyngeal musculature and vertebrae.
  • Grisel syndrome: neck pain and torticollis due to spasm of paraspinal muscles.
  • Velopharyngeal insufficiency.
  • Nasopharyngeal stenosis.
  • Recurrence of adenoid hypertrophy.
  • Cock robin deformity.

Velopharyngeal Insufficiency:

  • Risk factors for velopharyngeal insufficiency after adenoidectomy:
    • Occult submucous cleft
    • Neuromuscular disorders (CNS)
    • History of nasopharyngeal regurgitation before surgery
  • Adenoidectomy causes transient velopharyngeal sphincter dysfunction in about 5% of cases. This can cause troublesome rhinolalia aperta.
  • Velopharyngeal insufficiency (VPI) can occur in children with a repaired cleft palate, those with a submucous cleft, and children without any obvious palatal abnormalities. It can also occur after adenoidectomy, with a clinically significant incidence between 1 in 1500 and 1 in 3000.
  • It is necessary to check for submucous cleft palate by inspection and palpation before removal of adenoids.
  • Velopharyngeal dysfunction (VPD) is a disorder of the velopharyngeal (VP) sphincter or valve, which separate the nasal and oral cavities during speech, swallowing, vomiting, blowing, and sucking.
  • When the soft palate and pharyngeal walls are unable to form an effective seal, an abnormal connection between the nasal and oral cavities leads to
    • Hypernasal speech
    • Increased nasal resonance
    • Nasal regurgitation
    • Nasal emission
    • Decreased intraoral pressure during speech.
  • The overall result is decreased speech intelligibility and significant functional and social impairment.
  • Nasopharyngeal regurgitation causes recurrent upper respiratory infections.

Option A: Grisel syndrome

It is an incorrect option because:

  • Grisel syndrome presents as neck pain and torticollis.
  • It is due to a spasm of paraspinal muscles or atlantoaxial dislocation.
  • It does not present with regurgitation of fluid from the nose.

Option B: Nasopharyngeal stenosis

It is an incorrect option because:

  • Nasopharyngeal stenosis occurs due to excess mucosal removal or scarring during an adenoidectomy.
  • It presents as mouth breathing, snoring, rhinorrhea, hyponasality, dysphagia, otalgia, loss of hearing, and anosmia.
  • It does not lead to regurgitation of fluid from the nose.

Option D: Cock robin deformity

questions.text:
A 37-year-old female presents to the ENT department with a hoarse voice for the past few days. She also has occasional gastric reflux symptoms and a constant desire to clear her throat. On laryngoscopy following finding is seen:



Which of the following is incorrect regarding her condition?

choices.text: Unilateral & over the vocal process of arytenoids
Speech therapy to correct the pitch of voice
Intralesional injection of steroid is given to correct inflammation and size of granuloma

questions.solution:
Option B: Throat pain improves on phonation

  • The location of various laryngeal lesions is as follows:
  • Vocal polyp- Unilateral & Junction of anterior 1/3rd and posterior 2/3rd.
  • Vocal nodule- Bilateral & Junction of anterior 1/3rd and posterior 2/3rd.
  • Reinke's edema- Bilateral & Diffuse.
  • Contact granuloma- Unilateral & Over the vocal process of arytenoids, associated with Reflux disease.
  • The laryngoscope findings in the question above are consistent with a contact granuloma.
  • Contact granuloma is almost always unilateral and is found over the vocal process of arytenoids.
  • It is usually associated with and caused by gastric reflux.
  • Chief complaints are hoarse voice, a constant desire to clear the throat, and throat pain worse on phonation. Management includes:
  • Anti-reflux therapy.
  • Speech therapy to stop throat clearing and correct pitch of voice.
  • Inhaled steroids or intralesional injection of steroid to stop inflammation and size of granuloma. Micro-laryngeal surgery may be needed to remove granuloma.

Option A: Unilateral & over the vocal process of arytenoids

This is false because:

  • Contact granuloma is primarily unilateral, and over the vocal process of arytenoids.

Option C: Speech therapy to correct the pitch of voice

This is false because:

  • Speech therapy is employed in its treatment to correct the pitch of voice in patients with contact granuloma.

Option D: Intralesional injection of steroid is given to correct inflammation and size of granuloma

This is false because:

  • Intralesional injection of steroid is often given to correct inflammation and size of granuloma.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a complaint of epistaxis. After a series of treatments, the bleeding could not be stopped. His medical history is consistent with hypertension and diabetes. His medications include metformin and amlodipine. An attempt to block the external carotid artery is made which does not lead to resolution of the bleeding. Which of the following artery is responsible for the bleeding in this case?
questions.solution:
Option D: Anterior Ethmoidal Artery

  • Both external and internal carotid arteries supply the nose through their branches.
  • The source of epistaxis after ligation of the external carotid artery is from the internal carotid branch, i.e., the anterior ethmoidal artery.
  • Anterior ethmoidal artery ligation is considered for continued epistaxis uncontrolled by other means.
  • The anterior ethmoid artery is an extension of the ophthalmic artery, which is a branch of the internal carotid artery system.
  • As such, this is branch is unable to be addressed by embolization techniques.
  • If epistaxis is severe enough to consider addressing the anterior ethmoid artery, additional consideration of ligating the sphenopalatine artery should be entertained.
  • The posterior ethmoid artery, also a branch of the ophthalmic artery, is not routinely ligated due to its proximity to the optic nerve and inherent risk of injury to the nerve.
  • The anterior ethmoidal artery is identified via subperiostial elevation through a Lynch incision.
  • The artery is approximately 24mm from the anterior lacrimal crest and lies along the frontoethmoidal suture line. The following drawing demonstrates the artery as a distal branch of the ophthalmic artery.

Option A: Maxillary artery

  • The maxillary artery is a branch of the external carotid artery.
  • The bleed should stop when the external carotid is ligated.

Option B: Greater palatine artery

  • The greater palatine artery is a branch of the external carotid artery.
  • The bleed should stop when the external carotid is ligated.

Option C: Superior labial artery

  • The superior labial artery is a branch of the external carotid artery.
  • The bleed should stop when the external carotid is ligated.

questions.text: A 78-year-old female a known case of hypertension and uncontrolled diabetes mellitus for 15 years presents in the OPD with the complaint of otalgia (ear pain) and greenish-black discharge. On examination, the patient has tenderness over the temporal region. On otoscopy, she has multiple granulations in the external auditory canal. The culture of the discharge turns out to be Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Which of the following is the drug of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Ciprofloxacin

  • This patient is presented with necrotising otitis externa, an inflammatory condition most commonly caused by Pseudomonas infection.
  • It is found in elderly diabetics or immunocompromised patients (immunosuppressive therapy patients with cancer, AIDs, etc.)
  • The main symptoms, as described in the above scenario, are excruciating pain and granulations in the external ear.
  • Diagnosis is made by history and examination, and culture is done to confirm the presence of Pseudomonas.
  • CT scan can be done to check for any necrosis of bones, but Gallium-67 is more useful in the patient's follow-up; it is repeated every three weeks to check the response of the treatment. It is taken up by monocytes and reticuloendothelial cells and indicates soft tissue infection.
  • If untreated, malignant otitis externa can cause facial palsy, and infection may spread to the skull base causing multiple cranial nerve palsies.
  • Ciprofloxacin (at least 750 mg orally twice per day) is the antibiotic of choice, and prolonged treatment for a minimum of 6–8 weeks is recommended; because it shows good anti-pseudomonal activity and tissue penetration.
  • Ciprofloxacin belongs to the quinolones group of antibiotics.
  • The most common side effects are nausea and diarrhoea 
  • Pseudomonas resists itself rapidly, but so far, Ciprofloxacin use has shown a good response in eradicating the disease.
  • Other antibiotic choices for malignant otitis externa include :
    • Gentamicin combined with Ticarcillin.
    • Ceftriaxone or Ceftazidime.
    • Ofloxacin, and Levofloxacin.

Option A: Penicillin

  • Although Penicillin can be used for treating malignant otitis externa in combination with an Aminoglycoside, Pseudomonas has an outstanding ability to develop resistance against anti-microbials. Nowadays, Ciprofloxacin is the antibiotic of choice and prolonged treatment for the necrotising otitis externa.

Option B: 2nd generation cephalosporin

  • Due to the ability of Pseudomonas to develop resistance, it needs more powerful antibiotics like 3rd generation Cephalosporin or Quinolones.
  • Ciprofloxacin is the antibiotic of choice and prolonged treatment for the necrotising otitis externa.

Option D: Gentamicin

  • Gentamicin combined with Ticarcillin is effective, but Gentamicin is both ototoxic and nephrotoxic and better treatments are available such as 3rd generation Cephalosporins and Quinolones.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to your clinic by his mother. The mother says the child complains of a foreign body sensation in his eyes and dry eyes, and she has noticed the redness of his eyes for the past two weeks. His diet is poor in fruits and vegetables. His best-corrected visual acuity is 20/20 in both eyes, with normal motility and fundus. Slit-lamp examination shows keratinisation of the temporal and nasal conjunctiva with bilateral bitot spots. Which of the following is the best treatment for this child?

choices.text: Oral vitamin A 1 lakh units for 0, 1, 28 days
IM vitamin A 1 lakh units for 0, 1, 28 days
Oral vitamin A 1 lakh units for 0, 1, 14 days
IM vitamin A 1 lakh units for 0, 1, 14 days

questions.solution:
Option D: IM vitamin A 1 lakh units for 0, 1, 14 days

  • Xerophthalmia is a disease caused by severe Vitamin A deficiency.
  • It is one of the major causes of preventable blindness in developing countries.
  • Xerophthalmia is characterised by the following:
    • Night blindness
    • Conjunctival xerosis
    • Bitot spots
    • Corneal xerosis 
    • Corneal ulceration
    • Corneal scar 
    • Xerophthalmic fundus
  • Treatment for children over one year of age is 2 lakh units of vitamin A given orally at 0, 1 and 28 days or 1 lakh IM units at 0, 1 and 14 days.

Option A: Oral vitamin A 1 lakh units for 0, 1, 28 days

  • Half the dose is given for children less than one year of age; 1 lakh units of vitamin A are given orally at 0, 1, and 28 days or 0.5 lakh IM units at 0, 1 and 14 days.
  • This child is 3 years old.

Option B: IM vitamin A 1 lakh units for 0, 1, 28 days

  • Treatment for children over one year of age is 2 lakh units of vitamin A given orally at 0, 1 and 28 days or 1 lakh IM units at 0, 1 and 14 days.
  • IM treatment is given at 0, 1 and 14 days.

Option C: Oral vitamin A 1 lakh units for 0, 1, 14 days

  • Half the dose is given for children less than one year of age; 1 lakh units of vitamin A are given orally at 0, 1, and 28 days or 0.5 lakh IM units at 0, 1 and 14 days. 
  • This child is 3 years old.

questions.text: A sixty-year-old male presents to your clinic with the complaint of blurry vision in his right eye for the past month. About a year ago, the patient underwent phacoemulsification surgery for cataract removal of the same eye. The defective vision was gradual in onset and was not associated with pain, redness or watering. According to the patient, his cataract surgery was uncomplicated, and his vision was perfect after surgery. The most common cause of this patient’s condition is?
questions.solution:
Option A: Posterior capsular opacification

  • Posterior capsule opacification (PCO) is also called after cataract or secondary cataract.

  • It is the most common postoperative complication of cataract surgery.

  • The younger the age of the patient, the faster the occurrence.

  • In PCO, the posterior capsule becomes secondarily opacified due to the migration, proliferation, and differentiation of lens epithelial cells.

  • The symptoms are a slow, painless loss of vision following cataract surgery.

  • Types of PCO are:

    • Elschnig’s pearls (most common)

    • Soemmering's ring.

  • Treatment is done by ND: YAG laser. The wavelength of this laser is 1064 nm.

Option B: Neovascular glaucoma

  • Neovascular glaucoma is a type of secondary glaucoma.

  • The angle of the eye is closed due to the formation of new blood vessels.

  • Neovascular glaucoma typically develops in eyes with severe retinal vein blockage or severe diabetic eye disease.

  • The symptoms of neovascular glaucoma can include pain, redness, and decreased vision, although it is possible not to have any symptoms in the early stages of the disease.

  • This is not a complication of cataract surgery.

Option C: Chorioretinitis

  • Chorioretinitis is an inflammation of the choroid.

  • This inflammation can affect vision.

  • This is not a complication of cataract surgery.

Option D: Cystoid macular edema

  • Cystoid Macular edema (CME) is the thickening of the macula due to a disruption of the normal blood-retinal barrier.

  • Loss of vision occurs due to retinal thickening and fluid collection that disrupts the architecture of the photoreceptors.

  • This is not a complication of cataract surgery.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old patient presents to the clinic complaining of itching and ocular pain. The examination of his eye shows the following findings:



Which of the following is not a feature of the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Chalazion

  • The given image shows Arlt's line on the upper palpebral conjunctiva - a feature of trachoma.
  • It does not cause chalazion.

Chalazion:

  • A chalazion is a chronic granulomatous inflammation of the meibomian gland.
  • Etiology:
    • It is probably due to chronic irritation caused by an organism of low virulence.
  • The glandular tissue is replaced by granulation tissue containing giant cells predominantly.
  • It is often multiple occurring in crops. 
  • It is more common in adults than in children. 
  • Seen in people with oily skin and ocular rosacea.
  • Symptoms
    1. There is no pain unless the chalazion is secondarily infected.
    2. There is disfigurement due to the presence of swelling in the lid.
    3. It may be single or multiple.
  • Signs
    1. A small non-tender hard swelling in the lid, slightly away from the lid margin, is seen.
    2. There are no signs of acute inflammation.
    3. On everting the lid, the conjunctiva over the swelling is red or purple. It is grey in later stages. It may be yellow when secondarily infected by pyogenic organisms.
  • Treatment:
    • It is incised and thoroughly scraped.
    • Injection of triamcinolone directly into the chalazion may cause complete resolution.

Option A: Corneal opacity

  • Trachoma can cause corneal opacity, which can lead to blindness.

Option C: Entropion

  • Entropion is the inward turning of the eyelashes, which can lead to conjunctivitis due to constant irritation.
  • It is a feature of trachoma.

Option D: Herbert's pits

  • In trachoma, regression of the follicles leads to depressed, round, thinned areas known clinically as Herbert's pits.

​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 19-year-old female who was a victim of an acid attack was brought to the emergency department with complaints of severe facial pain. The pulse of the patient is 130 bpm. She is otherwise vitally stable. The was managed and stabilized. After initial stabilization, the damages were evaluated, and there was extensive ocular damage. Which of the following facts is true about the injury involved in this case?

choices.text: Steroids are used for initial management
Glaucoma is the most preventable complication following the acid injury

questions.solution:
Option D: Glaucoma is the most preventable complication following the acid injury

  • This is a case of acid injury in which the patient presents to the emergency department after an acid attack.
  • The patient complains of severe facial pain.
  • The patient has a high pulse, while the other vitals are in the normal range.
  • On examination, there is extensive ocular damage.
  • Chemical injuries of the eye may be divided into 2 types:
  • Acid injuries (burns)- less destructive → coagulate and precipitate proteins → create a barrier and prevent further penetration (except- hydrofluoric acid → fluoride ions penetrate into deep tissues → more damage)
  • It is managed by washing with normal saline.
  • Chemical debris can be removed by double eversion.
  • Other Mx options - Autologous serum, amniotic membrane transplantation (AMT), mucous membrane graft and conjunctival flaps.

Option A: Releases proteolytic enzymes

  • The acid injuries are less destructive, and they don't release any proteolytic enzyme.
  • Alkali injuries release proteolytic enzymes.

Option B: More destructive than alkali injuries

  • Alkali injuries- severe, they are lipophilic → saponification of membrane lipids → tissues undergo liquefactive necrosis plus the release of proteolytic enzymes → damage.

Option C: Steroids are used for initial management

  • Immediate Irrigation with normal saline (even water if normal saline is not available) for a minimum of 30 min, pH of conjunctiva must be 7-7.2.

questions.text: A 44-year-old male was referred to your clinic because of pain, redness, and elevated eye pressure in the right eye. The patient also gave a history of four similar episodes, in which he had the same symptoms and his eye pressure was elevated. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Features of Glaucomatocyclitic crisis (Posner-Schlossman syndrome): It typically affects young adults and is characterized by:

  • Recurrent attacks of acute rise of IOP (40-50 mm of Hg) without shallowing of the anterior chamber

  • Fine KPs at the back of cornea without any posterior synechiae

  • Epithelial corneal oedema

  • A dilated pupil

  • A white-eye (no congestion)

Treatment: It includes medical treatment to lower intraocular pressure along with a short course of topical steroids.

questions.text: A 5-month-old infant presents to the ophthalmology OPD with cloudy eyes since birth. On examination, the infant is not visually aware of the surrounding environment. Her eyes appear as shown in the image below. Which of the following does not cause this condition?
questions.solution:
Option D: Marfan’s syndrome

  • This infant with cloudy eyes since birth and no visual awareness has a congenital cataract.
  • Marfan’s syndrome is associated with lens subluxation due to zonular weakness. It does not cause congenital cataracts.
  • Cataracts may develop earlier in the subluxated lens compared to others of the same age but will not be congenital cataracts.

Option A: Trisomy 21

  • Trisomy 21 is called down’s syndrome.
  • It is a known cause of congenital cataracts.

Option B: Stickler syndrome

  • It is a connective tissue disorder that affects vision, hearing and joints.
  • It is associated with congenital lamellar cataracts.

Option C: Lowe’s syndrome

  • It is a rare disorder that affects the eyes, brain and kidneys.
  • It causes congenital cataracts and glaucoma.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female presents to the physician with complaints of a slowly enlarging painless mass in front of her neck. She further gives the history that this mass had grown over a three-year period. She has the sensation that food is getting stuck in her upper throat, and she easily feels fatigued. He is vitally stable, and the examination of reveals that the swelling has multiple nodules. The thyroid ultrasound revealed Grave’s disease. If the patient has eye involvement with the progression of the disease, then which of the following will be affected first?
questions.solution:
Option B: Inferior rectus

  • This is a case of multinodular goitre in which the patient presents with complaints of a slowly enlarging painless mass in front of the neck.
  • The patient further gave a history that the mass had grown over a three-year period.
  • The goitre is usually a mass which grows slowly over time.
  • It can lead to the symptoms of difficulty in breathing and the feeling of food getting stuck in the throat.
  • The examination of the patient, in this case, reveals multinodular goitre.
  • The goitre is classified into two types on the bases of nodularity: solitary nodules and multiple nodules.
  • The multinodular goitre most commonly occurs in hypothyroidism.
  • When this disease affects the eyes, the first muscle to be affected is the inferior rectus.

Option A: Lateral rectus

  • The lateral rectus is not the first muscle to be affected in thyroid ophthalmopathy.
  • The first muscle to be affected is the inferior rectus.
  • The lateral rectus is affected after the inferior rectus.

Option C: Medial rectus

  • The medial rectus is an adductor muscle.
  • This muscle functions along with the lateral rectus for the abduction of the eyes.
  • It is affected only if the inferior rectus is already affected in thyroid ophthalmopathy.

Option D: Superior rectus

  • The superior rectus is one of the very important muscles of the eye.
  • It helps in the elevation of the eyeball.
  • The elevation of the eyeball causes the cornea to move superiorly.
  • ​​​​​​​Inferior rectus is the first muscle affected, not superior rectus.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents in the outpatient department with a complaint of blurry vision, decreased visual acuity, redness, and floaters in both eyes. There is a vitreous cell found in both eyes on physical examination. The rest of the physical examination is normal. The vitals are within normal limits. What are the two tumours that can be considered in this patient which are commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Option D: Sebaceous Cancer, intraocular lymphoma

  • In the above-given case, the sign and symptoms of blurry vision, decreased visual acuity, floaters, and vitreous cells are suggestive of the diagnosis of Masquerade syndrome.
  • Sebaceous cancer and intraocular lymphoma are associated with Masquerade syndrome.
  • Sebaceous carcinoma originates from the sebaceous glands of the skin.
    • It primarily affects the eyelid and causes skin thickening.
  • Intraocular lymphoma is a lymphocytic malignancy.
    • Primary intraocular lymphoma (PIOL) is a subtype of primary central nervous system lymphoma (PCNSL).
  • Masquerade syndrome is intraocular tumour necrosis that may present as sterile endophthalmitis.
  • These include a group of diseases: Acute leukemia, iris melanoma, juvenile xanthogranuloma, small round cell malignancies, anterior segment ischemia, reticulum cell sarcoma or large cell lymphoma are some conditions which can present in this manner.
  • Eyelid sebaceous carcinoma and intraocular lymphoma are often associated with masquerade syndromes.

Option A: Conjunctival lymphoma, choroidal melanoma

  • Conjunctival lymphoma is an ocular tumour which is painless, salmon-pink and appears as a fleshy patch.
    • It generally has a smooth surface but appears multinodular sometimes or as follicular conjunctivitis.
    • It is most related to Non-Hodgkin lymphoma.
  • Choroidal Melanoma is a common intraocular tumour.
    • It's the primary intraocular malignant tumour in adults.

Option B: Conjunctival lymphoma, intraocular lymphoma

  • Conjunctival lymphoma is an ocular tumour which is painless, salmon-pink and appears as a fleshy patch.
    • It generally has a smooth surface but appears multinodular sometimes or as follicular conjunctivitis.
    • It is most related to Non-Hodgkin lymphoma.
  • Intraocular lymphoma is a lymphocytic malignancy.
    • Primary intraocular lymphoma PIOL is a subtype of primary central nervous system lymphoma (PCNSL).
    • Intraocular lymphoma can originate outside the central nervous system and metastasise to the eye.

Option C: Basal cell carcinoma, retinoblastoma

  • Basal cell carcinoma is skin cancer.
    • It develops in the areas of the body exposed to sunlight.
    • It appears as a bump and presents with a rolled margin or border.
