  • Retinoblastoma is an ocular tumour that originated in the retina.
    • It affects young children commonly.
  • Both of these are not linked to Masquerade syndrome.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy presents to the clinic with the complaint of fever, runny nose, and cough for the past three days. The boy also has a rash over his body. The mother reports that the boy first developed a fever and runny nose a few days ago. Today she noticed a rash, as shown below:



Which of the following term best describes the skin findings in the patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Morbilliform

  • This patient most likely has a morbilliform rash.
  • Exanthematous (maculopapular) drug eruption, also called morbilliform (measles-like) drug-induced exanthem, is the most common drug hypersensitivity reaction. It is characterized by a disseminated and occasionally generalized, symmetric eruption of erythematous macules and papules that occur approximately one to two weeks after initiating treatment with the causative drug or, in previously sensitized individuals, as early as 6 to 12 hours and up to three days after initiating treatment with the causative drug.
  • The exanthematous drug eruption should be differentiated from more severe forms of drug hypersensitivity, where the mucous membranes (oral, conjunctival, nasal, anogenital) and internal organs may be involved.

Differential Diagnosis of Morbilliform Reactions:

Common

  • Morbilliform drug eruptions - Common antibiotics can trigger a morbilliform drug eruption. These medications include penicillins, sulfonamides, thiazides, sulfonylureas, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), aromatic anticonvulsants, and gold.
  • Morbilliform viral eruptions (many) - Measles, Rubella, Scarlet fever, HHV 6.

Uncommon

  • Severe drug hypersensitivity reaction
  • Lupus erythematosus
  • Rickettsial infections
  • Serum sickness
  • Roseola vaccinatum
  • This eruption is usually self-limited and may last an average of 1-2 weeks

Option A: Herpetiform

  • It occurs in a grouped configuration with polycyclic margins. This patient most likely has morbilliform eruptions.

Option B: Lichenoid eruptions

  • These are violaceous to purple, polygonal lesions that resemble those seen in lichen planus. The best term for this patient’s lesions is morbilliform.

Option D: Milia

  • These are small, firm, white papules filled with keratin. This patient has morbilliform eruptions secondary to viral infection.

questions.text:
A 59-year-old woman presents to the dermatologic clinic to evaluate her skin lesions. She states that it has been present for several years and is not associated with other symptoms. On examination following lesion is noted as shown below:



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Fibroepithelial polyp

  • This is a case of fibroepithelial polyp in which the patient presents with complaints of skin lesion for several year and is asymptomatic.
  • Fibroepithelial polyp (Skin tag; Papilloma; Acrochordon)
  • Seen at sites of chafing such as the groin, axilla, or neck.
  • Benign and typically have a narrow stalk
  • Most cases are idiopathic but occasionally associated with insulin resistance.
  • Hanging or protruding polyps
  • Made of loosely arranged collagen fibers and blood vessels surrounded by the thick epidermis
  • Multiple causes include insulin resistance, human papillomavirus, acromegaly, and HIV.
  • Cryotherapy, surgical excision, and electrosurgery are the treatment options

Option A: Dermatofibromas

  • They are seen on legs or arms and are within the skin.
  • Painful nodule
  • The dimple sign is positive

Option C: Keratoacanthomas

  • They are benign tumors of the skin.
  • It contains a central plug of keratin.

Option D: Nodular BCC

  • Presents with nodule.
  • With or without central cystic change and telangiectasias.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presented to the office by his parents with a skin rash for 2 weeks. He was born out of a consanguineous marriage and had a history of the collodion membrane. Vital signs are normal. On examination, he had large, thick, plate-like brown scaling in a generalized distribution; no erythroderma and ectropion. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Lammellar ichthyosis

  • This patient’s signs and symptoms indicate Lamellar Ichthyosis (LI).
  • It is an autosomal recessive disease in which there is a deficiency of the transglutaminase-1 enzyme.
  • Large thick brown plate-like hyperkeratosis occurs as shown in the image below:

  • The scaling occurs over the whole body. In severe cases drooping of lower eyelids (ectropion), palmoplantar keratoderma, and scarring alopecia occurs.
  • The affected babies also have a history of collodion membrane at birth
ICHTHYOSIS VULGARIS X LINKED ICHTHYOSIS LAMELLAR ICHTHYOSIS
AD XLR AR
Def. of filaggrin Def. of steroid sulphatase enzyme Def. of transglutaminase-1 enzyme

Fine scales

Extensors mainly involved

Winter exacerbation

Thick brown hyperkeratosis

Flexors spared

Birth complications

Larger thick brown plate-like hyperkeratosis

The whole body involved' Collodion membrane/ baby

Option A: Ichthyosis Vulgaris​​​​​

  • Ichthyosis Vulgaris occurs due to a deficiency of filaggrin.
  • The affected patient has a long-lasting history of fine fish-like scales affecting extensor surfaces.

Option C: X Linked Ichthyosis

  • Linked Ichthyosis is an X-linked recessive disease caused by the deficiency of steroid sulphatase enzyme.
  • Flexor areas are spared.

Option D: Netherton syndrome

  • Newborns have skin that is red and scaly (ichthyosiform erythroderma).
  • Triad – ichthyosis, hair shaft abnormality, and severe atopic diathesis

questions.text:
A 16-year-old boy is brought by his mother after she noticed a dry, red patch on his back thirty minutes ago. He gives a history of an itchy rash that started on his shoulders that later spread to his trunk. He also added a history of sore throat 2 weeks ago. On examination, there are erythematous scaly papules and plaques, as shown in the picture:



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Pityriasis rosea

Pityriasis rosea:

  • A viral etiology for PR has been hypothesized based on the following observations:
    1. ​​​​​​​PR is sometimes preceded by a prodrome of headache, malaise, and pharyngitis.
    2. It occasionally occurs in small case clusters.
    3. It is not associated with bacterial or fungal organisms.

Following are the features of pityriasis rosea:

  • It may be preceded by a prodrome of headache, malaise, and/or sore throat but is mostly asymptomatic.
  • Diagnosis is based on medical history and physical examination.
  • The rash is itchy and starts with a herald patch.
  • Spreads classically downwards or centrifugally on the trunk and proximal extremities.
  • The herald patch is erythematous, round, and centrally clear with peripheral scales.
  • Collarette scale and Hanging curtain sign are characteristically seen

Option A: Guttate psoriasis 

  • It occurs as an acute eruption of small (1–10 mm) salmon-pink papules without central clearing, primarily involving the trunk.
  • This patient's symptoms and clinical appearance of rash are more suggestive of pityriasis rosea.

Option B: Tinea corporis 

  • While tinea corporis may be confused with a herald patch of Pityriasis rosea,
  • Tinea corporis does not typically result in the numerous lesions seen in this patient.

Option D: Herpes zoster 

  • Herpes zoster is a viral infection that occurs with reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus.
  • It is usually a painful but self-limited dermatomal rash.
  • Symptoms typically start with pain along the affected dermatome, followed in 2-3 days by a vesicular eruption.
